While Amazon is a notable exclusion, the analysts believe a deal could be reached in coming months. We view this is key to widespread adoption as, although Disney may be a household name, it's not a household device company and as a result, these deals will be key to actually putting the service in front of potential buyers, in their own homes. However, the analysts did downwardly revise near-term earnings estimates due to lower-than-expected fiscal third-quarter results, weak fiscal fourth-quarter guidance, and "more significant secular pressure on both legacy and acquired TV network assets." In addition to the secular pressure in traditional pay TV assets (which should come as no surprise given the now well understood cord cutting dynamic) the analysts called out margin pressure resulting from investments in original content creation, and the removal of licensing revenue as Disney brings assets in-house to build out its own streaming platforms. In our view, this too is well understood and a worthwhile tradeoff as we believe Disney needs to come out of the gate strong with its Disney+ release in order to solidify its service as a must have in the increasingly competitive streaming space -- especially if the company is to ultimately grow through the cord cutting dynamic. 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.24%; Yield: 1.35%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Disney's direct to consumer efforts via ESPN+ and Disney+ and are happy to ride out the associated investment cycle. Additionally, we view the integration of Fox assets as another catalyst as progress is made given the acquisition brings with it programming across six continents, reaching over 1.8 billion consumers that speak roughly 50 different languages, as well as the rights to Start India, India being one of the fastest growing countries in the world and all of the domestic content, plus an additional 30% ownership of Hulu, bringing their total Hulu ownership to 60%.Furthermore, we are bullish on the Studio Entertainment division's 2019 movie lineup, which features a new Avengers, Toy Story 4, and live-action reboots of The Lion King and Aladdin, amongst other titles. Lastly, we believe a strong consumer should continue to support attendance and spending at Parks and Resorts. Target Price: Reiterate $150; Rating: Two


RISKS: Fox integration risk, competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting the consumer


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Home Depot ; $227.93; 150 shares; 1.26%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Friday Home Depot saw its price target increased to $255 by analysts at Oppenheimer. Key to the analysts' views are what is going on in the mortgage market. The analysts point out that the average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage has declined about 130 basis points since later-2018. They believe this contraction in mortgage costs (down from 5% to 3.65%) "help fuel" Home Depot's fundamentals. "We are increasingly optimistic that a recent, meaningful moderation in mortgage rates should prove an incremental sales tailwind within the space and help support further the multiples at which HD and LOW trade." We are still looking for a pullback to the $215 level as the price we would upgrade shares back to a ONE, which we indicated last week in our Alert . 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.84%; Yield: 2.39%


INVESTMENT THESIS: The unquestioned leader in home improvement supplies, we like Home Depot for its consistent same-store sales performance, ability to gain market share and improve margins, and its business model that is relatively immune from Amazon-like pressures. We initiated our position shortly before the Spring--Home Depot's "Holiday season" --expecting the company to outperform expectations. Longer term, management's 2020 financial targets include sales to increase to the range of $115 billion to $120 billion, with operating margins in a range of 14.4% to 15% and return on invested capital of more than 40%. Lastly, Home Depot is a cash-generating machine. Making good use of its cash flows, the company recently authorized a 32% increase to its quarterly dividend (which puts the yield ~3.0%) as well as announced a $15 billion share repurchase program. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: Two


RISKS: Consumer Spending habits; Housing market downturn; inclement weather


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , Investor Relations



Honeywell ; $163.63; 300 shares; 1.81%; Sector: Industrials


WEEKLY UPDATE: No company updates this week, but Credit Suisse did publish their U.S. Multi Industry Q319 preview. Honeywell was labeled one of two names they believe are "most favorable into the print," acknowledging that Q3 organic sales could see some pressure, but the analysts expect modest negative revisions to 2019/2020 EPS compared to other industrials. This view is similar to how we have viewed Honeywell as a "defensive" industrial, which is thanks to its long-cycle exposure and pristine balance sheet. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.62%; Yield: 2.20%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Following a 2018 year when the company spun off two businesses, we believe the new Honeywell is worthy of a premium to its peer group as it has become less cyclical and more focused with stronger organic sales growth trends. The two segments we remain most positive on for their long-term growth profiles are Aerospace and Safety and Productivity Solution, as both stand to benefit from strong secular trends. Additionally, we appreciate management's ability to drive operational improvements in areas such as margin and free cash flow. Lastly, the balance sheet is clean has plenty of optionality, keeping the door open for accretive M&A and/or share buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $175; Rating: Two


RISKS: A slowdown in the aerospace market, a deterioration in commodity prices that affect businesses within PMT segment, trade war/tariffs exposure.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , Investor Relations



JPMorgan Chase & Co. ; $114.62; 650 shares; 2.75%; Sector: Financial


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.63%; Yield: 3.14%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view JPMorgan as the best of breed large cap financial. The firm consistently delivers the best return on equity/tangible common equity performance in the industry, making the stock well deserving of a premium to its growing tangible book value. Not only that, but the Fortress balance sheet provides a degree of insulation to the risks associated with an economic shock. Lastly, we believe the valuation is very reasonable, especially considering the roughly 3% dividend yield and big buyback. The firm's tangible book value per share as of the end of the second quarter 2019 is $59.42. Target Price: Reiterate $130; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, interest rates, credit quality.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



Lam Research ; $233.27; 150 shares; 1.29%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Analysts at KeyBanc came out in support of the semiconductor capital equipment space this week noting that "Broad-based [semiconductor] demand remains weak, but it appears we've found a true bottom, as inventories begin to normalize and expectations set up for a normal seasonal 4Q to close out a tough year" Recall, a bottoming in the semiconductor market is key to our thesis as we believe that as pricing power returns (as demand growth begins to outpace supply growth), chip manufacturers will increase capex to the benefit of Lam Research in order to keep up with demand and not cede market share. Recall, last week we noted that messaging on Micron's conference call was mixed as the company called for a decline in capex while at the same time pointing to improving demand trends. As a result, we told members that "while the capex commentary was a negative, industry commentary was a positive and we ultimately believe that as inventories shrink, capex will have to ramp back up to meet the demand." Backing this view, the analysts at KeyBanc stated, "if memory enters undersupply in 2020 (which we expect), we think capex budgets will increase quickly." Speaking to our desire to own shares for the time being, rather than try to time the exact point at which we will see a capex ramp from customers, the analysts sated, "while demand remains uncertain, we view mid-2019 as a likely trough. If so, we expect semiconductor equipment stocks to have limited downside risk over the midterm, and significant upside potential through 2020 as positive long-term tailwinds kick in. We view the long-term dynamics as healthy for semiconductor equipment, and valuations are attractive." It is precisely this risk/reward dynamic that we are focused on and why we are happy to stay patient and collect the ~2% dividend in the meantime. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.39%; Yield: 1.97%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: Two


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Schlumberger ; $31.88; 1500 shares; 1.76%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -7.14%; Yield: 6.27%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe Schlumberger is the best of breed name in the oil services industry. Although the company's earnings power is dependent on the timing of the upstream investment cycle, management has a strong reputation in execution as well as a good handle in understanding the supply/demand dynamic of the industry. The company's premier technology gives it an advantage over peers and allows for market share gains. Furthermore, we value the company's international presence as it means a lessened exposure to North America, where new drilling activity remains limited. As compensation for our patience in the investment cycle's recovery, shares offer an attractive dividend that was confirmed to be backed by cash flow on the company's most recent earnings call. Target Price: $55 Rating: Two


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, weak capital spending of upstream oil and gas operators.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (1/22/19), , , Investor Relations

urn:contentItem:5W96-PC31-F00X-J000-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-06-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Markets surge in face of multiple uncertainties.

Markets surged more than 4% this week despite the current challenges and uncertainties. Such storylines include antitrust probes of some of the largest tech companies in the market, signs that the U.S. economy has slowed, indications from the bond market that suggest a rate cut is necessary (speeches from Fed officials were quite dovish this week), and the Trump Administration showing no signs of letting up on the tariff front, with tariffs set to be implemented on Mexico come Monday should an immigration deal not be reached over the weekend. As a reminder, the administration has guided that it will start with a 5% tariff and then increase the rate by five percentage points every month until a deal is reached. But markets were quite optimistic that a deal will be struck in a timely manner following the interview with White House Council of Economic Advisers Chairmen Kevin Hassett on Friday's "Squawk on the Street." And to the point of the Fed, "bad news" has become "good news" as each tepid economic data point (like the jobs number from Friday) provides the Fed with justification to reverse a potential policy stake from last December.

Backing this view, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said in prepared remarks at a speech this week that, "We are closely monitoring the implications of these developments for the U.S. economic outlook and, as always, we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective." With these comments suggesting that the market is not "fighting the Fed", equities were able to strongly rally from what was a severe oversold condition.

At the same time, there has been little progress on the China trade front, with the threat of additional tariffs still in play. With that in mind, we have raised cash in anticipation of increased volatility, especially as we approach debate/campaign season, and have remained patient before putting our precious cash to work, widening our scales and picking our spots carefully. As a result of our discipline, we are being rewarded with the ability to remain calm and focused, and to view any pullback through a long-term buyer's lens.

The 10-Year Treasury yield moved lower to ~ 2.08% as trade tensions and concerns of a slowdown in the economy increased. Meanwhile gold prices rallied to the ~$1,340 per ounce level. The U.S. dollar index pulled back to the 96 - 97 range while WTI oil prices were volatile but pared losses by the end of the week and ultimately settled around $54.

First-quarter earnings season is winding down. Within the portfolio, we heard from Salesforce and Five Below .


Salesforce

Salesforce.com reported a strong top and bottom-line beat with its fiscal first-quarter 2020 result. Non-GAAP revenue of $3.798 billion (+26% year over year on a constant currency, or cc, basis) beat the consensus of $3.685 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of $0.63 (which we adjusted to exclude a $0.27 benefit related to the company's required mark-to-market accounting on its strategic investment) exceeded the consensus expectation of $0.61.

In addition to the positive headline results, the company reported billings of $2.758 billion, topping estimates of $2.212 billion. Digging into each cloud service offering's subscription and support revenue, Sales Cloud increased 11% year over year to about $1.1 billion, Service cloud increased 20% year over year to about $1 billion, Salesforce Platform and Other increased 46% year over year to $800 million, and lastly, Marketing Cloud & Commerce Cloud increased 33% year over year to $600 million. Taking a look at full-year guidance, management raised both its revenue and non-GAAP EPS expectations. Management now expects revenues to be in the range of $16.1 billion to $16.25 billion, representing an increase of 21% to 22% year over year growth, respectively with non-GAAO earnings per share in the range of $2.88 to $2.90.


Five Below

Five Below, Inc. reported a top and bottom-line beat with its fiscal first-quarter earnings results. Sales of $364.76 million (+23.1% year over year) edged the consensus of $363.95 million, and earnings per share of $0.46 (+31.4% year over year, although this includes $0.11 benefit related to share-based accounting) beat the consensus of $0.34.

The company opened thirty-nine new stores during the quarter and expanded into three new states. Of those new stores, twelve appeared on the company's top twenty-five all-time spring grand opening list, representing a testament of how successful (with quick payback periods) the company's regional to national expansion is. As for guidance, management raised its full-year outlook despite the incorporation of the increased tariff rates. Management now expects earnings per share to be in the rage of $3.11 to $3.18 per share (consensus $3.06) from the range of $3.00 to $3.07 per share on a re-affirmed net sales outlook.


Economy

On Monday, the Institute of Supply Management (ISM) reported that the purchasing managers' index (PMI), which measures the economic environment within the manufacturing sector, fell 0.7 percentage points in May to 52.1%, missing expectations of an increase to 53.0% reading. For reference, over the past 12-month period (June 2018 through May 2019), PMI has reached a high of 60.8%, a low of 52.1% and averaged 56.7%. This marks the 121stconsecutive month of expansion in the overall economy and the 33rd in the manufacturing sector. See for our full analysis.

On Tuesday, the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured goods (durable and nondurable) in April fell 0.8% (or $4.0 billion), to $499.3 billion, exceeding expectations for a 0.95% decrease following a 1.3% advance in March (revised down from +1.9% previously reported). Additionally, new orders of non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft (i.e., core capital goods) fell 1.0% in April, following a 0.3% advance in both March and February. See for our full analysis.

On Wednesday, the ADP National Employment Report was released, indicating a 27,000 private-sector seasonally adjusted payroll increase for the month of May, well short of expectations for 185,000 added jobs. Additionally, April's reading was revised down to +271,000, from +275,000 previously reported, while March's reading was increased to +158,000 from +151,000 previously reported. See for our full analysis.

Also, On Wednesday, the Institute of Supply Management (ISM) reported that the non-manufacturing index (NMI), which tracks the service sector of the economy, increased 1.4 percentage points in May to 56.9%, exceeding expectations for 55.4%, following April's 55.5% reading. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending June 1 were 218,000, unchanged from the previous week's revised level of (revised up from 215,000 previously reported) and 3,000 claims above expectations. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 215,000, a decrease of 2,500 from the previous week's revised average of 217,500 (from 216,750 previously reported). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 222 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

Finally, on Friday, the U.S. Labor Department reported that the economy added 75,000 jobs during the month of May, missing expectations for a 185,000 gain. In addition to the weaker-than-expected results, March's reading was revised down to +153,000 from +189,000, and April's reading was revised down to +224,000 from +263,000. With these big downward revisions, job gains have now averaged 151,000 over the last three months for a much slower pace than previously. In addition to the headline number, the unemployment rate held steady at 3.6% and continues to sit at its lowest level since 1969. In May, average hourly earnings for all employees on nonfarm payrolls increased by $0.06 to $27.83, a steady rate that followed a $0.06 gain in April. Over the year, average hourly earnings (i.e., wage inflation) have increased 3.1%, a tick slower rate from what we saw in April. See for our full analysis.

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)


Oil

On the commodity front, prices remain under pressure as, despite OPEC's best efforts to reduce supply and sanctions remaining in place on Venezuela and Iran, U.S. production continues to break records and global growth concerns weigh on the demand side of the equation. Further pressuring the demand side is the increased trade rhetoric as tariffs are set to be enacted on Mexico come Monday, should a deal not be reached over the weekend. As called out earlier this week by CNBC ( ), according to Chief Executive of the American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers trade association, Chet Thompson, "if these tariffs take hold, particularly if they're able to get up to 25%, that could really impact the overall competitiveness of the U.S. refining industry." Per the report, "Mexico's oil is heavy and refiners need it to blend with lighter U.S. oil to produce diesel fuel, gasoline and other products. Tariffs would drive up the cost of those imports." That in mind, we would also note that should the tariffs be put it in place, it would no doubt result in higher prices at the pump, something President Trump has been trying to avoid and a factor that would also impact consumer discretionary dollars, proving an additional headwind for industries that rely on consumers' after-tax spending power such as restaurants and retailers.

On the domestic front, on Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Information Agency (EIA), reported that in the week ending May 31, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) surged by 6.8 million barrels to 483.3 million barrels, a bearish reading versus expectations for a ~850,000-barrel decrease. Additionally, U.S. production ticked up to a new all-time high, increasing by 100,000 bpd to 12.4 million bpd. Lastly, net imports increased by 1.084 million bpd as imports increased by 1.065 million bpd, while exports decreased by 19,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at roughly $9 per barrel. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive US based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, while we did net into the market this week, putting just under $10,000 to work, we balanced our desire to buy with our understanding that there remains a great deal of uncertainty given the upcoming political debates and trade overhang. That in mind, we took advantage of weakness to bulk up on our position in Goldman Sachs and Nvidia ( and ), and Kohl's ( and ).

However, we offset these buys with sales of Comcast ( ), Abbott Laboratories ( ), and Citigroup ( ).

Moving on to the broader market, first-quarter earnings season is wrapping up and the results thus far have been relatively positive versus beaten down expectations coming into the season, with 75.7% of companies reporting a positive EPS surprise. For the first-quarter, earnings growth has increased roughly 0.8% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 0.72% advance throughout the season; of the 418 non-financials that reported, earnings growth is up 0.6%. Revenues are up 4.7% vs. expectations throughout the season for a 3.86% increase; 75.7% of companies beat EPS expectations, 18.3% missed the mark and 6.0% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 67.28% beat the prior year's EPS results, 30.45% came up short and 2.26% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Information Tech, Communication Services and Healthcare while the worst performing have been Real Estate, Energy and Utilities.

Next week, 8 companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. No portfolio companies will be reporting.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: Thor Industries THO, Lovesac LOVE, Uxin UXIN, Casey's General CASY, Ascena Retail Group ASNA, H&R Block HRB, HD Supply Holdings HDS, Chico's FAS CHS, John Wiley & SonsJW.A, Dave & Busters PLAY, Tailored Brands TLRD, lululemon athletica LULU, RH, Oxford Industries OXM, Duluth Trading Co DLTH, Tufin Software TUFN, Broadcom AVGO and Cheetah Mobile CMCM.

New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated over $2.46 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.

While Amazon has thus far not been named as one of the companies being scrutinized, shares still took a hit as investors speculated that they too could be at risk of an investigation at some point in the future. Given the weakness, we opted to shares back to a One as we believe the stock has adequately pulled back for investors to begin nibbling again. INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Amazon's continued Commerce dominance, AWS' continued leadership in the public cloud space, and ongoing growth of the company's advertising revenue stream, which feeds off Amazon's eCommerce business. Additionally, we believe profitability will continue to improve as AWS and advertising account for a larger portion of total sales as both these segments sport higher margins than the eCommerce operation. And while we believe the increasing share of revenue from these higher margin businesses will be key to driving profitability longer-term, we believe margins on ecommerce stand to improve as the company's infrastructure is further built out and economies of scale further kick in. INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: One


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.

INVESTMENT THESIS: Strong underlying performance with an achievable (and beatable) 2019 organic sales growth expectation in the 6.5% to 7.5% range. The company boasts high performing franchises in Medical Devices (with strong growth in Diabetes Care) and Diagnostics (with strong gains in Core Laboratory), while Nutrition and Established Pharmaceutical remain strategic parts of its total portfolio. We believe the company's opportunities for upside rest with additional Libre uptake, the Alinity U.S. launch, and an expanded indication of the Mitraclip. We believe in CEO Miles White and the Abbott management team, who has a strong track record of integrating acquisitions and delivering double-digit earnings per share growth. Lastly, Abbott has plenty of financial flexibility to pursue mergers/acquisitions and other strategic actions. Target Price: Reiterate $82; Rating: Two


RISKS: Emerging market exposure, Product disruptions.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , (1/23/19), , ,



BP ; $42.14; 2200 shares; 3.50%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 3.49% Yield: 5.84%


INVESTMENT THESIS: In addition to higher oil prices aiding the sector, we believe BP shares will see further upside thanks to management's visible trajectory toward a stated 900,000-barrel-per-day production target by 2021, a target reiterated during the companies fourth-quarter earnings conference call, and an improving cash flow profile as Macondo related payments (expected to be ~$2 billion in 2019 and ~$1 billion in 2020) wind down and the company works to reduce breakeven prices for organic free cash flow from $50 per barrel currently toward the $35 to $40 range by 2021. The cash flow dynamic also gives us increased confidence in BPs ability to maintain its dividend payout, a key factor supporting shares against any downturns in commodity prices and a crucial consideration for our income-oriented members. Target Price: Reiterate $54; Rating: Two


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, Macondo liability coming in above expectations


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (12/10/18), ,



Citigroup ; $65.69; 1250 shares; 3.10%; Sector: Financials


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 5.70%; Yield: 2.74%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from an expanded price-to-tangible book valuation as management executes on its turnaround initiative and believe improving return on tangible common equity performance will ultimately lead to a higher book price and multiple expansion. Furthermore, the bank's over-capitalized balance sheet provides significant room for capital return to shareholders, providing a level of support and making for an attractive risk/reward profile. Target Price: $80; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System Regulation, interest rates, emerging markets, credit quality


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



Comcast ; $41.48; 2100 shares; 3.29%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: Though we remain bullish on the longer-term we opted in the name in an effort to both stay disciplined (we realized a ~33% gain) and rebuild our cash position in anticipation of further volatility. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.17%; Yield: 2.03%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see further upside resulting from progress on the integration of Sky plc, which will serve to increase the company's international presence while nearly doubling its customer base. Additionally, the acquisition provides Comcast access to Sky's "Q Box," which said to be even better than the X1 and provides a buffer should cord cutting accelerate in Europe. Recall, domestically, the X1 has been shown to be more resilient to the trend than competing platforms. Regarding the debt load on the balance sheet resulting from the acquisition, we reaffirm that management has an excellent M&A track record and believe strong cash flow generation will provide the means to successfully de-leverage overtime, allowing shares to re-rate higher over time. Lastly, regarding the US business, we believe management's decision to focus operations around broadband is continuing to be rewarded with higher margins and providing a greater ability to bundle cheaper, less in demand services such as video. Target Price: Reiterate $48; Rating: Two


RISKS: An acceleration of cord cutting, failure to realize targeted Sky integration synergies, 5G impacting broadband business, competition


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , ,



Corteva ; $26.31; 391 shares; 0.39%; Sector: Chemicals


WEEKLY UPDATE: On Monday, DowDuPont completed its separation into DuPont and Corteva Inc. Shareholders of DowDuPont were entitled to one share of CTVA for every 3 DWDP owned. Following the separation, Jim and the "Squawk on the Street" crew CEO Jim Collins. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.45%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Corteva is one of the few pure-play agriculture companies in the market and is a leader in seed and crop protection. Although the ag market can be volatile at times due to weather disruptions, the company expects organic sales growth to be 1-2% above the market rate. Corteva also has an aspect of a "self-help" story too through the realization of cost synergies over the course of the next few years. Target Price: Reiterate $29; Rating: Two


RISKS: Weather-related disruptions affecting planting conditions, exposure to emerging markets


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , Investor Relations



Walt Disney ; $138.04; 875 shares; 4.56%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 4.54%; Yield: 1.27%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Disney's direct to consumer efforts via ESPN+ and Disney+ and are happy to ride out the associated investment cycle. Additionally, we view the integration of Fox assets as another catalyst as progress is made given the acquisition brings with it programming across six continents, reaching over 1.8 billion consumers that speak roughly 50 different languages, as well as the rights to Start India, India being one of the fastest growing countries in the world and all of the domestic content, plus an additional 30% ownership of Hulu, bringing their total Hulu ownership to 60%.Furthermore, we are bullish on the Studio Entertainment division's 2019 movie lineup, which features a new Avengers, Toy Story 4, and live-action reboots of The Lion King and Aladdin, amongst other titles. Lastly, we believe a strong consumer should continue to support attendance and spending at Parks and Resorts. Target Price: Reiterate $150; Rating: Two


RISKS: Fox integration risk, competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting the consumer


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , , , ,



DuPont de Nemours ; $73.64; 391 shares; 1.09%; Sector: Chemicals


WEEKLY UPDATE: On Monday, DowDuPont completed its separation into DuPont and Corteva Inc. Immediately after the split, DuPont underwent a 1 for 3 reverse stock split. Following the separation, Jim and the "Squawk on the Street" crew CEO Ed Breen. 1-Wk. Price Change: 14.01%; Yield: 2.28%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe DuPont is undervalued relative to peers, and its separation into a single entity will help unlock that value difference. The company's portfolio consists of market-leading growth in Electronics & Imaging, Nutrition & Biosciences, Safety & Construction, and Transporation & Advanced Polymers. Lastly, we appreciate the significant amount of portfolio optionality that is present. Within the company, management created a Non-Core segment which comprises about 10% of the entire portfolio had is expected to do about $2 billion in sales during FY 2019. The main goal of these assets is for divestitures, which management plans to execute on through the year and the proceeds of which will be used for bolt-on M&A and/or share buybacks.


Target Price: Reiterate $80; Rating: Two


RISKS: Ongoing challenges in its three largest businesses: Automotive (15% of net sales), Smartphone (5% of net sales) and North American Residential Construction (4% of net sales); Softening demand due to tariffs,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , Investor Relations



Five Below ; $127.52; 150 shares; 0.72%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported a top and bottom-line beat with its fiscal first-quarter results. 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.94%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: This is a regional to national story that we believe will sustain momentum as organic growth, thanks to management's ability to recoup its initial investment in new stores in 8 months on average, is largely based on new store openings, something fully in management's control. Additionally, we value Five Below for its entirely domestic revenue stream, which insulates it from global trade dynamics and any slowing of global growth. And while tariffs may pressure the supply chain, should they increase, we believe management is already taking steps to mitigate any potential margin pressure. Lastly, while an economic slowdown could impact all retailers, we believe that Five Below's focus on less expensive products will allow it to be resilient as shoppers will naturally look for discounts when funds run low, making Five Below stores all the more attractive in such an environment. Target Price: Reiterate $135; Rating: Two


RISKS: Economic slowdown leading to less consumer spending, competition, lack of innovative product mix


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , Investor Relations



Honeywell International ; $172.26; 650 shares; 4.23%; Sector: Industrials


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 4.84%; Yield: 1.90%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Following a 2018 year when the company spun off two businesses, we believe the new Honeywell is worthy of a premium to its peer group as it has become less cyclical and more focused with stronger organic sales growth trends. The two segments we remain most positive on for their long-term growth profiles are Aerospace and Safety and Productivity Solution, as both stand to benefit from strong secular trends. Additionally, we appreciate management's ability to drive operational improvements in areas such as margin and free cash flow. Lastly, the balance sheet is clean has plenty of optionality, keeping the door open for accretive M&A and/or share buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $175; Rating: Two


RISKS: A slowdown in the aerospace market, a deterioration in commodity prices that affect businesses within PMT segment, trade war/tariffs exposure.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , Investor Relations



JPMorgan Chase ; $109.16; 875 shares; 3.60%; Sector: Financial


WEEKLY UPDATE: JPMorgan announced the closing of Finn, a digital no-fee baking platform that wasn't having much success anyway. No change to our view from that news. 1-Wk. Price Change: 3.02%; Yield: 2.93%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view JPMorgan as the best of breed large cap financial. The firm consistently delivers the best return on equity/tangible common equity performance in the industry, making the stock well deserving of a premium to its growing tangible book value. Not only that, but the Fortress balance sheet provides a degree of insulation to the risks associated with an economic shock. Lastly, we believe the valuation is very reasonable, especially considering the roughly 3% dividend yield and big buyback. Target Price: Reiterate $130; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, interest rates, credit quality.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , (1/15/19), ,



Microsoft ; $131.40; 550 shares; 2.73%; Sector: Technology


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 6.24%; Yield: 1.40%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe the cloud to be a secular growth trend and that upside to shares will result from Microsoft's hybrid cloud leadership as the company grab's market in this expanding industry. While companies may look to build out multi-cloud environments, Microsoft's Azure offering will be a prime choice thanks to the company's decision to provide the same "stack" used in the public cloud, to companies for their on-premise data centers. Additionally, we would note that hybrid environments are currently the preference for most companies because it allows them to maintain critical data in house while taking advantage of the agility and scalability provided by public clouds. Outside of the cloud opportunity, we maintain a positive view on the company's growing gaming business, which we believe is becoming an increasingly prominent factor in the Microsoft growth story as gaming becomes more mainstream, management works to convert its gaming revenue from one-time license purchase to a recurring subscription model and as technologies like augmented/virtual reality evolve. Finally, as it relates to LinkedIn and other subscription-based services such as O365 and various Dynamics products, we continue to value them highly for their recurring revenue streams, which we remind members, provides for greater transparency of future earnings. Target Price: Reiterate $140; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowdown in IT spending, competition, cannibalization of on premises business by the cloud


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , ,



Palo Alto Networks ; $195.54; 225 shares; 1.66%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, analysts at BMO reiterate their Outperform rating (and $250 price target), however, in line with our own view, noted that while they believe the strategic shift away from a firewall focus to a cloud focus to be the right one, added that they "expect the stock to remain in the penalty box until the next quarterly results given the very poorly communicated change of focus in pursuing shorter duration large deals broadly, and unattached subscriptions more specifically." 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.30%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe cyber security to be a secular growth trend that will continue to be a priority for cooperate investments globally in coming years. We value Palo Alto above others because, while firewall spend will continue to be a key factor supporting sales and earnings in the near- to- mid-term, we believe CEO Nikesh Arora's intense focus on cloud security will provide for longer relevance and industry dominance. Target Price: Reiterate $270; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowing global growth - particularly in the US, where PANW does the bulk of its business - leading to less than expected corporate cyber security investments, competition, cloud providers moving into the cloud security space


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (1/22/19), ,

urn:contentItem:5XK1-YPP1-JCHV-V53C-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Stocks end little changed for week, holding near records as consumer strength offsets China trade tensions.

Markets were largely unchanged this week and continued to hover near record highs as the U.S. economy showed signs of a strong, resilient consumer. Despite poor earnings from select retailers that have failed to adapt to the shift in consumer trends toward online shopping and a growing preference for off-price retail, we saw incredibly strong results from key retailer Target . With each quarter Target looks to have gained more and more market share from mall-based stores. That said, the market remains in a holding pattern with earnings season winding down and the nearing holiday season, which will be another test of the strength of the consumer. Regarding trade, recent optimism diminished this week. President Trump appears reluctant to reduce tariffs without further concessions from China, while Beijing has voiced strong disapproval regarding a bill supporting pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong, passed by the Senate and the House, that is waiting for the president's signature. Due to our concern of a new tariff threat, we chose to lock in our gains in Caterpillar and exit our position.

Yields on 10-year Treasury notes hovered around the 1.75% level, while gold prices remained around the ~$1,470s per ounce level. The dollar index stood at the 98 level while WTI oil prices moved to the upper $50s near their two-month high.

Third-quarter earnings season is underway. Within the portfolio, we heard from Kohl's and Home Depot .





Kohl's reported mixed earnings with its FY3Q19 earnings results. On the top line, sales of $4.625 billion (-0.1% YoY) outpaced the $4.399 billion consensus. However, on the bottom line, adjusted earnings per share of $0.74 (-24% YoY) sorely missed expectations of $0.86 per share.

An annual contraction on the margin front was expected, given the impact of tariffs and promotional efforts, two factors management has spoken to in the past. However, the results were a hair short of expectations coming in at 36.3% (-63bps YoY) versus 36.6% expected. Additionally, although same-store sales did return to growth following a 2.9% decline in the prior quarter, it missed expectations, coming in at 0.4% versus a 0.9% consensus.

Unfortunately, numbers speak louder than words and while the third-quarter results were disappointing, we believe guidance to be most responsible for Tuesday's decline, as despite returning to growth on same store sales, management was force to cut its full-year earnings forecast to the range of $4.75 to $4.95 per share, down from their prior guidance range of $5.15 to $5.45 per share.





Home Depot reported a mixed headline result with its third-quarter earnings. Sales of $27.2 billion (+3.5% year-over-year) came in light against the $27.53 billion consensus and adjusted earnings per share of $2.53 beat the consensus by one penny.

Looking at comparable sales, Home Depot saw a 3.6% increase at the company level against consensus expectations of 4.6% growth, while U.S. comps grew 3.8% against expectations of 4.7%. The pace of growth slowed as Home Depot moved through the quarter, with total company comps of 4.1% in August; 3.7% in September; and 3.1% in October with U.S. comps of 4.4% in August; 3.9% in September; and 3.3% in October.

Looking at the rest of fiscal 2019, management now expects sales to increase 1.8% and comp sales to increase 3.5% (compared to 3.9% consensus expectations). These two figures were both negatively revised from prior expectations for 2.3% sales growth and comp sales growth of 4%. This comp guidance implies fourth-quarter comp growth of roughly 5%, representing a solid acceleration from this quarter, but of course down from prior consensus expectations of 5.5%. When asked about its confidence in this 5% guide, management cited an absence or reversal of pressure of third quarter headwinds such as lumber deflation, foreign currency exchange, and event-timing shift. Bottom line expectations were held steady with management maintaining its earnings per share outlook of $10.03 compared to $10.13 consensus expectations.


Economy

On Tuesday, the U.S. Census Bureau reported that housing starts advanced 3.8% month over month in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.314 million. That was up from September's revised rate of 1.266 million but below expectations for a 1.32-million-unit rate. With October's reading, housing starts are up 8.5% from the same time last year. As for building permits, which "provide national, state, and local statistics on the number and valuation of new privately-owned housing units authorized by building permits in the United States," units authorized in October advanced 5.0% month over month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.461 million, exceeding expectations for a 1.39 million seasonally adjusted rate. This follows a revised September reading of 1.391 million. With October's monthly advance, permits are up 14.1% from the same time last year. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) reported that existing home sales -- completed transactions for single-family homes, town homes, condominiums and co-ops -- advanced 1.9% in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.46 million, a beat versus expectations for a roughly 1.5% monthly advance. With October's reading, overall existing home sales are up 4.6% from the same time last year. On the pricing front, the median existing home price increased 6.2% YoY to $270,900, marking the 92nd consecutive month of year-over-year price gains. Additionally, regarding 30-year, conventional, fixed-rate mortgages, according to Freddie Mac, the average commitment rate was 3.69% in October, slightly above the 3.61% rate seen in September, but well below the 4.54% average commitment rate across all of 2018. As for unsold inventory, supplies remain below the six-month level many view as balanced, currently sitting at a 3.9-month supply given the current rate of sales, down from the 4.1-month level seen in September. See for our full analysis.

Also on Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending November 16 were 227,000, unchanged from the previous week's revised level (revised up from 225,000), and 9,000 claims above expectations of 218,000. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 221,000, a 3,500-claim increase from the previous week's revised average of 217,500 (revised up from 217,000). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 - the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 245 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .


Key Global Economic Readings

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)


Oil

On the commodity front, oil prices held in the mid- to- upper-$50s range as hopes for a trade deal in the near-term and the global market continued to be oversupplied. Demand expectations came down on the back of slowing global growth - causing OPEC to at its December meeting. On the trade front, in addition to President Trump's reluctance to reduce tariffs, tensions were also reignited this week by the of the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act by the U.S. House of Representatives. Moreover, while a lesser than expected build in U.S. inventories offered some support, this was countered by ongoing record production levels.

On the domestic front, on Thursday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), reported that in the week ending November 15, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) increased by 1.4 million barrels to 450.4 million barrels, a bullish reading versus expectations for a 1.54-million-barrel increase. Additionally, U.S. production held at an all-time high of 12.8 million bpd. Lastly, net imports decreased by 172,000 bpd as imports increased by 222,000 bpd, while exports increased by 394,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at around the $5 to $6 per barrel level. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive US based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we added to our positions in Schlumberger
and Starbucks
, trimmed our position in Johnson & Johnson
and exited our position in Caterpillar .

Moving on to the S&P 500, third-quarter earnings season is underway with 75.8% reporting a positive EPS surprise. For the third quarter, earnings growth is down roughly 1.0% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 1.12% decline throughout the season; of the 400 non-financials that reported, earnings are down 1.7%. Revenues for the S&P 500 are up 2.7% vs. expectations throughout the season for a 2.76% increase; 75.8% of companies beat EPS expectations, 17.3% missed the mark and 6.9% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 66.17% beat the prior year's EPS results, 31.05% came up short and 2.78% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Healthcare, Information Tech and Consumer Staples, while the worst performing have been Real Estate, Materials and Energy.

Next week, 23 companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. Within the portfolio, we will hear from Burlington Stores BURL on Tuesday, before the opening bell.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: Jacobs JEC, Hewlett Packard Enterprise HPE, PVH PVH, Beacon Roofing Supply BECN, Agilent A, Caleres CAL, Palo Alto Networks PANW, Nutanix NTNX, MTS Systems MTSC, Ambarella AMBA, Golub Capital GBDC, Best Buy BBY, Tech Data TECD, Bank of Nova Scotia BNS, Dollar Tree DLTR, Hormel Foods HRL, Dick's Sporting Goods DKS, Analog Devices ADI, Abercrombie & Fitch ANF, Dycom DY, Cracker Barrel CBRL, Momo MOMO. Chico's FAS CHS, Eaton Vance EV, American Woodmark AMWD, Bitauto Holdings BITA, Titan Machinery TITN, Spire SR, Movado Group MOV, Dell DELL, HP HPQ, VMware VMW, Keysight KEYS, Autodesk ADSK, Guess? GES, Central Garden CENT, Veeva Systems VEEV, Box BOX, QAD QADA, Deere DE, DouYu DOYU, Daktronics DAKT, Frontline FRO and Uxin UXIN.

New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated over $2.46 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.

Abbott Laboratories ; $83.74; 725 shares; 2.08%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: Shares came under some pressure early in the week as a presented at the American Heart Association meeting in Philadelphia showed that drug medication with lifestyle changes may be just as effective in treating patients with severe but stable heart disease as stents/procedures. We recognize how this study could create a shift in the way patients seek heart treatment, however we do not anticipate any immediate sweeping change in how cardiologists practice. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.30%; Yield: 1.53%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Strong underlying performance with an achievable (and beatable) 2019 organic sales growth expectation in the 6.5% to 7.5% range. The company boasts high performing franchises in Medical Devices (with strong growth in Diabetes Care) and Diagnostics (with strong gains in Core Laboratory), while Nutrition and Established Pharmaceutical remain strategic parts of its total portfolio. We believe the company's opportunities for upside rest with additional Libre uptake, the Alinity U.S. launch, and an expanded indication of the Mitraclip. We believe in CEO Miles White and the Abbott management team, who has a strong track record of integrating acquisitions and delivering double-digit earnings per share growth. Lastly, Abbott has plenty of financial flexibility to pursue mergers/acquisitions and other strategic actions. Target Price: Reiterate $94; Rating: ne


RISKS: Emerging market exposure, Product disruptions.

Amazon ; $1,745.72; 80 shares; 4.79%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Amazon is gearing up for Black Friday, kicking it off a week early by deals this week. Online sales are a crucial aspect of the Amazon story and we will look for another strong selling season this week, however, the items we are most interested in seeing sell strongly are the Amazon Alexa-equipped devices as every sale on this front represents another door through which Amazon can sell its services and Prime subscriptions. In other news, CNBC that the company is coming under fire regarding practices with its Ring doorbell as senators want answers on how the company "retains and secures customers' data and videos." As noted in the report, Senators Ron Wyden of Oregon, Chris Van Hollen of Maryland, Ed Markey of Massachusetts, Chris Coons of Delaware and Gary Peters of Michigan sent a to CEO Jeff Bezos, following the release of investigatory by Markey, raising concerns that Ring's data could be hacked or accessed by foreign actors. While we will of course monitor the situation for additional updates, this is just another example regarding ongoing (and well known) concerns surrounding the ways in which big tech handles and uses user data - something we continue to monitor. 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.36%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Amazon's continued Commerce dominance, AWS' continued leadership in the public cloud space, and ongoing growth of the company's advertising revenue stream, which feeds off Amazon's eCommerce business. Additionally, we believe profitability will continue to improve as AWS and advertising account for a larger portion of total sales as both these segments sport higher margins than the eCommerce operation. And while we believe the increasing share of revenue from these higher margin businesses will be key to driving profitability longer-term, we believe margins on ecommerce stand to improve as the company's infrastructure is further built out and economies of scale further kick in. The embedded call option is that management is always looking to enter a new space and generate new revenue streams. Target Price: Reiterate $2,050; Rating: One


RISKS: High valuation exposes the stock to volatile swings, eCommerce has exposure to slower consumer spending, competition, management is not afraid to invest heavily, potential headwinds resulting from new eCommerce regulation in India, management is not scared to invest aggressively for growth, which can at times cause volatile reactions as near-term concerns arise relating to the impact on margins.

The Wall Street Journal that the company is looking for ways to reduce the super-targeting of political ads by increasing the minimum amount of people that can be targeted by a given ad "from 100 to a few thousand." Per the article, according to an unnamed source "Facebook has sought feedback on potential changes with large Republican and Democratic political ad buyers -- about that possible change and other ideas -- in efforts to limit how misinformation is spread, since ads with false or misleading information are often targeted toward specific audiences." We view the move as a positive as, despite positive underlying business fundamentals, political headlines have remained an overhang on the company and stock. We believe taking these additional steps will help to address concerns from the political sphere regarding the platform's influence on election results. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.91%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Facebook is the leading social media company. It monetizes its platforms and delivers targeted advertisements across all major demographics at a high ROI. Although revenue is expected to decelerate as the company transitions its monetization emphasis to Instagram Stories from Facebook's NewsFeed, and there are additional risks to margins related to increased OpEx spending, we believe both processes have become well understood by investors at this point. Plus, we think future growth opportunities exist through increased monetization of the WhatsApp and Messenger verticals. While critics claim the member base has become disengaged, Facebook's first quarter results showed trends have held with daily active users (DAUs) of 1.56 billion and monthly active users (MAUs) of 2.375 billion. Lastly, we believe the stock's current price to earnings multiple is cheap relative to the company's growth and competitive moat. Target Price: Reiterate $225; Rating: One

Alphabet ; $1,293.67; 70 shares; 3.1%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: Alphabet officially launched it video game streaming platform this week, Stadia. Unfortunately, reviews have skewed negative as performance does not appear to be living up to expectations or the promises made by management. That said, it is important that while this may make for poor headlines, Stadia was not expected to represent a material contribution to the top line. Analysts at MKM Partners noted their belief that it would likely not represent more than 0.25% of 2021 sales. That in mind, we do believe the platform to be a step in the right direction as it can serve to increase engagement with users both by giving Alphabet exposure to the rapidly growing gaming market and increasing engagement with YouTube as it tries to compete with Amazon's Twitch. Moreover, it serves to further bolster the company's hardware business, with the analysts at MKM also pointing out that "hardware sales are growing at 2x the growth rate of core Advertising sales, and will have effectively grown 5x from '16 to '20." So, bottom line, this was not as strong a release as expected, but expectations were never that high to begin with. However, we will look for improvements over time as we do believe the gaming to continue growing over time and would not be surprised to see Stadia increase its revenue share in the years to come. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.99%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe that while Search and digital ad dominance is what will carry shares in the near- to- midterm, longer-term it is the company's artificial intelligence (AI) "moat" that will provide for new avenues of growth. AI is what has made the company's Search, Video (YouTube) and targeted ad capabilities best-in-class and is the driving force behind the company's success in voice (Google Home) and autonomous driving (Waymo). Furthermore, we believe it is this AI expertise that will also make the company more prevalent in other industries, including healthcare via subsidiary Verily, as AI and machine learning continue to disrupt operations across industries. We believe Alphabet's willingness to invest in new areas, knowing most will fail, is a recipe for long-term success as while most " " projects may fail, every once in a while, you end up with a Waymo, perhaps the division's, most successful graduate to date. Lastly, compounding out positive view of the company's future opportunities, we believe that Alphabet's free cash flow generation and solid balance sheet set it apart and are what will allow the company to continue taking chances on far-out ground-breaking and potentially world changing projects. Target Price: Reiterate $1,400; Rating: One


RISKS: Regulatory risk (data privacy), competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting consumers and therefore ad buyer activity
