ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , , Interview , ,



BP PLC ; $38.55; 1,750 shares; 2.31%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.68%; Yield: 6.38%


INVESTMENT THESIS: In addition to higher oil prices aiding the sector, we believe BP shares will see further upside thanks to management's visible trajectory toward a stated 900,000-barrel-per-day production target by 2021, a target reiterated during the companies fourth-quarter earnings conference call, and an improving cash flow profile as Macondo related payments (expected to be ~$2 billion in 2019 and ~$1 billion in 2020) wind down and the company works to reduce breakeven prices for organic free cash flow from $50 per barrel currently toward the $35 to $40 range by 2021. The cash flow dynamic also gives us increased confidence in BPs ability to maintain its dividend payout, a key factor supporting shares against any downturns in commodity prices and a crucial consideration for our income-oriented members. Target Price: Reiterate $50; Rating: Two


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, Macondo liability coming in above expectations


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , ,



Burlington Stores Inc ; $206.01; 350 shares; 2.47%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: With non-ecommerce, non-off-price retailers feeling the pain thus far this earnings season, we look forward to hearing Burlington's management next week, when the company reports earnings on Tuesday, before the opening bell. On the top line, we are looking for sales of $1.786 billion and on the bottom line, we're looking for earnings of $1.40 per share. 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.6%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Specializing as an off-price retailer, Burlington Stores sources its merchandise opportunistically, meaning that management purchases excess inventory from struggling retailers and then resells the quality merchandise at everyday low prices. The bargains Burlington's stores offer creates a "treasure hunting" experience for its shoppers, and this cannot be replicated by e-commerce. Therefore, we believe Burlington's business model keeps them immune from the pressures facing department stores, and we expect the company will continue to deliver low single digit same store sales growth. Lastly, any supply chain disruptions caused by tariffs may work to Burlington's favor, as off-price's value will gain additional favor should either prices increase, or stores need to unload inventory. Target Price: Reiterate $220; Rating: Two


RISKS: Consumer spending, inventory availability, fashion trends


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , ,



Cisco Systems ; $44.85; 1,200 shares; 1.84%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.53%; Yield: 3.12%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from an improved earnings profile as the company transitions from lumpier hardware sales, toward a recurring software and security revenue stream. We also believe the reduction in DRAM prices, a major input cost for the company, is proving to be a near- to- mid-term tailwind. Lastly, we believe the transformation along with corporate initiatives to adopt the cloud will keep earnings resilient in the face of any broader macroeconomic slowdown. Target Price: $50; Rating: Two


RISKS: A rebound in DRAM prices placing pressure on margins, a decline in corporate IT spending, competition, execution risk related to the shift toward software and security


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



Citigroup ; $74.87; 700 shares; 1.8%; Sector: Financials


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.63%; Yield: 2.72%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from an expanded price-to-tangible book valuation as management executes on its turnaround initiative and believe improving return on tangible common equity performance will ultimately lead to a higher book price and multiple expansion. Furthermore, the bank's over-capitalized balance sheet provides significant room for capital return to shareholders, providing a level of support and making for an attractive risk/reward profile. The firm's tangible book value per share as of the end of the second quarter 2019 is $67.64. Target Price: Reiterate $80; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System Regulation, interest rates, emerging markets, credit quality


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



Comcast ; $44.8; 1,400 shares; 2.15%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.54%; Yield: 1.88%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see further upside resulting from progress on the integration of Sky plc, which will serve to increase the company's international presence while nearly doubling its customer base. Additionally, the acquisition provides Comcast access to Sky's "Q Box," which said to be even better than the X1 and provides a buffer should cord cutting accelerate in Europe. Recall, domestically, the X1 has been shown to be more resilient to the trend than competing platforms. Regarding the debt load on the balance sheet resulting from the acquisition, we reaffirm that management has an excellent M&A track record and believe strong cash flow generation will provide the means to successfully de-leverage overtime, allowing shares to re-rate higher over time. Lastly, regarding the US business, we believe management's decision to focus operations around broadband is continuing to be rewarded with higher margins and providing a greater ability to bundle cheaper, less in demand services such as video. Target Price: Reiterate $56; Rating: Two


RISKS: An acceleration of cord cutting, failure to realize targeted Sky integration synergies, 5G impacting broadband business, competition


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



Disney ; $148.29; 775 shares; 3.94%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: Shares gained more as strong reviews/demand for the Disney+ continued to come in and strong boxes office results from Frozen 2 are expected this weekend. 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.50%; Yield: 1.19%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Disney's direct to consumer efforts via ESPN+ and Disney+ and are happy to ride out the associated investment cycle. Additionally, we view the integration of Fox assets as another catalyst as progress is made given the acquisition brings with it programming across six continents, reaching over 1.8 billion consumers that speak roughly 50 different languages, as well as the rights to Start India, India being one of the fastest growing countries in the world and all of the domestic content, plus an additional 30% ownership of Hulu, bringing their total Hulu ownership to 60%.Furthermore, we are bullish on the Studio Entertainment division's 2019 movie lineup, which features a new Avengers, Toy Story 4, and live-action reboots of The Lion King and Aladdin, amongst other titles. Lastly, we believe a strong consumer should continue to support attendance and spending at Parks and Resorts. Target Price: Reiterate $150; Rating: Two


RISKS: Fox integration risk, competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting the consumer


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



Goldman Sachs ; $220.28; 450 shares; 3.4%; Sector: Financials


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.01%; Yield: 2.27%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Goldman Sachs is a strong performing investment bank, and the firm is currently ahead of its goal to generate an additional $5 billion in annual revenue by 2020. Meanwhile, the firm has delivered consistent improvements to its return on equity and return on tangible common equity metrics-which are drivers of a premium over book price-while tangible book value has continued to grow. Another reason why we think the share price deserves a greater premium is because of management's emphasis on fee-based, or more recurring, revenue streams. At the end of 2018, 61% of Goldman's revenues were fee-based, up from 48% in 2013. The firm's tangible book value per share as of the end of the second quarter 2019 is $203.05. Target Price: Reiterate $270; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, 1MDB litigation, interest rates, financial market activity


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , ,



Home Depot ; $218.03; 150 shares; 1.12%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . 1-Wk. Price Change: -8.12%; Yield: 2.50%


INVESTMENT THESIS: The unquestioned leader in home improvement supplies, we like Home Depot for its consistent same-store sales performance, ability to gain market share and improve margins, and its business model that is relatively immune from Amazon-like pressures. We initiated our position shortly before the Spring--Home Depot's "Holiday season" --expecting the company to outperform expectations. Longer term, management's 2020 financial targets include sales to increase to the range of $115 billion to $120 billion, with operating margins in a range of 14.4% to 15% and return on invested capital of more than 40%. Lastly, Home Depot is a cash-generating machine. Making good use of its cash flows, the company recently authorized a 32% increase to its quarterly dividend (which puts the yield ~3.0%) as well as announced a $15 billion share repurchase program. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: Two


RISKS: Consumer Spending habits; Housing market downturn; inclement weather


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , Investor Relations



Honeywell ; $176.79; 300 shares; 1.82%; Sector: Industrials


WEEKLY UPDATE: Honeywell hosted a two-day ( here and   here ) Investor showcase of its Honeywell Building Technologies (HBT) business made up of Fire & Life Safety, Building Management Systems, Connected Buildings, Electrical Products, Security, and HON Building Solutions. Management spoke of an industry with a $100 billion-plus total addressable market, with HBT operating in about $60 billion of that market growing at a roughly 4% compound annual growth rate. Management also sees a HBT business that can grow at a mid-single digit percent compound growth rate over the long-term with segment margins of 23%, up from 2019's estimate of about 20.5. We always like to turn to our favorite industrial analyst Stephen Tusa of JPMorgan for his view on the company's in his coverage, and he wrote in a research note this week that HBT "looks to us like one of the higher value non-residential businesses, with outgrowth potential as these connected building technologies continue to proliferate, and we see HON as positioned well to benefit with HBT segment profit growth of ~7.5% above the EE/MI sector average." Lastly and of little surprise, management reaffirmed its 4Q2019 guidance and FY 2019 guidance at the event. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.73%; Yield: 2.04%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Following a 2018 year when the company spun off two businesses, we believe the new Honeywell is worthy of a premium to its peer group as it has become less cyclical and more focused with stronger organic sales growth trends. The two segments we remain most positive on for their long-term growth profiles are Aerospace and Safety and Productivity Solution, as both stand to benefit from strong secular trends. Additionally, we appreciate management's ability to drive operational improvements in areas such as margin and free cash flow. Lastly, the balance sheet is clean has plenty of optionality, keeping the door open for accretive M&A and/or share buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $175; Rating: Two


RISKS: A slowdown in the aerospace market, a deterioration in commodity prices that affect businesses within PMT segment, trade war/tariffs exposure.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , Investor Relations



Johnson & Johnson ; $138.07; 475 shares; 2.25%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: While not representing a change in our longer-term investment thesis, we opted to on our position in an effort to take advantage of recent strength, which we touched on , and protect against the possibility of a negative talc-related headline that would send shares back below the $130 level. 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.32%; Yield: 2.75%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view Johnson and Johnson as a consistent performer with durable franchises across the consumer and healthcare industry. Importantly, we expect the company's Pharmaceutical and Consumer business to grow above their respective industry growth rates, and even though Medical Devices has lagged, we have seen encouraging signs of improvements. Lastly, the company has one of the best balance sheets in the market, providing management with plenty of optionality for strategic M&A and/or buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $155; Rating: Two


RISKS: Talc Litigation, Biosimilar and generic pressure, pipeline execution.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , Investor Relations



JPMorgan Chase & Co. ; $130.79; 650 shares; 2.91%; Sector: Financial


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.97%; Yield: 2.75%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view JPMorgan as the best of breed large cap financial. The firm consistently delivers the best return on equity/tangible common equity performance in the industry, making the stock well deserving of a premium to its growing tangible book value. Not only that, but the Fortress balance sheet provides a degree of insulation to the risks associated with an economic shock. Lastly, we believe the valuation is very reasonable, especially considering the roughly 3% dividend yield and big buyback. The firm's tangible book value per share as of the end of the second quarter 2019 is $59.42. Target Price: $135; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, interest rates, credit quality.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



Kohl's ; $47; 1,000 shares; 1.61%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . 1-Wk. Price Change: -20.45%; Yield: 5.70%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We like Kohl's position in the department store industry. Its brands are tailored to middle-income buyers who shop for value, or good deals, while their store locations remain away from the mall which has been subject to decline in foot traffic. The company is run by a strategic management team who has several strong initiatives in place (standard-to-small initiatives, partnership with Planet Fitness, Fanatics, of course Amazon and more) that drive traffic and improve inventory management. Additionally, Kohl's continues to be a large beneficiary of peer closings (like Bon-Ton), resulting in increased market share. Target Price: Reiterate $56; Rating: Two


RISKS: A decline in consumer spending, shifts in consumer fashion preferences, margin pressure related to increased competition, weather impacting consumer shopping habits, tariffs,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



Lam Research ; $261.98; 150 shares; 1.35%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Shares came under pressure this week on a downgrade to Sell (from Neutral) by analysts at UBS. While we acknowledge that shares have been incredibly strong this year, we remind members that we have booked profits all the way up and given the dynamics in the memory industry, we continue to like the outlook for shares as we continue to believe that DRAM/NAND demand growth will outpace supply growth as we work through CY2020 and ultimately result in increased level of chip maker capex to the benefit of Lam Research. 1-Wk. Price Change: -7.65%; Yield: 1.76%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $285; Rating: Two


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Nvidia ; $210.89; 475 shares; 3.43%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, Jim had the chance to with CEO Jensen Huang on Mad Money. We provided our takeaways on what is most important for members to know, . 1-Wk. Price Change: 3.28% Yield: 0.30%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Nvidia's GPU dominance, the moat created by its CUDA, the company's parallel computing platform, and significant growth in all of the company's end markets including, the cloud (think datacenter), gaming, autonomous vehicles and pro visualization. Furthermore, we believe the cloud (i.e. data center) growth will be even more of a factor in upside following the acquisition of Mellanox, which thanks to its low latency "InfiniBand" technology, provides Nvidia the ability be a more integral player in the buildout of data centers by working to both accelerate server subsystems via GPU-acceleration and accelerate the data center overall by "tying together" the multiple subsystems and allowing them to operate as a single cohesive unit. Target Price: Reiterate $220; Rating: Two


RISKS: slow uptake of ray-tracing chips which will depend on gaming publishers' implementation of the new technology in software releases, a slowdown in the IT/data center spending, competition, slower than expected inventory channel normalization.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



UnitedHealth Group ; $276.84; 325 shares; 3.08%; Sector: Health


WEEKLY UPDATE: As we on Monday, shares continue to benefit from the "Medicare for All" plan put out by U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts last Friday that is being considered "more centered" and less immediate than previously thought. In response to the news, analysts at SunTrust updated their targets on Managed Care operators across the board, stating "We remain bullish on Managed Care and continue to view the companies as a key part of the healthcare cost solution." The analysts took their UNH target from $310 to $335. 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.76%; Yield: 1.56%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view UnitedHealth Group as a high performing health insurance company. Its business is divided into two subsidiaries: UnitedHealthcare, which represents the insurance side of the company, and Optum, a fast-growing, margin expanding, and technology/data leveraging division with exposure to PBM, healthcare consulting, and specialized health and wellness services. We value the company's consistent, economic-cycle resilient performance, supported by management's long-term expectation of 13% to 15% growth. Lastly, the company generates a significant amount of operating cash flow, which supports the large share repurchase program that is currently in place. Target Price: Reiterate $305; Rating: Two


RISKS: Higher than expected medical costs, changes to healthcare policy, slower growth at Optum


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,

urn:contentItem:5Y2G-49W1-JCHV-V2CK-00000-00Weekly Roundup2020-01-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Wall Street pulls back ahead of next week's "Super Bowl of earnings"

Markets pulled back slightly this week as some decent corporate earnings, on a case by case basis, were not enough to support relatively higher stock valuations and mounting economic concerns related to the spreading coronavirus in China. We also attribute some of the noticeably pronounced declines in healthcare stocks to the rising uncertainty of the Iowa caucuses, and media stocks facing backlash due to persisting concerns of the ongoing challenges related to cord cutting. Elsewhere, we saw our consumer-packaged goods names rally as investors looked for durable yields against a falling 10-Year Treasury yield, and certain semiconductors gained in response to strong outlooks from a few key companies.

Looking ahead, next week will be the true test as earrings kick into high gear with a number of industry bellwethers reporting. Their unique outlooks will provide in-depth views on global economic activity. Also, several big tech names are set to report earnings which could move markets because tech represents the largest sector of the S&P 500.

If earnings won't keep you busy enough, we'll hear from the FOMC and Fed Chair Jerome Powell on Wednesday following the conclusion of the January FOMC meeting. While the market largely expects rates to go unchanged (87.3% probability at the time this was written according to the ), commentary around inflation expectations and balance sheet policy will be key to forming future rate movement expectations - a key factor impacting equity valuations.

10-year Treasury yields continued their downward drift and fell below~1.7%, while gold prices pushed higher to around 1,575. The U.S. dollar index remained between 97 and 98, and WTI oil prices plunged under $55 per barrel due to economic-slowdown concerns related to the coronavirus.

Fourth-quarter earnings season is picking up. Within the portfolio, we heard from Abbott Laboratories and Comcast .



Abbott Laboratories reported in-line earnings, with its fourth-quarter 2019 results. Revenues of $8.314 billion (+7.1% year over year) came in ahead of the $8.266 billion consensus, while adjusted earnings per share of $0.95 (+17% YoY) matched expectations. On a very positive note, organic sales increased a whopping 8.5% in the quarter, reflecting a nice acceleration from the third quarter's 7.6% rate and topping estimates.

Management issued full-year 2020 guidance, and from an organic sales perspective they expect growth of 7.0% to 8.0%. In 2019 Abbott delivered organic sales growth of 7.7%. Momentum appears to be on its side and this expected rate of growth for a company of this size (+$100 billion market cap) is nothing short of remarkable. From an earnings perspective, adjusted EPS is expected to be in the range of $3.55 to $3.65, which at a midpoint of $3.60 (+11.1% growth YoY) is a penny shy of the $3.61 consensus.

For the first quarter 2020, management expects adjusted earnings per share to be $0.69 to $0.71, which at a midpoint of $0.70 is two pennies less than the $0.72 consensus. Though bottom line guidance for the first quarter and the full year is a tad below expectations, we think it is worth looking past this forecast due to management's history of conservatism with their initial read.



Comcast reported a top and bottom-line beat with its fourth-quarter results. On the top line, revenue of $28.398 billion (+2% year over year) beat expectations of $28.17 billion. Adjusted EBITDA of $8.436 (+3.0% YoY) billion was roughly in line with $8.45 billion estimates and adjusted earnings per share of $0.79 (+7.7% YoY) edged expectations by three pennies.

Comcast generated $2.484 billion in free cash flow in the quarter, up about 20% from a year ago, but light against $2.86 billion consensus estimates. The company ended the quarter with consolidated net debt of $96.2 billion, down from $97.1 billion in the prior quarter. This puts pro forma net leverage at 2.8x, down from 2.9x a quarter ago. Although the balance sheet is not yet at the point where Comcast will resume share repurchases, the company announced a 10% increase to its dividend (to $0.92 per share from $0.84 on an annualized basis), representing the 12th consecutive annual increase. This dividend hike will put the new yield slightly below 2.0%.

As for guidance, management expects 2020 will see higher programming expense growth due to the number of contracts up for renewal, but the increase is expected to be back-half weighted. Still, Comcast expects Cable EBITDA margins to increase 50 basis points from the full year thanks to growth in high-margin connectivity, continued operational improvements, better performance from Xfinity Mobile, and higher political advertising. It looks like consensus was looking for guidance of 50-100 basis points, and that might explain why the stock turned lower after an initial pre-market pop. Nevertheless, management was likely conservative with their initial forecast, just like they were at the start of 2019 (they ended the year with expansion of about 3x their initial forecast). Elsewhere, management expects 2020 capital intensity improvement of "approximately 50 basis points" year over year. For Sky, EBITDA is expected to be consistent with 2019 results (before investment and on current FX rates) as tailwinds related to the deployment of Sky Q -- whose current customers tend to have higher viewership, retention levels, ARPU, and better product attachment -- will be met with the challenging macro and gambling legislation.


Economy

On Wednesday, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) reported that existing home sales -- completed transactions for single-family homes, town homes, condominiums and co-ops - advanced 3.6% in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.54 million, a beat versus expectations for an increase to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.43 million. With December's reading, overall existing home sales are up 10.8% from the same time last year. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending January 18 were 211,000, an increase of 6,000 from the previous week's revised level of 205,000 (revised up from 204,000), however, 4,000 claims below expectations of 215,000. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 213,250, a 3,250-claim decrease from the previous week's revised average of 216,500 (revised up from 216,250). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 - the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 254 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

On Friday, the IHS Markit Group reported that the IHS Markit Flash U.S. Composite PMI Output Index for January registered a reading of 53.1, up from 52.7 in December. Driving the headline number was accelerated services sector growth. The Flash U.S. PMI Services Business Activity Index advanced to 53.2 (from 52.8 in December), while the IHS Markit Flash U.S. Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 51.7 (from 52.4 in December). However, the Flash U.S. Manufacturing Output Index was unchanged, holding at 52.4 in January. See for our full analysis.

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)


Oil

On the commodity front, prices moved lower as the U.S. continues to pump at record levels and concerns regarding the on Chinese growth, global travel and global economic growth in general as a result, pressured future demand expectations. Those concerns more than offset favorable such as OPEC+ production cuts, Iranian sanctions, and increased tensions in the Middle East in general following the assassination of Iranian General Qasem Soleimani.

On the domestic front, on Thursday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), reported that in the week ending January 17, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) decreased by 0.4 million barrels to 428.1 million barrels, a bearish reading versus expectations for a 1.0 million barrel decrease. Additionally, U.S. production held at all-time highs of 13.0 million bpd. Lastly, net imports decreased by 53,000 bpd as imports decreased by 120,000 bpd, while exports decreased by 67,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at around the $6 per barrel level. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive US based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we viewed weakness as an opportunity to increase our stake in Tyson Foods
and Bristol-Myers Squibb
. On the other hand, we trimmed several positions including PepsiCo
, and Facebook , UnitedHealth Group and Marvel Technology Group -- with a Kohl's exit -- .

Moving on to the S&P 500, fourth-quarter earnings season is ramping up. Members should take the following data with a grain of salt as the data set is somewhat limited so early in the season. That said, 69.3% of companies reporting so far have posted a positive EPS surprise. For the fourth quarter, earnings growth is down roughly 1.3% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 1.76% decline throughout the season; of the 49 non-financials that reported, earnings are down 3.1%. Revenues for the S&P 500 are up 3.3% vs. expectations throughout the season for a 2.55% increase; 69.3% of companies beat EPS expectations, 24.0% missed the mark and 6.7% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 64.0% beat the prior year's EPS results, 34.67% came up short and 1.33% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Information Tech, Communication Services and Consumer Staples, while the worst performing have been Materials, Industrials and Real Estate.

Next Sunday is the Superbowl, but the week ahead is the "Super Bowl of earnings" with 130 companies in the S&P 500 set to report. Within the portfolio, we will hear from Starbucks and Apple on Tuesday after the close; Novartis and Mastercard on Wednesday before the open; Microsoft , Lam Research and Facebook on Wednesday after the close; Amazon on Thursday after the close; and Honeywell on Friday before the open.

The bargains Burlington's stores offer creates a "treasure hunting" experience for its shoppers, and this cannot be replicated by e-commerce. Therefore, we believe Burlington's business model keeps them immune from the pressures facing department stores, and we expect the company will continue to deliver low single digit same store sales growth. Lastly, any supply chain disruptions caused by tariffs may work to Burlington's favor, as off-price's value will gain additional favor should either prices increase, or stores need to unload inventory. Target Price: Reiterate $245; Rating: Two


RISKS: Consumer spending, inventory availability, fashion trends

Disney ; $139.97; 775 shares; 3.53%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: Disney that in response to the coronavirus "Shanghai Disney Resort is temporarily closing Shanghai Disneyland, Disneytown including Walt Disney Grand Theatre and Wishing Star Park, starting January 25, 2020." While this is obviously a negative development for the earnings power of Disney's Theme Park operations, it's important to keep in mind that Disney is only partially exposed as the company owns only 43% of the Shanghai Disney Resort. With that, given the ongoing spread of the virus in the region, it is worth noting that should we see a similar move in Hong Kong, Disney maintains 47% ownership of the Hong Kong Disneyland Resort. While we do not want to make light of the situation, we want members to understand Disney's exposure. That said, outside of the theme parks we will also continue monitor the impact on movie theaters as many in China have been closed due to the outbreak and depending on the timeline may result in some pressure on global box office sales. While this is more difficult to quantify (some revenues may be delayed rather than lost and again the timeline of these closures, including the length of closures and the timing around Disney movie releases, will be key), we will continue to monitor the situation and update members as we learn more. In other news, we want to point out that Disney announced it moved up the launch date for Disney+ in West Europe markets by one week, and analysts at Morgan Stanley raised their price target on the stock off higher DTC estimates. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.94%; Yield: 1.26%

Lastly, we believe a strong consumer should continue to support attendance and spending at Parks and Resorts. Target Price: Reiterate $150; Rating: Two

WEEKLY UPDATE: CEO Sundar Pichai at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week to discuss "quantum computing, artificial intelligence and the future of technology governance." Cancer is often missed and the difference in outcome is profound. In lung cancer, for example, five experts agree this way and five agree the other way. We know we can use artificial intelligence to make it better." As members can see in our investment thesis. We have long-viewed AI as a crucial competitive moat that will ultimately allow the company to push into new areas of growth, we believe Pichai's comments to further support this view. 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.90%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe that while Search and digital ad dominance is what will carry shares in the near- to- midterm, longer-term it is the company's artificial intelligence (AI) "moat" that will provide for new avenues of growth. AI is what has made the company's Search, Video (YouTube) and targeted ad capabilities best-in-class and is the driving force behind the company's success in voice (Google Home) and autonomous driving (Waymo). Furthermore, we believe it is this AI expertise that will also make the company more prevalent in other industries, including healthcare via subsidiary Verily, as AI and machine learning continue to disrupt operations across industries. We believe Alphabet's willingness to invest in new areas, knowing most will fail, is a recipe for long-term success as while most " " projects may fail, every once in a while, you end up with a Waymo, perhaps the division's, most successful graduate to date. Lastly, compounding out positive view of the company's future opportunities, we believe that Alphabet's free cash flow generation and solid balance sheet set it apart and are what will allow the company to continue taking chances on far-out ground-breaking and potentially world changing projects. INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $315 Rating: Two


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.

While previous volatility doesn't mean it will happen again in the future, we want to prepare ourselves for this type of repeat scenario. INVESTMENT THESIS: Our thesis on MRVL is heavily predicated on Marvell's integral role in the 5G cycle. Additionally, we believe the Cavium deal was a big step in the company's transformation while the acquisition of Aquantia, a leader in Multi-Gig Ethernet connectivity, will help in broadening Marvell's connectivity solutions portfolio and capitalizing on the future of high-speed networking requirements in cars that are needed to enable autonomous, electric, and safety/security applications. Furthermore, on the M&A front, we believe the acquisition Avera Semiconductor, a developer of custom ASICs for networking and telecom equipment was a 5G additive play as Avera's biggest end market exposure is base stations, which are leveraged to 5G. While companies may look to build out multi-cloud environments, Microsoft's Azure offering will be a prime choice thanks to the company's decision to provide the same "stack" used in the public cloud, to companies for their on-premise data centers. Additionally, we would note that hybrid environments are currently the preference for most companies because it allows them to maintain critical data in house while taking advantage of the agility and scalability provided by public clouds. Outside of the cloud opportunity, we maintain a positive view on the company's growing gaming business, which we believe is becoming an increasingly prominent factor in the Microsoft growth story as gaming becomes more mainstream, management works to convert its gaming revenue from one-time license purchase to a recurring subscription model and as technologies like augmented/virtual reality evolve. urn:contentItem:5XHJ-5F41-JCHV-V30M-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Markets notch more weekly gains as earnings season moves forward, consumers remain resilient.

Markets notched another gain this week as, despite ongoing uncertainty around trade, optimism of a deal progressed, the U.S. economy continued to prove itself resilient, and third-quarter earnings came in better than feared -- though the cautious commentary from Cisco still has us a bit concerned on the enterprise front. While there may always be some pressure as a result of either profit taking or intensifying trade rhetoric -- especially given that we are making new all-time highs and the bears will look for any reason to sell -- we remain bullish thanks to a resilient consumer on the back of a strong job market as we enter the holiday season -- a factor causing much of the recent strength seen in the retail sector (think Kohl's KSS, Burlington BURL, and Home DepotHD). Moreover, we continue to believe that if we truly are inching closer to a deal, manufacturing activity will be able to pick back up and become less worse with a recovery in global economic growth.

10-year Treasury yields slipped to the 1.8% level, while gold prices remain around the ~$1,470s per ounce level. The dollar index stands at around the 98 level while WTI oil prices are in the mid- to- upper-$50s region.

Third-quarter earnings season is underway. Within the portfolio, we heard from Cisco, Viacom and Nvidia .



Cisco Systems reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its fiscal first quarter 2020 results. Revenue of $13.20 billion (+2% YoY excluding the SPVSS divestment) edged past the consensus of $13.08 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of 84 cents (+12% YoY) beat the consensus by three pennies.

Digging deeper, product revenue was flat YoY at $9.878 billion but in line with $9.824 billion consensus, while service was up 4% at $3.281 billion -- and in line with the $3.254 billion consensus. Breaking products down further, infrastructure platforms revenue fell 1% YoY to $7.538 billion vs. $7.608 billion consensus; application revenue was up 6% to $1.499, in line with $1.476 billion consensus; security revenue grew 22% to $815 million, which was strong compared to $723 million consensus; and "other products" revenue fell to $26 million, vs. a $36 million consensus. Software subscriptions as a percent of total software revenue -- one of the more meaningful metrics for assessing the company's transformation -- now sits at 71%, up 1 percentage point quarter-over-quarter, and 12 percentage points year-over-year.

Guidance was a big disappointment and sent shares lower the next day. For the second quarter of fiscal 2020, revenue is expected to decline 3% to 5% year-over-year, well below Street estimates of 2.4% growth. Moving through guidance, adjusted gross margins are expected range from 64.5% to 65.5% (vs. the Street's expectation of 64.5%) with an adjusted operating margin rate of 32.5% to 33.5% (vs. the Street's 32.5%). All of this leads to an adjusted earnings-per share guidance in the range of 75 cents to 77 cents, which is light against a 79-cent consensus expectation.



Viacom reported a top and bottom-line beat with its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings results. Revenues of $3.433 billion (-1% YoY, flat constant currency) topped the consensus of $3.42 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of $0.79 (-20% YoY; -14% on constant currency) exceeded estimates by $0.03.

At Filmed Entertainment, revenues of $851 million (-14% YoY) came in short of the $865 million estimates. But more importantly, adjusted operating income was $54 million (+42% YoY), exceeding estimates of $14 million and marked the 11th straight quarter of YoY operating income improvement. At Media Networks, revenues of $2.614 billion (+4 YoY, +6% constant currency) beat $2.584 billion consensus expectations, while adjusted operating income of $597 million (-16% YoY, -13% constant currency) was below $623 million expectations.

With this likely the last reported quarter for Viacom as a standalone company, investors focus now moves to the Viacom-CBS merger. During the Q&A, management spoke to four revenue opportunities of the combination: distribution, U.S. advertising, content licensing, and streaming.



Nvidia reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its fiscal third quarter 2020 results. Revenue of $3.014 billion (-5% YoY) outpaced the $2.921 billion consensus, while adjusted earnings per share of $1.78 (-3% YoY) surpassed expectations of $1.58 per share. On the margin front, Nvidia outperformed its own guidance with adjusted gross margins coming in at a strong 64.1%, up 400 basis points sequentially and a solid beat versus prior guidance of 62.5% +/-50bps.

In the upcoming quarter management expects revenue in the range of $2.95 billion +/-2%, which at the midpoint is a tad short vs. the $3.066 billion consensus.

But while the revenue guide may have come up short, gross margins guidance more than makes up for it as management expects adjusted gross margins for the fourth quarter in the range of 64.5% +/- 50bps, a strong forecast vs. the 62.65% consensus heading into the print. Adjusted operating expense guidance of $805 million on the other hand was a bit high vs. expectations of $783 million and up slightly from third quarter adjusted operating expenses of $774 million.


Economy

On Wednesday, The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics that the Consumer Price Index (CPI) advanced 0.4% in October on a seasonally adjusted basis, edging out expectations for a 0.3% monthly advance, following a flat September reading. Over the last 12 months, the CPI has increased 1.8% before seasonal adjustment, also outpacing the 1.7% consensus and representing an acceleration versus the 1.7% rate seen in August and September.

The "core" CPI rose 0.2% in October, in line with expectations. Over the past 12 months, core CPI has risen 2.3%, below expectations for a 2.4% advance. However, while the advance is above the Fed's 2.0% target, the reading represents a deceleration from the 2.4% annual rate of advance seen in August and September. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reported that the Producer Price Index for final demand advanced 0.4% (seasonally adjusted) in October, edging out expectations for a 0.3% advance and coming on the heels of a 0.3% decline in September. On an annual basis (unadjusted), the PPI increased 1.1%, also outpacing expectations for a rise of 0.9%, following a 1.4% annual rate of advance in September.

Core PPI was up 0.1% in October following a flat September reading. Additionally, the core index advanced 1.5% from the same time last year, a deceleration from the 1.7% annual rate of advance seen in the 12-month period that ended in September. See for our full analysis.

Also, on Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending November 9 were 225,000, an 14,000-claim increase from the previous week's unrevised level of 211,000, and 10,000 claims above expectations of 215,000. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 217,000, a 1,750-claim increase from the previous week's unrevised average of 215,250. The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 - the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 244 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

On Friday, the U.S. Commerce Department reported that retail and food-services sales advanced 0.3% in October to $526.5 billion, exceeding expectations for a 0.2% monthly advance, following a 0.3% decline in September. Retail and food services sales are up 3.1% from the same time last year. On a monthly basis, excluding auto sales, retail sales were up 0.2%, missing expectations for a 0.4% rise. Excluding autos and gas, sales were up 0.1%, also missing expectations for a 0.3% advance. Core retail sales were up 0.3% in October, matching expectations. See for our full analysis.

Also, on Friday, the Federal Reserve announced that industrial production fell 0.8% in October, missing expectations for a 0.4% monthly decline. However, partially offsetting the miss, September's reading was revised up to indicate a 0.3% decline (from -0.4% previously). Capacity utilization also came in below expectations for October, registering a 76.7% reading versus a 77.0% consensus. Total industrial production is down 1.1% from the same time last year, while total capacity utilization increased 2.2% annually. See for our full analysis.

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)


Oil

On the commodity front, oil prices remain rangebound as trade negotiations remain in limbo and efforts by OPEC+ to bring supply in line with demand, are offset by rampant US production

On the domestic front, on Thursday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), reported that in the week ending November 8, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) increased by 2.2 million barrels to 449.0 million barrels, a bearish reading versus expectations for a 1.65 million barrel increase. Additionally, U.S. production pushed a new all-time high of 12.8 million bpd. Lastly, net imports decreased by 589,000 bpd as imports decreased by 327,000 bpd, while exports increased by 262,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at around the $5 to $6 per barrel level. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive U.S. based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we initiated a position in Starbucks
and bulked up on our stakes in Twilio
and Viacom . On the other hand, we trimmed our exposure in Caterpillar twice through our Alerts and and also UnitedHealth Group in our Alert here .

Moving on to the S&P 500, third-quarter earnings season is underway with 75.7% reporting a positive EPS surprise. For the third quarter, earnings growth is down roughly 1.1% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 1.23% decline throughout the season; of the 390 non-financials that reported, earnings are down 1.9%. Revenues for the S&P 500 are up 2.7% vs. expectations throughout the season for a 2.79% increase; 75.7% of companies beat EPS expectations, 17.5% missed the mark and 6.8% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 66.08% beat the prior year's EPS results, 31.07% came up short and 2.84% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Healthcare, Information Tech and Consumer Stapled, while the worst performing have been Real Estate, Materials and Energy.

Next week, 23 companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. Within the portfolio, we will hear from Home Depot and Kohl's on Tuesday, before the opening bell.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: LexinFintech LX, Qudian QD, Manchester United MANU, ZTO Express ZTO, BiliBili BILI, Woodward WWD, Ashland ASH, America's Car-Mart CRMT, Kornit Digital KRNT, TJX TJX, Medtronic MDT, Aramark ARMK, FinVolution Group PPDF, Transdigm Group TDG, JinkoSolar Holding JKS, MAXIMUS MMS, NJ Resources NJR, 58.com WUBA, Endava DAVA, PagSeguro Digital PAGS, Urban Outfitters URBN, Esco Tech ESE, Target TGT, Lowe's LOW, Pinduoduo PDD, QIWI QIWI, Avaya Holdings AVYA, Spire SR, L Brands LB, Netease NTES, Sociedad Quimica y Minera SQM, La-Z-Boy LZB, Cubic CUB, Sonos SONO, Green Thumb GTBIF, Nuance Communications NUAN, Macy's M, BJ's Wholesale BJ, Berry Global BERY, Baozun BZUN, BrightView BV, Evoqua Water AQUA, Brady BRC, Anaplan PLAN, Hoegh LNG Partners HMLP, Gap GPS, Ross Stores ROST, Nordstrom JWN, Post POST, Intuit INTU, Splunk SPLK, Pure Storage PSTG, Matthews MATW, Shoe Carnival SCVL, Enanta Pharmaceuticals ENTA, Ooma OOMA, i3 Verticals IIIV, J.M. Smucker SJM, Foot LockerFL, Atkore International ATKR, Hibbett Sporting HIBB, Futu Holdings FUTU and Buckle BKE.

New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated over $2.46 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.


Tickers: ABT ABBV AMZN ATVI AAPL BP BURL C CAT CMCSA CRM CSCO CVS DIS FB GOOGL GS HD HON JPM JNJ KSS LRCX MA MRVL MSFT NVDA NVS PEP SBUX SLB TWLO UNH VIAB



ONES


Abbott Laboratories ; $85.71; 725 shares; 2.12%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, Abbott Laboratories announced that Miles White will step down as CEO effective March 31st, 2020 but remain Executive Chairmen of the Board. It signals the end of a 21-year run, which represents the second longest for a non-founder in the entire S&P 100. Succeeding White will be current President and COO Robert Ford, a 23-year veteran of the company who has served in many leadership roles within the company including in the Nutrition and Medical Devices businesses. We discussed the news in more detail earlier this week, . 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.35%; Yield: 1.49%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Strong underlying performance with an achievable (and beatable) 2019 organic sales growth expectation in the 6.5% to 7.5% range. The company boasts high performing franchises in Medical Devices (with strong growth in Diabetes Care) and Diagnostics (with strong gains in Core Laboratory), while Nutrition and Established Pharmaceutical remain strategic parts of its total portfolio. We believe the company's opportunities for upside rest with additional Libre uptake, the Alinity U.S. launch, and an expanded indication of the Mitraclip. We believe in CEO Miles White and the Abbott management team, who has a strong track record of integrating acquisitions and delivering double-digit earnings per share growth. Lastly, Abbott has plenty of financial flexibility to pursue mergers/acquisitions and other strategic actions. Target Price: Reiterate $94; Rating: ne


RISKS: Emerging market exposure, Product disruptions.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , ,



Amazon ; $1739.49; 80 shares; 4.75%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, as anticipated, Amazon it plans to contest the Pentagon's decision to award the $10 billion, 10 year "JEDI" contract to Microsoft, citing "unmistakable bias." We spoke to Jim about it during Friday's Facebook live video, which members can watch, .1-Wk. Price Change: -2.60%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Amazon's continued Commerce dominance, AWS' continued leadership in the public cloud space, and ongoing growth of the company's advertising revenue stream, which feeds off Amazon's eCommerce business. Additionally, we believe profitability will continue to improve as AWS and advertising account for a larger portion of total sales as both these segments sport higher margins than the eCommerce operation. And while we believe the increasing share of revenue from these higher margin businesses will be key to driving profitability longer-term, we believe margins on ecommerce stand to improve as the company's infrastructure is further built out and economies of scale further kick in. The embedded call option is that management is always looking to enter a new space and generate new revenue streams. Target Price: Reiterate $2,050; Rating: One


RISKS: High valuation exposes the stock to volatile swings, eCommerce has exposure to slower consumer spending, competition, management is not afraid to invest heavily, potential headwinds resulting from new eCommerce regulation in India, management is not scared to invest aggressively for growth, which can at times cause volatile reactions as near-term concerns arise relating to the impact on margins.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , (1/10/19), ,



AbbVie ; $88.63; 1150 shares; 3.48%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: The company sold $30 billion of bonds on Tuesday, the fourth largest investment grade bond sale on record. Proceeds will be used to fund the Allergan acquisition which is expected to close in early 2019. The fact that this deal was met with strong demand is a positive indication of the robust free cash flow the new company is expected to generate. We are raising our price target to $94, as we roll out our estimates to FY2020. Or new target represents a valuation of ~9.5x FY2020 earnings estimates of $9.89 per share. 1-Wk. Price Change: 4.01%; Yield: 5.33%


INVESTMENT THESIS: AbbVie is a biopharmaceutical company best known for its blockbuster drug Humira, which is expected to generate about $19 billion in sales this calendar year and more than $18 billion in 2020. Despite the incredible selling strength of this product, investors have shied away from this name due to Humira's lost patent protection in Europe and risk in the United States in 2023. Key to the AbbVie's future is the acquisition of Allergan, a deal that will diversify the company's revenue stream and give it exposure to Medical Aesthetics, neuroscience, and eye care, while also increase operating cash flow. Lastly, the company pays a high yielding dividend that we believe is supported by the balance sheet and well covered by the cash flow. Target Price: Raised to $94 Rating: One


RISKS: Execution of the Allergan integration, drug pricing, pipeline issues, loss of exclusivity on key drugs, competition


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , ,



Activision Blizzard ; $53.44; 800 shares; 1.46%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, analysts at Stifel, who currently maintain a Buy rating at $65 price target on shares, released a brief industry overview note calling out that according to Sensor Tower, Call of Duty Mobile downloads had reached 148 million downloads and $53 million in revenues. While the recurring sales power of the mobile game remains to be seen we believe the update to support our view that it is certainly increasing the company's reach and therefore in-game monetization potential. As for consoles, the report also noted that according to Game Sales Data (GSD), "Call of Duty: Modern Warfare was the best-selling title (physical + digital) in Europe for the week-ended November 3rd." Given the ongoing sales momentum, we continue to believe that fourth-quarter guidance provided on the most recent earnings release will ultimately prove conservative. 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.58%; Yield: 0.69%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe video gaming to be one of the fastest growing forms of entertainment and that the issues that had plagued the Activision Blizzard in the past such as a failure to innovate in-line with player demand (being late to the game with a battle royal game) and a previous lack of updates to established franchises, such as Overwatch and Diablo, to now be behind the company and that shares have failed to reflect improving fundamentals. In addition to strong title launches, we continue to view Activision Blizzard as being at the forefront of the esports industry (though we place little emphasis on this in the near-term as esports profitability remains a longer-term story) thanks to significant investments in the Overwatch league and decision to launch a Call of Duty league in calendar year 2020. Finally, compounding the improving company-specific fundamentals, we believe the industry-wide shift toward digital downloads and in-game monetization to be a material factor that will aid in margin expansion overtime. Target Price: Reiterate $62 Rating: One


RISKS: Competition, in-game purchase related regulatory headwinds, failed adoption of new releases.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



CVS Health ; $74.29; 2175 shares; 5.52%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: Credit Suisse hosted CEO Larry Merlo and CFO Eva Boratto for a presentation at the 28th Annual Credit Suisse Healthcare Conference. The part of the conversation we were focused on was the HealthHubs, which we remind you are in pilot mode. The current plan is for 1,500 Hub locations by the end of 2021. On the third-quarter earnings call, management qualitatively said these Hubs are outperforming traditional stores. During the Credit Suisse presentation, Boratto said they plan to give more quantitative metrics by the middle of next year. Though shares have been on a tear lately, we stand by our view that CVS can achieve a reasonable price to multiple of 12x on a $7 EPS number. 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.51%; Yield: 2.69%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Aetna integration progress, which we believe will allow shares to re-rate higher as the price-to-earnings valuation closes the gap with peers, and a deleveraging of the balance sheet, which has been another concern for investors. We believe the new CVS Health will transform into a diversified pharmacy/healthcare retailer that is integrated with a managed care operation, creating a more personalized and analytic-based experience that all patients will want. Additionally, we value shares because CVS is an all-domestic company (providing insulation from trade-related headwinds) in the healthcare field (defensive) without a lot of cyclicality, making it even more attractive as we are faced with a barrage of headlines about slower global economic growth. Target Price: Reiterate $84; Rating: One


RISKS: Failure to execute on Aetna integration, greater than expected rebate guarantee headwinds on PBM business, regulatory headwinds


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , , , , Investor Relations



Salesforce ; $163.21; 775 shares; 4.32%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: It's that time of year, where we will hear from industry leaders and learn more about the direction of the company at Salesforce's annual event, next week. Jim will be there in person to cover the event and we look forward to learning more and hearing from a slew of influential people including Tim Cook and President Barack Obama. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.30%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We are bullish on shares of CRM as we view Salesforce as a key player in the "digital revolution" and invaluable to those companies looking to build out their digital strategy and better understand their customer base. Furthermore, we believe the acquisition of MuleSoft effectively expanded the company's total addressable market by unlocking data previously trapped on legacy systems, to be used on the Salesforce platform. These factors compounded by a strong management team keep us confident that the company remains on track to reach its FY2022 target of $21 billion to $23 billion in revenue. Target Price: Reiterate $170; Rating: One


RISKS: Slowdown in IT spending, competition

Alphabet ; $1333.54; 70 shares; 3.19%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, the Wall Street Journal that Google, in what has been code-named "Project Nightingale," has been working with Ascnesion, "a Catholic chain of 2,600 hospitals, doctors' offices and other facilities" to collect and analyze personal-health data on millions of people in across 21 states. Per the report, "The data involved in the initiative encompasses lab results, doctor diagnoses and hospitalization records, among other categories, and amounts to a complete health history, including patient names and dates of birth." While the news appeared to violate the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPA), the companies claimed it was compliant with federal law. As also noted in the article, HIPA "allows hospitals to share data with business partners without telling patients, as long as the information is used 'only to help the covered entity carry out its health care functions.'" We will continue to monitor for updates. However, while this may be technically legal, it certainly does not help Alphabet's case as regulators and politicians continue to look at the company with many calling for a breakup. That said, as we've noted before, we do not believe a potential breakup would ruin the investment case and continue to believe that a breakup of big tech may even unlock value as faster growing segments would be freed up to trade at an expanded multiple. In other news, just in case a massive data collection on millions of American's health records wasn't enough to draw further scrutiny, the WSJ also this week that Google has its sights trained on consumer finance with plans to roll out consumer checking accounts. Per the article, "The project, code-named Cache, is expected to launch next year with accounts run by Citigroup Inc. and a credit union at Stanford University, a tiny lender in Google's backyard." 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.87%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe that while Search and digital ad dominance is what will carry shares in the near- to- midterm, longer-term it is the company's artificial intelligence (AI) "moat" that will provide for new avenues of growth. AI is what has made the company's Search, Video (YouTube) and targeted ad capabilities best-in-class and is the driving force behind the company's success in voice (Google Home) and autonomous driving (Waymo). Furthermore, we believe it is this AI expertise that will also make the company more prevalent in other industries, including healthcare via subsidiary Verily, as AI and machine learning continue to disrupt operations across industries. We believe Alphabet's willingness to invest in new areas, knowing most will fail, is a recipe for long-term success as while most " " projects may fail, every once in a while, you end up with a Waymo, perhaps the division's, most successful graduate to date. Lastly, compounding out positive view of the company's future opportunities, we believe that Alphabet's free cash flow generation and solid balance sheet set it apart and are what will allow the company to continue taking chances on far-out ground-breaking and potentially world changing projects. RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, interest rates, credit quality.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



Kohl's ; $59.08; 1000 shares; 2.02%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: We look forward to hearing from management when the company reports earnings next week on Tuesday, before the opening bell, where we will be looking for sales of $4.4 billion and earnings of $0.86 per share. 1-Wk. Price Change: 3.58%; Yield: 4.54%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We like Kohl's position in the department store industry. Its brands are tailored to middle-income buyers who shop for value, or good deals, while their store locations remain away from the mall which has been subject to decline in foot traffic. The company is run by a strategic management team who has several strong initiatives in place (standard-to-small initiatives, partnership with Planet Fitness, Fanatics, of course Amazon and more) that drive traffic and improve inventory management. Additionally, Kohl's continues to be a large beneficiary of peer closings (like Bon-Ton), resulting in increased market share. Target Price: Reiterate $56; Rating: Two


RISKS: A decline in consumer spending, shifts in consumer fashion preferences, margin pressure related to increased competition, weather impacting consumer shopping habits, tariffs,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



Lam Research ; $283.68; 150 shares; 1.45%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Shares hit a in response to the strong earnings/outlook from Applied Materials. 1-Wk. Price Change: 4.03%; Yield: 1.62%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $285; Rating: Two


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Nvidia ; $204.19; 475 shares; 3.31%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.73%; Yield: 0.31%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Nvidia's GPU dominance, the moat created by its CUDA, the company's parallel computing platform, and significant growth in all of the company's end markets including, the cloud (think datacenter), gaming, autonomous vehicles and pro visualization. Furthermore, we believe the cloud (i.e. data center) growth will be even more of a factor in upside following the acquisition of Mellanox, which thanks to its low latency "InfiniBand" technology, provides Nvidia the ability be a more integral player in the buildout of data centers by working to both accelerate server subsystems via GPU-acceleration and accelerate the data center overall by "tying together" the multiple subsystems and allowing them to operate as a single cohesive unit. Target Price: Reiterate $220; Rating: Two


RISKS: slow uptake of ray-tracing chips which will depend on gaming publishers' implementation of the new technology in software releases, a slowdown in the IT/data center spending, competition, slower than expected inventory channel normalization.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,



Schlumberger ; $35.36; 1500 shares; 1.81%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.70%; Yield: 5.66%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe Schlumberger is the best of breed name in the oil services industry. Although the company's earnings power is dependent on the timing of the upstream investment cycle, management has a strong reputation in execution as well as a good handle in understanding the supply/demand dynamic of the industry. The company's premier technology gives it an advantage over peers and allows for market share gains. Furthermore, we value the company's international presence as it means a lessened exposure to North America, where new drilling activity remains limited. As compensation for our patience in the investment cycle's recovery, shares offer an attractive dividend that was confirmed to be backed by cash flow on the company's most recent earnings call. Target Price: $55 Rating: Two


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, weak capital spending of upstream oil and gas operators.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (1/22/19), , , Investor Relations



UnitedHealth Group ; $269.4; 325 shares; 2.99%; Sector: Health


WEEKLY UPDATE: We our position this week following a strong rally related to the Trump administration's release of a rule that if passed, would force hospitals and insurers to publicize negotiated rates. As by CNBC, "The administration already requires hospitals to publish list prices, sometimes referred to as 'sticker prices.' That doesn't always reflect what someone with insurance might pay. The rule presented Friday, expected to be enacted in 2021, will go further by requiring hospitals to also post the prices paid by various insurance plans." This new policy may be a "better than feared outcome." While the strong move on Friday came following President Trump's press conference on the planned rule, we believe it was also aided by the release of Elizabeth Warrens, , which appears to be less extreme than feared, at least to start, as it noted that a transition to a full Medicare for All system would take multiple years and start with a "Medicare for All option." 1-Wk. Price Change: 4.84%; Yield: 1.60%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view UnitedHealth Group as a high performing health insurance company. Its business is divided into two subsidiaries: UnitedHealthcare, which represents the insurance side of the company, and Optum, a fast-growing, margin expanding, and technology/data leveraging division with exposure to PBM, healthcare consulting, and specialized health and wellness services. We value the company's consistent, economic-cycle resilient performance, supported by management's long-term expectation of 13% to 15% growth. Lastly, the company generates a significant amount of operating cash flow, which supports the large share repurchase program that is currently in place. Target Price: Reiterate $305; Rating:


RISKS: Higher than expected medical costs, changes to healthcare policy, slower growth at Optum


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , ,
