urn:contentItem:5WWM-M101-F00X-J4H4-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Markets see volatility as U.S. Trade war with China intensifies.

Markets, despite seeing some volatility into the weekend on the news that China plans to in kind to U.S. tariffs, had a largely positive week as earnings from several major retailers backed the view that while global (including the U.S.) economic growth may be slowing, the U.S. consumer remains strong. Regarding the tariffs, China plans to implement tariffs of 5% to 10% on $75 billion worth of U.S. goods in two stages, the first coming on September 1st and the second on December 15th, the same dates that US tariffs on Chinese goods are currently set to take effect.

However, while the news out of China sent Friday's pre-market activity from positive to negative almost instantly, markets attempted to pare losses flip back to positive territory as , noting that the challenge now is to sustain the US economic expansion (indicating that they will act as necessary to do so). Additionally, he stated that while inflation has ticked up slightly in their view, they will continue to consider global dynamics, including the ongoing U.S./China trade war, asserting that the Fed can adjust policy as a result of trade developments.

Nevertheless, the rally attempt was ultimately stymied as President Trump responded to China's tariff announcement by :


"Our Country has lost, stupidly, Trillions of Dollars with China over many years. They have stolen our Intellectual Property at a rate of Hundreds of Billions of Dollars a year, & they want to continue. I won't let that happen! We don't need China and, frankly, would be far better off without them. The vast amounts of money made and stolen by China from the United States, year after year, for decades, will and must STOP. Our great American companies are hereby ordered to immediately start looking for an alternative to China, including bringing your companies HOME and making your products in the USA. I will be responding to China's Tariffs this afternoon. This is a GREAT opportunity for the United States. Also, I am ordering all carriers, including Fed Ex, Amazon, UPS and the Post Office, to SEARCH FOR & REFUSE, all deliveries of Fentanyl from China (or anywhere else!). Fentanyl kills 100,000 Americans a year. President Xi said this would stop - it didn't. Our Economy, because of our gains in the last 2 1/2 years, is MUCH larger than that of China. We will keep it that way!"

While the tweets were certainly intense, we remind members that this is President Trump's negotiating style, to hit hard and later walk it back. As a result, we remain focused on the underlying fundamentals of our positions and will look to use any ensuing weakness to our advantage by buying those stocks that do not rely on lower rates or global growth and are instead, exposed to secular multi-year trends.

10-year Treasury yields are hovering around the 1.5% 2-10 spread continues to play in inversion territory. Gold prices remain in the low $1,500s per ounce level. The U.S. dollar stands at ~97 level while WTI oil prices continue to tread water in the mid-$50s per barrel region.

Second-quarter earnings season is winding down. Within the portfolio, we heard from Home Depot, Kohl's and Salesforce.



Home Depot reported a mixed headline result with its second-quarter earnings. Sales of $30.8 billion (+1.2% year-over-year) came in shy against the $30.98 billion consensus, but adjusted earnings per share of $3.17 beat the consensus by nine cents.

Looking at comparable sales, Home Depot saw a +3% increase at the company level compared to expectations of 3.4%, with +3.1% in the United States. Importantly, comps picked up speed through the quarter, as the monthly cadence was +0.2% in May, +4.1% in June, and +4.6% in July, and the U.S. delivering +0.6% comps in May, +4.1% in June, and +4.7% in July. All but two regions in the United delivered positive comps, and every merchandising department, expect for lumber, was in positive territory.

On guidance, Management trimmed its full year sales outlook to +2.3%, with comparable sales of +4%, a change from previous guidance of a +5% comps growth. This new target reflects continued lumber price deflation and some conservatism around how the U.S. consumer may be affected by the trade war.



Kohl's reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its FY2Q19 earnings results. On the top line, sales of $4.43 billion (-3.1% YoY) outpaced the $4.31 billion consensus. On the bottom line, adjusted earnings per share of $1.55 (-12% YoY) exceeded expectations of $1.53 per share. In addition to the headline results, while the company's gross margin declined 70 bps from the year ago period at 38.8%, it was largely in line with expectations. Looking to the all-important retail metric, same-store sales (a.k.a. comps), while the headline numbers came in above estimates, same-store sales were somewhat disappointing at -2.9% versus the -2.4% analysts were looking for. While this is certainly not what it was in the year-ago period when same store sales advanced 3.1%, it is a sequential improvement versus the FY1Q19's 3.4% decline and in line with CFO Bruce Besanko's commentary on the first-quarter conference call, where he stated, "We expect Q2 comps to remain soft but show relative improvement to Q1."

Additionally, despite the second-quarter comps miss, it is important to remember that sentiment was about as bad as it could have been coming into the release and as a result, in our view, the same store sales miss is forgivable given the simple fact that despite all the pressures facing retail such as trade, a tight labor market and fears of a recession on the horizon, the company managed to reaffirm its adjusted annual earnings guidance (which management reiterated does take into account tariff concerns) of $5.15 to $5.45 per diluted share, which at the midpoint ($5.30 per share) exceeds the $5.23 per share consensus.



Salesforce.com reported a strong top- and bottom-line beat with its fiscal second quarter 2020 earnings. Revenue of $4 billion (+23% year-over-year on a constant currency, or CC, basis) beat the consensus of $3.955 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of 66 cents (including items) exceeded the consensus expectation of 47 cents.

By services: sales cloud revenue growth accelerated sequentially to 12.5% with its $1.13 billion number; service cloud increased 22% year-over-year to about $1.1 billion; Salesforce platform and "other" increased 28% year-over-year to $0.9 billion (and that includes $159 million of "Mulseoft,"); and lastly, marketing cloud & commerce cloud increased 36% year-over-year to $0.6 billion.

Salesforce.com's current remaining performance obligation, which represents all future revenue under contract that has not been recognized as revenue yet, increased 25% YoY CC to $12.1 billion, topping expectations of $11.82 billion. Cash flow was strong relative to expectations, decreasing 5%YoY to $436 million but greatly exceeding estimates of $271 million.

For the full year, management raised its full fiscal year revenue outlook to $16.75 billion to $16.90 billion (+26% to 27% YoY growth), smashing current consensus of $16.435 billion. In addition, adjusted earnings per share is expected to be $2.82 to $2.84, an outlook that is greater than the current consensus of $2.77. Plus, operating cash flow is expected to grow 21% to 22% YoY.


Economy

On Tuesday, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) reported that existing home sales - completed transactions for single-family homes, town homes, condominiums and co-ops - popped 2.5% in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.42 million, exceeding expectations for a 2.3% increase (or 5.39 million rate). Compounding the advance, June's reading was revised up to a 5.29 million unit rate from 5.27 million previously reported. With July's reading, existing home sales are up 0.6% from the same time last year. As for pricing, the median existing home price increased 4.3% YoY to $280,800, marking the 89th consecutive month of yearly price gains. Additionally, regarding 30-year, conventional, fixed-rate mortgages, the average commitment rate was 3.77% in July, down from 3.80% in June and below the 4.54% average for all of 2018, according to Freddie Mac. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending August 17 were 209,000, a 12,000-claim decrease from the previous week's revised level of 221,000 (revised up from 220,000), and 7,000 claims below expectations of 216,000 initial jobless claims. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 214,500, an increase of 500 from the previous week's revised average of 214,000 (revised up from 213,750). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 233 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

On Friday, the U.S. Census Bureau reported that new home sales in July dropped 12.8% month over month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 635,000. However, while the decline missed expectations for a 0.16% advance on a percentage point basis (to a 647,000 seasonally adjusted unit rate), June's reading was revised sharply upward to a rate of 728,000 (from 646,000 previously), more than making up for the July miss.

Digging deeper, month over month, sales surged 50.0% in the Northeast (+56.0% YoY), however, this was more than offset by an 11.1% decline in the Midwest (-18.8% YoY), a 14.2% pullback in the West (+8.4.0% YoY), and a 16.1% drop in the South (+3.2% YoY). As for costs, the average selling price in July advanced to $388,000 (from $354,500 in June). The median sales price also moved higher, increasing to $312,800 (from $306,000 in June). See for our full analysis.Oil

On the commodity front, the dynamic remains largely unchanged. Oil prices remain in limbo as fears of a global slowdown continue to be counter balanced by ongoing tensions in the Middle East. While the global growth fears remain a result of ongoing trade issues, tensions in the Middle East intensified coming into the week as . A larger than expected U.S. inventory drawdown also helped support prices.

On the domestic front, on Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), reported that in the week ending August 16, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) decreased by 2.7 million barrels to 437.8 million barrels, a bullish reading versus expectations for a 1.89 million barrel drawdown. Additionally, U.S. production was unchanged at 12.3 million bpd. Lastly, net imports fell by 617,000 bpd as imports decreased by 497,000 bpd, while exports increased by 120,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent currently stands at ~$5 per barrel. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive U.S. based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we added to our positions in Palo Alto Networks ( ), Citigroup ( ) and Viacom ( ).

Moving on to the broader market, second-quarter earnings season is winding down with 74.3% of companies reporting a positive EPS surprise. For the second-quarter, earnings growth is up roughly 2.2% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 2.07% advance throughout the season; for the 408 non-financials that reported, earnings are up 2.0%. Revenues are up 3.6% vs. expectations throughout the season for a 3.13% increase; 74.3% of companies beat EPS expectations, 18.3% missed the mark and 7.4% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 67.58% beat the prior year's EPS results, 31.58% came up short and 0.84% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Healthcare, Information Tech and Communication Services, while the worst performing have been Consumer Discretionary, Energy and Utilities.

Next week, 26 companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. Within the portfolio we will here from Burlington BURL on Thursday before the open and Marvell MRVL on Thursday after the close.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: OSI Systems OSIS, Futu Holdings FHL, BiliBili BILI, Caleres CAL, Bank of Nova Scotia BNS, Bank of Montreal BMO, J.M. Smucker SJM, Catalent CTLT, Momo, Eaton Vance EV, American Woodmark AMWD, Lancaster Colony LANC, Barnes & Noble Education BNED, J. Jill JILL, Anaplan PLAN, Hewlett Packard Enterprise HPE, Autodesk ADSK, HEICO HEI, Veeva Systems VEEV, Philbro Animal Health PAHC, Lannett LCI, Ooma OOMA, Coty COTY, Tiffany & Co TIF, Brown-Forman BF.B, Chico's FAS CHS, Express EXPR, Daktronics DAKT, PVH PVH, Greif GEF, Guess? GES, Five Below FIVE, Matrix Service MTRX, Ollie's Bargain Outlet OLLI, Nutanix NTNX, Shoe Carnival SCVL, Sportsmans Warehouse SPWH, Box BOX, Tilly's TLYS, H&R Block HRB, Semtech SMTC, Okta OKTA, Elastic ESTC, Zuora ZUO, Toronto-Dominion BankTD, Best Buy BBY, Tech Data TECD, Dollar GeneralDG, Dollar Tree DLTR, Patterson Companies PDCO, Sanderson Farms SAFM, Designer Brands DBI, Abercrombie & Fitch ANF, GMS GMS, Hain Celestial HAIN, Titan Machinery TITN, Methode Electronics MEI, Malibu Boats MBUU, Dell DELL, Ulta Beauty ULTA, Workday WDAY, Cooper COO, American Outdoor Brands AOBC, Yext YEXT, Ambarella AMBA, Campbell Soup CPB and JinkoSolar Holding JKS.

New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated over $2.46 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.

Amazon $1749.62; 80 shares; 5.35%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary

WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, TechCrunch that Amazon "has acquired a 49% stake in Future Coupons, a group entity owned by India's second largest retail chain Future Group." An Amazon spokesperson told the online publication, "Amazon has agreed to invest in Future Coupons Limited, which is engaged in developing innovative value-added payment products and solutions such as corporate gift cards, loyalty cards, and reward cards primarily for corporate and institutional customers. This investment will enhance Amazon's existing portfolio of investments in the payments landscape in India." We view this as a solid move that should aid the company's push into the India, a market that has been incredibly difficult to gain traction in due to regulation, however, one that is highly sought after given its over 6% GDP growth rate (one of the fastest in the world), ~1.34 billion population and rapidly growing middle class (think a greater base of consumers able to buy discretionary items). 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.40%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Amazon's continued Commerce dominance, AWS' continued leadership in the public cloud space, and ongoing growth of the company's advertising revenue stream, which feeds off Amazon's eCommerce business. Additionally, we believe profitability will continue to improve as AWS and advertising account for a larger portion of total sales as both these segments sport higher margins than the eCommerce operation. And while we believe the increasing share of revenue from these higher margin businesses will be key to driving profitability longer-term, we believe margins on ecommerce stand to improve as the company's infrastructure is further built out and economies of scale further kick in. The embedded call option is that management is always looking to enter a new space and generate new revenue streams. Target Price: Reiterate $2,050; Rating: ONE


RISKS: High valuation exposes the stock to volatile swings, eCommerce has exposure to slower consumer spending, competition, management is not afraid to invest heavily. The outcome of the Pentagon's $10 billion JEDI contract is also something to watch as Amazon is largely considered to be the front runner, Potential headwinds resulting from new eCommerce regulation in India, management is not scared to invest aggressively for growth, which can at times cause volatile reactions as near-term concerns arise relating to the impact on margins.

Burlington Stores Inc $173.96; 475 shares; 3.16%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: We look forward to hearing from management next week, when the company reports earnings on Thursday, before the opening bell. On the top line, we're looking for sales of $1.63 billion. On the bottom line, expectations are for earnings of $1.14 per share. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.06%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Specializing as an off-price retailer, Burlington Stores sources its merchandise opportunistically, meaning that management purchases excess inventory from struggling retailers and then resells the quality merchandise at everyday low prices. The bargains Burlington's stores offer creates a "treasure hunting" experience for its shoppers, and this cannot be replicated by e-commerce. Therefore, we believe Burlington's business model keeps them immune from the pressures facing department stores, and we expect the company will continue to deliver low single digit same store sales growth. Lastly, any supply chain disruptions caused by tariffs may work to Burlington's favor, as off-price's value will gain additional favor should either prices increase, or stores need to unload inventory. Target Price: Reiterate $200; Rating: One


RISKS: Consumer spending, inventory availability

INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe that while Search and digital ad dominance is what will carry shares in the near- to- midterm, longer-term it is the company's artificial intelligence (AI) "moat" that will provide for new avenues of growth. Furthermore, we believe it is this AI expertise that will also make the company more prevalent in other industries, including healthcare via subsidiary Verily, as AI and machine learning continue to disrupt operations across industries. We believe Alphabet's willingness to invest in new areas, knowing most will fail, is a recipe for long-term success as while most " " projects may fail, every once in a while, you end up with a Waymo, perhaps the division's, most successful graduate to date. Lastly, compounding out positive view of the company's future opportunities, we believe that Alphabet's free cash flow generation and solid balance sheet set it apart and are what will allow the company to continue taking chances on far-out ground-breaking and potentially world changing projects. Microsoft Corp $133.39; 550 shares; 2.8%; Sector: Technology


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, Microsoft Azure CTO Mark Russinovich published a in which he announced that the company "will join industry partners to create the Confidential Computing Consortium, a new organization that will be hosted at The Linux Foundation. The Confidential Computing Consortium will be dedicated to defining and accelerating the adoption of confidential computing." Per the post, "Confidential computing technologies offer the opportunity for organizations to collaborate on their data sets without giving access to that data, to gain shared insights and to innovate for the common good. The Consortium, which will include other founding members Alibaba, ARM, Baidu, Google Cloud, IBM, Intel, Red Hat, Swisscom and Tencent, is the organization where the industry can come together to collaborate on open source technology and frameworks to support these new confidential computing scenarios." We view this as an important move as big tech remains under fire for its data privacy practices - though Microsoft has largely been left tout of the spotlight shined on companies such as Alphabet and Facebook. We believe initiatives such as this will help keep Microsoft in the good graces of consumers and developers and act as another incentive when companies are choosing cloud providers as again, data privacy is a top priority. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.01%; Yield: 1.38%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe the cloud to be a secular growth trend and that upside to shares will result from Microsoft's hybrid cloud leadership as the company grab's market in this expanding industry. While companies may look to build out multi-cloud environments, Microsoft's Azure offering will be a prime choice thanks to the company's decision to provide the same "stack" used in the public cloud, to companies for their on-premise data centers. Additionally, we would note that hybrid environments are currently the preference for most companies because it allows them to maintain critical data in house while taking advantage of the agility and scalability provided by public clouds. Outside of the cloud opportunity, we maintain a positive view on the company's growing gaming business, which we believe is becoming an increasingly prominent factor in the Microsoft growth story as gaming becomes more mainstream, management works to convert its gaming revenue from one-time license purchase to a recurring subscription model and as technologies like augmented/virtual reality evolve. Finally, as it relates to LinkedIn and other subscription-based services such as O365 and various Dynamics products, we continue to value them highly for their recurring revenue streams, which we remind members, provides for greater transparency of future earnings. Target Price: Raised to $150; Rating: One


RISKS: Slowdown in IT spending, competition, cannibalization of on premises business by the cloud

Additionally, Bloomberg reported that Apple's subscription video service Apple TV+ is expected to roll out by November with an estimated cost of $9.99 per month. Additionally, the Financial Times this week that the company has committed $6 billion for original shows and movies ahead of the launch. While the figure is a sharp increase from the $1 billion committed in Apple's first year of original content, it's pales in comparison to the $15 billion that industry leader Netflix is expected to spend this year. Lastly, 9to5Mac reported that the upcoming Apple Arcade subscription gaming service will likely be priced at $4.99 per month. We view all three of these new and upcoming releases as supportive of our view that in the long run, a heftier Services offering will allow Apple to increase its recurring revenue stream and expand companywide margins. 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.87%; Yield: 1.52%


INVESTMENT THESIS: While we acknowledge that near- to- midterm performance remains heavily influenced by iPhone sales, we believe longer-term upside will come as Services revenue grows its share of overall sales. Services provide for a recurring revenue stream at higher margins, a factor that serves to reduce earnings volatility while allowing for a higher percentage of sales to fall to the bottom line, as a result, we believe that Services growth and the installed base, are much more important than how many devices the company can sell in a given 90-day period. In addition to improved profitability we also believe the transparent nature of this revenue stream will demand an expanded price-to-earnings multiple as segment sales grow. Furthermore, we believe that Apple's desire to push deeper into the healthcare arena will help make its devices invaluable as more life-changing features are added and the company works to democratize health records. Lastly, also see upside resulting from increased adoption of wearables (think the Apple Watch) and potential new product announcements such as an AR/VR headset or an update on project Titan, the company's secretive autonomous driving program. Target Price: Reiterate $260; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowdown in consumer spending, competition, lack of new product innovation, elongated replacement cycles, failure to execute on Services growth initiative


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , Interview , ,



Comcast $42.43; 1400 shares; 2.27%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE1: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.74%; Yield: 1.98%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see further upside resulting from progress on the integration of Sky plc, which will serve to increase the company's international presence while nearly doubling its customer base. Additionally, the acquisition provides Comcast access to Sky's "Q Box," which said to be even better than the X1 and provides a buffer should cord cutting accelerate in Europe. Recall, domestically, the X1 has been shown to be more resilient to the trend than competing platforms. Regarding the debt load on the balance sheet resulting from the acquisition, we reaffirm that management has an excellent M&A track record and believe strong cash flow generation will provide the means to successfully de-leverage overtime, allowing shares to re-rate higher over time. Lastly, regarding the US business, we believe management's decision to focus operations around broadband is continuing to be rewarded with higher margins and providing a greater ability to bundle cheaper, less in demand services such as video. Target Price: Reiterate $56; Rating: Two


RISKS: An acceleration of cord cutting, failure to realize targeted Sky integration synergies, 5G impacting broadband business, competition


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , ,



Disney $131.67; 775 shares; 3.9%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, The Verge that Disney+, the company's upcoming subscription streaming services will be available on the following platforms: Apple TV (tvOS), Android mobile devices, Android TV, Chromecast, Desktop web browsers, iPad (iPadOS), iPhone (iOS), PlayStation 4, Roku streaming players, Roku TV and the Xbox One. Notably, as the article points out, "Amazon's Fire TV lineup is the glaring omission from this list - at least for now." 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.61%; Yield: 1.34%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Disney's direct to consumer efforts via ESPN+ and Disney+ and are happy to ride out the associated investment cycle. Additionally, we view the integration of Fox assets as another catalyst as progress is made given the acquisition brings with it programming across six continents, reaching over 1.8 billion consumers that speak roughly 50 different languages, as well as the rights to Start India, India being one of the fastest growing countries in the world and all of the domestic content, plus an additional 30% ownership of Hulu, bringing their total Hulu ownership to 60%.Furthermore, we are bullish on the Studio Entertainment division's 2019 movie lineup, which features a new Avengers, Toy Story 4, and live-action reboots of The Lion King and Aladdin, amongst other titles. Lastly, we believe a strong consumer should continue to support attendance and spending at Parks and Resorts. Target Price: Reiterate $150; Rating: Two


RISKS: Fox integration risk, competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting the consumer


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



DuPont $66; 391 shares; 0.99%; Sector: Chemicals


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.18%; Yield: 1.82%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe DuPont is undervalued relative to peers, and its separation into a single entity will help unlock that value difference. The company's portfolio consists of market-leading growth in Electronics & Imaging, Nutrition & Biosciences, Safety & Construction, and Transporation & Advanced Polymers. Lastly, we appreciate the significant amount of portfolio optionality that is present. Within the company, management created a Non-Core segment which comprises about 10% of the entire portfolio had is expected to do about $2 billion in sales during FY 2019. The main goal of these assets is for divestitures, which management plans to execute on through the year and the proceeds of which will be used for bolt-on M&A and/or share buybacks.


Target Price: Reiterate $80; Rating: Two


RISKS: Ongoing challenges in its three largest businesses: Automotive (15% of net sales), Smartphone (5% of net sales) and North American Residential Construction (4% of net sales); Softening demand due to tariffs,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , Investor Relations



Facebook $177.75; 375 shares; 2.55%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -3.24%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Facebook is the leading social media company. It monetizes its platforms and delivers targeted advertisements across all major demographics at a high ROI. Although revenue is expected to decelerate as the company transitions its monetization emphasis to Instagram Stories from Facebook's NewsFeed, and there are additional risks to margins related to increased OpEx spending, we believe both processes have become well understood by investors at this point. Plus, we think future growth opportunities exist through increased monetization of the WhatsApp and Messenger verticals. While critics claim the member base has become disengaged, Facebook's first quarter results showed trends have held with daily active users (DAUs) of 1.56 billion and monthly active users (MAUs) of 2.375 billion. Lastly, we believe the stock's current price to earnings multiple is cheap relative to the company's growth and competitive moat. Target Price: Reiterate $225; Rating: Two


RISKS: Regulation, weak engagement on core platform, capital spending, margin pressure, monetization strategy of WhatsApp and Messenger


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , ,



Goldman Sachs $196.2; 450 shares; 3.37%; Sector: Financials


WEEKLY UPDATE: May look to upgrade our rating to a ONE soon because the stock price has fallen well below the firm's second quarter 2019 tangible book value per share price of $203.05 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.61%; Yield: 2.55%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Goldman Sachs is a strong performing investment bank, and the firm is currently ahead of its goal to generate an additional $5 billion in annual revenue by 2020. Meanwhile, the firm has delivered consistent improvements to its return on equity and return on tangible common equity metrics-which are drivers of a premium over book price-while tangible book value has continued to grow. Another reason why we think the share price deserves a greater premium is because of management's emphasis on fee-based, or more recurring, revenue streams. At the end of 2018, 61% of Goldman's revenues were fee-based, up from 48% in 2013. Target Price: Reiterate $270; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, 1MDB litigation, interest rates, financial market activity


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , ,



Home Depot $217.47; 225 shares; 1.87%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . 1-Wk. Price Change: 6.79%; Yield: 2.50%


INVESTMENT THESIS: The unquestioned leader in home improvement supplies, we like Home Depot for its consistent same-store sales performance, ability to gain market share and improve margins, and its business model that is relatively immune from Amazon-like pressures. We initiated our position shortly before the Spring--Home Depot's "Holiday season" --expecting the company to outperform expectations. Longer term, management's 2020 financial targets include sales to increase to the range of $115 billion to $120 billion, with operating margins in a range of 14.4% to 15% and return on invested capital of more than 40%. Lastly, Home Depot is a cash-generating machine. Making good use of its cash flows, the company recently authorized a 32% increase to its quarterly dividend (which puts the yield ~3.0%) as well as announced a $15 billion share repurchase program. Target Price: to $230; Rating: Two


RISKS: Consumer Spending habits; Housing market downturn; inclement weather


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , Investor Relations



Honeywell $156.49; 350 shares; 2.09%; Sector: Industrials


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -5.17%; Yield: 2.10%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Following a 2018 year when the company spun off two businesses, we believe the new Honeywell is worthy of a premium to its peer group as it has become less cyclical and more focused with stronger organic sales growth trends. The two segments we remain most positive on for their long-term growth profiles are Aerospace and Safety and Productivity Solution, as both stand to benefit from strong secular trends. Additionally, we appreciate management's ability to drive operational improvements in areas such as margin and free cash flow. Lastly, the balance sheet is clean has plenty of optionality, keeping the door open for accretive M&A and/or share buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $175; Rating: Two


RISKS: A slowdown in the aerospace market, a deterioration in commodity prices that affect businesses within PMT segment, trade war/tariffs exposure.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , Investor Relations



Kohl's $45.18; 1300 shares; 2.24%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . As a result of the quarterly report, which missed expectations for same-store sales and as a result causes us to maintain our view that this is a "show me" story, we are reducing our price target to $56 per share, representing ~10.5x 2020 consensus earnings expectations of $5.31 per share. 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.73%; Yield: 5.93%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We like Kohl's position in the department store industry. Its brands are tailored to middle-income buyers who shop for value, or good deals, while their store locations remain away from the mall which has been subject to decline in foot traffic. The company is run by a strategic management team who has several strong initiatives in place (standard-to-small initiatives, partnership with Planet Fitness, Fanatics, of course Amazon and more) that drive traffic and improve inventory management. Additionally, Kohl's continues to be a large beneficiary of peer closings (like Bon-Ton), resulting in increased market share. Target Price: Reduced to $56; Rating: Two


RISKS: A decline in consumer spending, shifts in consumer fashion preferences, margin pressure related to increased competition, weather impacting consumer shopping habits, tariffs,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Lam Research $200.39; 350 shares; 2.68%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.30%; Yield: 2.20%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: Two


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Shopify $382.75; 45 shares; 0.66%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Discussed on Friday's Daily Rundown Video how we may lock in our massive gains in the position soon. 1-Wk. Price Change: 6.69%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Shopify is a leading cloud-based, multichannel commerce platform that helps businesses of all size compete on the internet. Its platform acts as a "retail operating system" for businesses and provides tools that assist in areas such digital marketing, payments and shipping. Instead of putting goods directly on an e-commerce marketplace, Shopify helps businesses build their own websites and online presence, allowing them to connect directly with their audience. Additionally, part of the Shopify value proposition relates to its benefit of scale which allows the company to negotiate online payment rates and shipping rates on their customer's behalf. Shopify also empowers small businesses and helps merchants thrive through the merchant funding and by offering cash advances. Lastly, international expansion represents a key area of opportunity for Shopify. Target Price: Reiterate $350; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowing net merchant additions, customer churn, competition, weak execution international expansion


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , ,



THREES


Palo Alto Networks $201.57; 175 shares; 1.35%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, despite our Three rating, we made a small purchase because we believe the recent selloff on the that Dave Peranich, one of Palo Alto's top sales executives, has stepped down from the company has been an overreaction. Even though we added to our position, we are not changing our Three rating as our stance on the upcoming quarter has not changed. That said, as noted in our our thinking at the time of the trade was that we now have a stock that is too cheap to sell and its sharp, overreacted selloff has created an interesting opportunity for a trade. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.15%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe cyber security to be a secular growth trend that will continue to be a priority for cooperate investments globally in coming years. We value Palo Alto above others because, while firewall spend will continue to be a key factor supporting sales and earnings in the near- to- mid-term, we believe CEO Nikesh Arora's intense focus on cloud security will provide for longer relevance and industry dominance. Target Price: Reiterate $270; Rating: Three


RISKS: Slowing global growth - particularly in the US, where PANW does the bulk of its business - leading to less than expected corporate cyber security investments, competition, cloud providers moving into the cloud security space, billings visibility

urn:contentItem:5WFP-34X1-F00X-J354-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-06-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Markets are treading water as investors ponder the G-20, politics and stress tests.

Markets are treading water just under all-time highs as we head into the weekend with day one of G-20 2019 behind us and still no trade deal or developments to speak of. As members know, we believe the trade negotiations to be the primary focus of the market as any positive development can serve to reinvigorate business confidence and potentially cause an uptick in U.S. manufacturing activity and business investments and as a result, keep the expansion going. On the other hand, we believe a breakdown in negotiations would prove highly detrimental as the U.S. and global economy in general are already showing signs of a slowdown and any further tariffs or added friction in the supply chain via sanctions (such as those on Huawei) would certainly see a further reduction in business confidence and slowdown in growth.

While G-20 is our current focus, it isn't the only event the markets had to contend with this week as Wednesday and Thursday evening saw campaign season kick off with the first of the Democratic debates. Though it's still too early to speculate as to whom the Democratic front runner will be, we'll be watchful of how polling progresses and what platform with respect to U.S. healthcare system, tax reform, student debt and more they run on. While we do our best to avoid being political, we will of course continue to monitor the political sphere for new developments as, the closer we get to the 2020 election, the more the risk landscape facing our holdings will shift.

Lastly, outside of the political spectrum, after the close on Thursday, the Federal Reserve announced the second stage of its annual stress tests on the country's 18 largest banks.

The 10-Year Treasury yield dipped yet hovered right above the ~2.0% level while gold prices pushed through the ~$1,400 per ounce level. The U.S. dollar index remains in the 96-97 range while WTI oil prices went into the weekend pressed up against the $60 per barrel level.

First-quarter earnings season has come to a close. No portfolio companies reported this week.


Economy

On Tuesday, shortly after the opening bell, the U.S. Census Bureau reported that new home sales in May declined 7.8% month over month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 626,000. The reading missed expectations for an increase to 683,750, however, was slightly offset by an upward revision to April's estimates, which was revised up to 679,000 (from 673,000). With the May reading, on a year-over-year basis, sales are down 3.7% from May's 2018's estimate of 650,000. As for costs, the average selling price in May decreased to $377,200 (from $386,500 in April). The median sales price also moved lower, decreasing to $308,000 (from $335,100 in April). See for our full analysis.

On Wednesday, the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured durable goods fell 1.3% in May to $243.4 billion, following a 2.8% decline in April (revised down from -2.1% previously reported). The reading missed expectations for a 0.2% decline. With the monthly advance, new orders for durable goods are up 1.0% from the same time last year. Shipments for manufactured durable goods increased 0.4% to $254.1 billion in May, following a 1.6% decrease in April. Driving the move was a 1.1% increase in shipments of machinery. Unfilled orders fell in May, declining 0.5% to $1.1712 trillion, following a 0.2% decline in April and were led by a 0.7% pullback in unfilled orders of transportation equipment. Finally, inventories bumped up 0.5% in May to $424.6 billion, following a 0.4% advance in April led by a 1.6% increase in transportation equipment. With April's readings, shipments are up 3.9%, unfilled orders increased 5.0%, and total inventories have grown by 0.8% from the same time last year.

New orders for non-defense capital goods, excluding aircraft (i.e., core capital goods) increased 0.4% in May, quadrupling expectations of a 0.1% monthly increase. This followed a 0.3% advance in March and a 1.0% decline in April. Shipments of core capital goods, popped 0.7% last month, outpacing expectations for a 0.1% increase. With the monthly readings, new orders for core capital goods are up 2.3% from the same time last year while shipments are up 3.8% annually. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday morning before the opening bell, The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) reported in its third reading (based on a more complete set of data than the second reading released last month on May 30) that real Gross Domestic Product -- GDP adjusted for inflation, our best gauge for economic growth -- increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.1% in the first quarter of 2019. That figure was a tick short of expectations for a 3.2% increase, but was in line with the 3.1% rate seen in the second reading. This latest reading follows readings of 2.2% and 3.4% annual rates of growth in the fourth and third quarters of 2018, respectively.

In addition to real GDP, we want to note that the core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, which takes out food and energy to reduce month-to-month volatility, rose 1.7% from the same time last year (first quarter of 2018). It was a deceleration from the 1.9% annual rate of increase seen in the fourth quarter of 2018 but up from 1.6% in the BEA's second estimate. On a quarter-over-quarter basis, the core PCE price index is up 1.2%, also a deceleration from the fourth quarter's 1.8% quarterly advance but up from 1.0% in the BEA's second reading. See for our full analysis.

Also, on Thursday, The National Association of Realtors reported that its Pending Home Sales Index rebounded 1.1% in May to 105.4, a tick above expectations for a 10.% monthly advance and coming on the heels of a 1.5% decline in April. Recall that pending home sales represent contracts signed for existing home sales set to close in the next one to two months. With May's reading, pending home sales are down 0.7%, year over year, missing expectations for a 0.4% annual uptick and marking the 17th straight month of year-over-year declines. See for our full analysis.

Lastly on Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending June 22 were 227,000, a 10,000-claim increase from the previous week's revised level of 217,000 (revised up from 216,000) and 7,000 claims above expectations for a 220,000-claim reading. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 221,250, an increase of 2,250 from the previous week's revised average of 219,000 (revised up from 218,750). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 225 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

Finally, on Friday, the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) released personal income and spending numbers for May. Personal income rose 0.5% (or $88.6 billion), exceeding expectations for a 0.3% advance and coming on the heels of 0.5% increase in April. Personal disposable income - the income available for spending or saving after taxes - also rose 0.5% (or $72.6 billion) in May, following a similar advance in April.

Personal consumption expenditures (PCE) increased 0.4% (or $59.7 billion) in May, coming up short versus a 0.5% consensus following a 0.6% increase in April. When adjusted for inflation, real PCE increased 0.2% (or $32.9 billion) monthly, in line with expectations for an unchanged reading, following a similar gain in April.

Notably, the PCE price index ticked up 0.2% in May, following a 0.3% advance in April. The Core PCE price index (which takes out food and energy to reduce month-to-month volatility) rose 0.2% in May following a similar advance in April. More importantly, on a year-over-year basis, the core index was up 1.6% in May, coming off the heels of a similar advance in April. See for our full analysis.


Key Global Economic Readings

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)


Oil

On the commodity front, oil prices pressed higher this week aided by supply side dynamics including the Philadelphia refinery explosion last week and a significant inventory drawdown in the U.S. as well as ongoing tensions abroad including in the Middle East and Venezuela. On the demand side, hopes for a are also aiding prices, the thinking being that a deal can reinvigorate global growth and energy demand as a result.

While the factors noted above should help support prices, we would also call out that working against these factors are the near record high (and likely increasing) production levels in the U.S., elevated production in Russia and as to whether OPEC+ will maintain production cuts into the end of the year -- though are that the production cut agreement will ultimately be extended.

For those of our members who are bit perplexed as to why prices have not been even more volatile given all the crosswinds impacting the market, CNBC put together a quick 60 second discussing the dynamics we speak to weekly including record U.S. production, international production, OPEC+ and fears of a global slowdown that we believe may help some get a quick overview of the ongoing undercurrents in the oil market.

On the domestic front, on Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), reported that in the week ending June 21, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) fell by 12.8 million barrels to 469.6 million barrels, a bullish reading versus expectations for a 2.54 million barrel drawdown. Additionally, U.S. production pulled back slightly, decreasing by 100,000 bpd to 12.1 million bpd. Lastly, net imports declined by 1.16 million bpd as imports decreased by 812,000 bpd, while exports increased by 348,000 bpd. See for the full report and for more of our thoughts on the report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at roughly $6 per barrel. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive U.S. based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we bulked up on positions in Kohl's ( ) and Mastercard ( ), while trimming our stakes in Amazon and Shopify ( ), Facebook and Johnson & Johnsons ( ), and Apple ( ).

Moving on to the broader market, first-quarter earnings season has come to an end and the results were relatively positive versus beaten down expectations coming into the season, with 75.9% of companies reporting a positive EPS surprise. For the first-quarter, earnings growth increased roughly 0.9% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 0.72% advance throughout the season; of the 430 non-financials that reported, earnings growth was up 0.6%. Revenues were up 3.4% vs. expectations throughout the season for a 3.48% increase; 75.9% of companies beat EPS expectations, 18.1% missed the mark and 6.0% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 67.07% beat the prior year's EPS results, 30.72% came up short and 2.21% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Information Tech, Communication Services and Healthcare while the worst performing have been Real Estate, Energy and Utilities.

Next week, no companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. No portfolio companies will be reporting.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: Acuity Brands AYI, Greenbrier GBX, Omnova Solutions OMN, Simply Good Foods SMPL and Int'l Speedway ISCA.

Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated over $2.46 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.

Cisco Systems ; $54.73; 1200 shares; 2.42%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: While there was little in terms of company-specific updates this week, analysts at Cowen reiterated the name as their "Best Idea," calling out, in line with our own view, the resiliency of earnings resulting from the shift to recurring software revenues, and improving competitive position the growing strategic importance of the network. 1-Wk. Price Change: -4.03%; Yield: 2.56%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from an improved earnings profile as the company transitions from lumpier hardware sales, toward a recurring software and security revenue stream. We also believe the reduction in DRAM prices, a major input cost for the company, is proving to be a near- to- mid-term tailwind. Lastly, we believe the transformation along with corporate initiatives to adopt the cloud will keep earnings resilient in the face of any broader macroeconomic slowdown. Target Price: Reiterate $62; Rating: ONE


RISKS: A rebound in DRAM prices placing pressure on margins, a decline in corporate IT spending, competition, execution risk related to the shift toward software and security

Salesforce ; $151.73; 775 shares; 4.33%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, analysts at KeyBanc reiterated their Overweight rating calling out their positive view of the Tableau acquisition and noting their estimate that "Tableau's revenue could triple to $3B+ while contributing $1B+ in operating cash flow by CY23." Contributing to their positive view is the simple fact that enterprises are in the process of replacing legacy systems, which "opens up a $41B data modernization opportunity where >90% of the spend is invested in systems designed 20+ years ago." As a reminder, the ability to help enterprise clients access data trapped in legacy systems was the key reason we were so enthused about the prior acquisition of MuleSoft, despites some calls that Salesforce had overpaid. Bottom line, despite the recent pressure on shares, we believe the Tableau acquisition will ultimately prove a win for Salesforce longer-term. 1-Wk. Price Change: -3.26%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We are bullish on shares of CRM as we view Salesforce as a key player in the "digital revolution" and invaluable to those companies looking to build out their digital strategy and better understand their customer base. Furthermore, we believe the acquisition of MuleSoft effectively expanded the company's total addressable market by unlocking data previously trapped on legacy systems, to be used on the Salesforce platform. These factors compounded by a strong management team keep us confident that the company remains on track to reach its FY2022 target of $21 billion to $23 billion in revenue. Target Price: Reiterate $170; Rating: One


RISKS: Slowdown in IT spending, competition

Dow Inc. ; $49.31; 458 shares; 0.83%; Sector: Chemicals


WEEKLY UPDATE: RBC Capital slightly reduced its Dow Inc. price target to $62 from $66 citing weakness in polyurethanes and siloxanes. Although the uncertain macro continues to weigh on Dow Inc. and the prices of its good, we continue to believe the hefty dividend yield provides more than adequate compensation for upcycle patience. 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.96%; Yield: 5.68%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We appreciate the transformation that has occurred at Dow Inc following its merger and separation. Dow Inc has streamlined its operations and now sells into six different businesses in three market verticals: Performance Materials and Coating; Industrial Intermediates and Infrastructure; and Packaging and Specialty Products. Capital discipline is of greater importance at the company, with management favoring brownfield projects over greenfield and focusing on incremental, high-return on invested capital projects. This strategy allows management to offer a significant capital return policy and target a peer leading dividend payout ratio of approximately 45% across the cycle. From its first day post-separation, Dow Inc was the high yielding stock in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, and management has a program in place to repurchase $3 billion worth of stock. Target Price: Reiterate $62; Rating: One


RISKS: Macroeconomic slowdown, margin compression due to commodity prices, competition

Alphabet ; $1,082.80; 70 shares; 2.79%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: As members know, one of the reasons we think so highly of Alphabet is the company's willingness to take chances on new initiatives via the "X Moonshot Factory" This week, Google Cloud CEO, Thomas Kurian that another project born in the X moonshot factory, " " will be making its way to the Google Cloud. Per the announcement, "this union will create a powerful and comprehensive security portfolio that will benefit all of our customers." We welcome the news as we view security advancements as key to Alphabet's ability to entice potential customers to adopt the company's cloud solution, which is well-known to be lagging the likes of Microsoft's Azure and Amazon's AWS. 1-Wk. Price Change: -3.78%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe that while Search and digital ad dominance is what will carry shares in the near- to- midterm, longer-term it is the company's artificial intelligence (AI) "moat" that will provide for new avenues of growth. AI is what has made the company's Search, Video (YouTube) and targeted ad capabilities best-in-class and is the driving force behind the company's success in voice (Google Home) and autonomous driving (Waymo). Furthermore, we believe it is this AI expertise that will also make the company more prevalent in other industries, including healthcare via subsidiary Verily, as AI and machine learning continue to disrupt operations across industries. We believe Alphabet's willingness to invest in new areas, knowing most will fail, is a recipe for long-term success as while most " " projects may fail, every once in a while, you end up with a Waymo, perhaps the division's, most successful graduate to date. Lastly, compounding out positive view of the company's future opportunities, we believe that Alphabet's free cash flow generation and solid balance sheet set it apart and are what will allow the company to continue taking chances on far-out ground-breaking and potentially world changing projects. Target Price: Reiterate $1,400; Rating: One


RISKS: Regulatory risk (data privacy), competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting consumers and therefore ad buyer activity

Longer term, management's 2020 financial targets include sales to increase to the range of $115 billion to $120 billion, with operating margins in a range of 14.4% to 15% and return on invested capital of more than 40%. Lastly, Home Depot is a cash-generating machine. Making good use of its cash flows, the company recently authorized a 32% increase to its quarterly dividend (which puts the yield ~3.0%) as well as announced a $15 billion share repurchase program. Lam Research ; $187.84; 375 shares; 2.60%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Though there was little in terms of company specific news, shares saw support on the back of the Micron earnings conference call (which took place on Tuesday after the close). Though Micron did note that it may need to reduce capex in the near-term in order to bring supply back in line with demand (a negative for Lam Research as Micron capex is essential Lam Research's revenue), management helped in that investors were given more clarity into the timing of when the supply and demand would be back in balance -- recall, the market can adjust to good news or bad news, it's uncertainty that causes the greatest deal of volatility. As called out on our , when this balance is achieved and demand growth once again begins to outplace supply growth, we believe capex will ramp back up as memory prices inflect and our patience in LRCX (which we are being compensated for thanks to the stock's ~2.5% dividend yield) will be rewarded. As a reminder, despite the historically cyclical nature of semiconductors we believe demand is becoming more secular as it is driven by trends such as 5G, autonomous driving, AI and more. 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.63%; Yield: 2.34%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, we believe that thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature and as a result, we believe that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in out initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which lead to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: One


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.

Mastercard ; $264.53; 175 shares; 1.71%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, despite being above basis, we opted to bulk up on our position in MasterCard. The stock has seen strong support around the $260 level and we believe our initial position was small enough that a small violation of cost basis discipline was warranted given our view that the name represents a tremendous play on the secular movement from cash to card and contactless payments methods, which are becoming an increasingly pervasive part of today's society. Additionally, we believe the visibility behind this theme provides a sense of durability to long-term sales and earnings growth. Lastly, as noted in our trade , "when we think longer term for new ways Mastercard can deliver growth, the company is still scratching the surfacing in terms of a massive business to business (B2B) opportunity." 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.02%; Yield: 0.50%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from the secular shift toward digital payments and a growing "network effect" as acceptance rates of digital payments increase among merchants. In line with this view, we also believe the shift to ecommerce to be a tailwind as online purchases inherently require some form of digital payments. In the near-term we also expect a tailwind to result from the coming release of the Apple Card as MasterCard was selected as the card's payment processing platform. Furthermore, we value MasterCard for the strong three-year Performance Objectives management laid out on their fourth quarter 2018 and full year 2018 financial results conference call. For 2019 - 2021, on a currency-neutral basis, excluding future acquisitions and Special Items, management's goal is for low-teen Net Revenue CAGR (compound annual growth rate), a minimum 50% Annual Operating Margin, and high-teens percent earnings per share CAGR. Lastly, the company also has a hefty share repurchase program in place. In December 2018, the company announced a new share repurchase program worth $4 billion, which went on top of an existing program. As of April 25th, the company had $4.5 billion remaining under current repurchase program authorizations. Target Price: Reiterate $280; Rating: One


RISKS: Slowdown in consumer spending and a prolonged shift toward digital payment mediums
