Apple ; $197.92; 400 shares; 2.92%; Sector: Technology


WEEKLY UPDATE: While we continue to view AAPL as an "own, don't trade name" we opted to trim shares this week we believe that being long-term owners still means we must take our gains when stocks rally, especially when the run comes ahead of an event that can materially impact upcoming quarterly earnings, that event in this case being the G-20 summits where Trump and Xi are set to meet for further trade negotiations. As noted in our , "even though Apple is the poster child of American corporate success, the company is still firmly in the cross hairs of tariffs and we think it is fair game for both sides in terms of leverage. Essentially, we think the Trump Administration has little interest in shielding Apple from new tariffs because they want those jobs to come back to the United States, and we also wouldn't put it past President Xi to take action against Apple as a reciprocating measure for the United States' actions against Huawei." Also this week, Apple it acquisition of Drive.ai, while CNCB that the company is continuing its push into healthcare as "some Apple retail locations now sell a glucose monitor that integrates with the iPhone to give people with diabetes a way to track their blood sugar through Apple's Health app." 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.43%; Yield: 1.56%


INVESTMENT THESIS: While we acknowledge that near- to- midterm performance remains heavily influenced by iPhone sales, we believe longer-term upside will come as Services revenue grows its share of overall sales. Services provide for a recurring revenue stream at higher margins, a factor that serves to reduce earnings volatility while allowing for a higher percentage of sales to fall to the bottom line, as a result, we believe that Services growth and the installed base, are much more important than how many devices the company can sell in a given 90-day period. In addition to improved profitability we also believe the transparent nature of this revenue stream will demand an expanded price-to-earnings multiple as segment sales grow. Furthermore, we believe that Apple's desire to push deeper into the healthcare arena will help make its devices invaluable as more life-changing features are added and the company works to democratize health records. Lastly, also see upside resulting from increased adoption of wearables (think the Apple Watch) and potential new product announcements such as an AR/VR headset or an update on project Titan, the company's secretive autonomous driving program. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowdown in consumer spending, competition, lack of new product innovation, elongated replacement cycles, failure to execute on Services growth initiative


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , Interview , ,



Abbott Laboratories ; $84.10; 600 shares; 1.86%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: Credit Suisse analysts went on a Chicago Bus Trip, held meetings with Abbott management, and published a note about their takeaways which include "continuing ability" to deliver 6.5% to 7.5% organic sales with double-digit growth on the bottom line. Credit Suisse mentioned that the U.S. Alinity launch (one of the three key upcoming growth drivers for the company) is 12 to 18 months out "from swinging into full force." On the Libre (another key growth driver), Credit Suisse mentioned Abbott's plans to expand manufacturing capacity. The Libre 2 is still under FDA review. -Wk. Price Change: -1.06%; Yield: 1.52%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Strong underlying performance with an achievable (and beatable) 2019 organic sales growth expectation in the 6.5% to 7.5% range. The company boasts high performing franchises in Medical Devices (with strong growth in Diabetes Care) and Diagnostics (with strong gains in Core Laboratory), while Nutrition and Established Pharmaceutical remain strategic parts of its total portfolio. We believe the company's opportunities for upside rest with additional Libre uptake, the Alinity U.S. launch, and an expanded indication of the Mitraclip. We believe in CEO Miles White and the Abbott management team, who has a strong track record of integrating acquisitions and delivering double-digit earnings per share growth. Lastly, Abbott has plenty of financial flexibility to pursue mergers/acquisitions and other strategic actions. Target Price: Reiterate $82; Rating: Two


RISKS: Emerging market exposure, Product disruptions.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , (1/23/19), , ,



BP PLC ; $41.70; 2,200 shares; 3.38%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.77% Yield: 5.90%


INVESTMENT THESIS: In addition to higher oil prices aiding the sector, we believe BP shares will see further upside thanks to management's visible trajectory toward a stated 900,000-barrel-per-day production target by 2021, a target reiterated during the companies fourth-quarter earnings conference call, and an improving cash flow profile as Macondo related payments (expected to be ~$2 billion in 2019 and ~$1 billion in 2020) wind down and the company works to reduce breakeven prices for organic free cash flow from $50 per barrel currently toward the $35 to $40 range by 2021. The cash flow dynamic also gives us increased confidence in BPs ability to maintain its dividend payout, a key factor supporting shares against any downturns in commodity prices and a crucial consideration for our income-oriented members. Target Price: Reiterate $54; Rating: Two


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, Macondo liability coming in above expectations


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (12/10/18), ,



Citigroup ; $70.03; 1,150 shares; 2.97%; Sector: Financials


WEEKLY UPDATE: On the back of a successful completion of the Fed's , Citigroup modestly increased its quarterly dividend payment to $0.51 from $0.45 (a 13% increase) while announcing a new $17.5 billion share repurchase program over the next four quarters. 1-Wk. Price Change: 3.03%; Yield: 2.57%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from an expanded price-to-tangible book valuation as management executes on its turnaround initiative and believe improving return on tangible common equity performance will ultimately lead to a higher book price and multiple expansion. Furthermore, the bank's over-capitalized balance sheet provides significant room for capital return to shareholders, providing a level of support and making for an attractive risk/reward profile. Target Price: $80; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System Regulation, interest rates, emerging markets, credit quality


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , ,



Comcast ; $42.28; 2,100 shares; 3.27%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, we were once again reminded of why Netflix has been the one "FANG" stock we do not hold in the portfolio as came in that Comcast will pull "The Office" from the Netflix platform in 2021 and include it on its own, yet to be released streaming service. While some members may be wondering, why this matters seeing as the show is years old at this point, we would call out that it was the most watched show on the Netflix platform in 2018 and continues the trend of content producers such as Comcast and Disney ending license agreements in an effort to increase the attractiveness of their own streaming offers. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.94%; Yield: 1.99%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see further upside resulting from progress on the integration of Sky plc, which will serve to increase the company's international presence while nearly doubling its customer base. Additionally, the acquisition provides Comcast access to Sky's "Q Box," which said to be even better than the X1 and provides a buffer should cord cutting accelerate in Europe. Recall, domestically, the X1 has been shown to be more resilient to the trend than competing platforms. Regarding the debt load on the balance sheet resulting from the acquisition, we reaffirm that management has an excellent M&A track record and believe strong cash flow generation will provide the means to successfully de-leverage overtime, allowing shares to re-rate higher over time. Lastly, regarding the U.S. business, we believe management's decision to focus operations around broadband is continuing to be rewarded with higher margins and providing a greater ability to bundle cheaper, less in demand services such as video. Target Price: Reiterate $48; Rating: Two


RISKS: An acceleration of cord cutting, failure to realize targeted Sky integration synergies, 5G impacting broadband business, competition


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , ,



Disney ; $139.64; 875 shares; 4.5%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: In addition to Comcast deciding to pull "The Office" from Netflix in 2021, we this week that Disney+ has lured Netflix's Director Of Original Film, Matt Brodlie away from Netflix to serve as Senior Vice President of International Content Development for the Disney+ platform. We provided a few thoughts on the move in our Alert . 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.42%; Yield: 1.26%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Disney's direct to consumer efforts via ESPN+ and Disney+ and are happy to ride out the associated investment cycle. Additionally, we view the integration of Fox assets as another catalyst as progress is made given the acquisition brings with it programming across six continents, reaching over 1.8 billion consumers that speak roughly 50 different languages, as well as the rights to Start India, India being one of the fastest growing countries in the world and all of the domestic content, plus an additional 30% ownership of Hulu, bringing their total Hulu ownership to 60%.Furthermore, we are bullish on the Studio Entertainment division's 2019 movie lineup, which features a new Avengers, Toy Story 4, and live-action reboots of The Lion King and Aladdin, amongst other titles. Lastly, we believe a strong consumer should continue to support attendance and spending at Parks and Resorts. Target Price: Reiterate $150; Rating: Two


RISKS: Fox integration risk, competition, macroeconomic slowdown impacting the consumer


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , , , , ,



DuPont ; $75.07; 391 shares; 1.08%; Sector: Chemicals


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.58%; Yield: 1.60%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe DuPont is undervalued relative to peers, and its separation into a single entity will help unlock that value difference. The company's portfolio consists of market-leading growth in Electronics & Imaging, Nutrition & Biosciences, Safety & Construction, and Transporation & Advanced Polymers. Lastly, we appreciate the significant amount of portfolio optionality that is present. Within the company, management created a Non-Core segment which comprises about 10% of the entire portfolio had is expected to do about $2 billion in sales during FY 2019. The main goal of these assets is for divestitures, which management plans to execute on through the year and the proceeds of which will be used for bolt-on M&A and/or share buybacks.


Target Price: Reiterate $80; Rating: Two


RISKS: Ongoing challenges in its three largest businesses: Automotive (15% of net sales), Smartphone (5% of net sales) and North American Residential Construction (4% of net sales); Softening demand due to tariffs,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , Investor Relations



Facebook ; $193.00; 375 shares; 2.67%; Sector: Communication Services


WEEKLY UPDATE: While we remain bullish on the company (and stock) longer-term and believe the introduction of can certainly aid Facebook in building out its ecommerce revenue stream, we opted to ahead of the political debates in order to hedge against headline risk (it's no secret that politicians on both sides of the aisle have called for increased scrutiny of big tech and potential the breakup of some companies) and the potential that too much good news has been priced in too quickly following the Libra announcement. 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.97%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Facebook is the leading social media company. It monetizes its platforms and delivers targeted advertisements across all major demographics at a high ROI. Although revenue is expected to decelerate as the company transitions its monetization emphasis to Instagram Stories from Facebook's NewsFeed, and there are additional risks to margins related to increased OpEx spending, we believe both processes have become well understood by investors at this point. Plus, we think future growth opportunities exist through increased monetization of the WhatsApp and Messenger verticals. While critics claim the member base has become disengaged, Facebook's first quarter results showed trends have held with daily active users (DAUs) of 1.56 billion and monthly active users (MAUs) of 2.375 billion. Lastly, we believe the stock's current price to earnings multiple is cheap relative to the company's growth and competitive moat. Target Price: Reiterate $225; Rating: Two


RISKS: Regulation, weak engagement on core platform, capital spending, margin pressure, monetization strategy of WhatsApp and Messenger


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , ,



Five Below Inc ; $193.00; 150 shares; 0.66 %; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: We addressed this week's declines in our Daily Rundown video . When asked if this stock should be upgraded back to a ONE off the pullback, we suggested patience due to the risk of additional tariffs post G-20. 1-Wk. Price Change: -8.58%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: This is a regional to national story that we believe will sustain momentum as organic growth, thanks to management's ability to recoup its initial investment in new stores in 8 months on average, is largely based on new store openings, something fully in management's control. Additionally, we value Five Below for its entirely domestic revenue stream, which insulates it from global trade dynamics and any slowing of global growth. And while tariffs may pressure the supply chain, should they increase, we believe management is already taking steps to mitigate any potential margin pressure. Lastly, while an economic slowdown could impact all retailers, we believe that Five Below's focus on less expensive products will allow it to be resilient as shoppers will naturally look for discounts when funds run low, making Five Below stores all the more attractive in such an environment. Target Price: Reiterate $135; Rating: Two


RISKS: Economic slowdown leading to less consumer spending, competition, lack of innovative product mix


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , Investor Relations



Honeywell ; $174.59; 650 shares; 4.18%; Sector: Industrials


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.16%; Yield: 1.88%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Following a 2018 year when the company spun off two businesses, we believe the new Honeywell is worthy of a premium to its peer group as it has become less cyclical and more focused with stronger organic sales growth trends. The two segments we remain most positive on for their long-term growth profiles are Aerospace and Safety and Productivity Solution, as both stand to benefit from strong secular trends. Additionally, we appreciate management's ability to drive operational improvements in areas such as margin and free cash flow. Lastly, the balance sheet is clean has plenty of optionality, keeping the door open for accretive M&A and/or share buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $175; Rating: Two


RISKS: A slowdown in the aerospace market, a deterioration in commodity prices that affect businesses within PMT segment, trade war/tariffs exposure.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , , Investor Relations



Johnson & Johnson ; $139.28; 475 shares; 2.44%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: Though we remain longer-term bullish on shares thanks to the company's faster-than-industry growing Pharmaceutical franchise, improving Medical Device business, non-economically sensitive consumer goods business, and pristine balance sheet, we opted to as shares have had strong run since our and risks related to the opioid and talc trials remain unsettled. 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.98%; Yield: 2.73%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view Johnson and Johnson as a consistent performer with durable franchises across the consumer and healthcare industry. Importantly, we expect the company's Pharmaceutical and Consumer business to grow above their respective industry growth rates, and even though Medical Devices has lagged, we have seen encouraging signs of improvements. Lastly, the company has one of the best balance sheets in the market, providing management with plenty of optionality for strategic M&A and/or buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $155; Rating: One


RISKS: Talc Litigation, Biosimilar and generic pressure, pipeline execution.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , Investor Relations



JPMorgan Chase & Co. ; $111.80; 800 shares; 3.30%; Sector: Financial


WEEKLY UPDATE: On the back of a successful completion of the Fed's , JP Morgan increased its per share quarterly dividend payment to $0.90 from $0.80 representing an increase of 12.5%. On the share repurchase side, the company announced a new program worth up to $29.4 billion over the next four quarters. Also this week, in line with management's focus on advancing the technological side of the banking business, Sky News that "JP Morgan is finalizing a deal that would see it becoming a sizeable minority shareholder in 10x Future Technologies, which develops the tech platforms underpinning digital banking operations." While not a game changer for a firm the size of JPMorgan, we view it as another step in the right direction (should it be confirmed in coming weeks) that will help ensure the bank maintains its competitive edge in an industry that is seeing more disruption than ever before. As noted in the article, ex-Barclays chief Antony Jenkins "set up 10x in 2016, backed by a belief that most traditional banking infrastructure was being rendered obsolete by advances in technology and changing customer behaviour." 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.16%; Yield: 2.86%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view JPMorgan as the best of breed large cap financial. The firm consistently delivers the best return on equity/tangible common equity performance in the industry, making the stock well deserving of a premium to its growing tangible book value. Not only that, but the Fortress balance sheet provides a degree of insulation to the risks associated with an economic shock. Lastly, we believe the valuation is very reasonable, especially considering the roughly 3% dividend yield and big buyback. Target Price: Reiterate $130; Rating: Two


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, interest rates, credit quality.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , (1/15/19), ,



Microsoft Corp ; $133.96; 550 shares; 2.72%; Sector: Technology


WEEKLY UPDATE: Long time Microsoft Bear John DiFucci of Jefferies raised his price target to $90 but remained steadfast in his view that Microsoft is overvalued and Azure "will likely never see margins similar to AWS at scale, and the long-term margin of even AWS may be lower than most expect." We always welcome and appreciate the contrarian view, but this call has been too wrong for too long 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.31%; Yield: 1.37%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe the cloud to be a secular growth trend and that upside to shares will result from Microsoft's hybrid cloud leadership as the company grab's market in this expanding industry. While companies may look to build out multi-cloud environments, Microsoft's Azure offering will be a prime choice thanks to the company's decision to provide the same "stack" used in the public cloud, to companies for their on-premise data centers. Additionally, we would note that hybrid environments are currently the preference for most companies because it allows them to maintain critical data in house while taking advantage of the agility and scalability provided by public clouds. Outside of the cloud opportunity, we maintain a positive view on the company's growing gaming business, which we believe is becoming an increasingly prominent factor in the Microsoft growth story as gaming becomes more mainstream, management works to convert its gaming revenue from one-time license purchase to a recurring subscription model and as technologies like augmented/virtual reality evolve. Finally, as it relates to LinkedIn and other subscription-based services such as O365 and various Dynamics products, we continue to value them highly for their recurring revenue streams, which we remind members, provides for greater transparency of future earnings. Target Price: Reiterate $140; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowdown in IT spending, competition, cannibalization of on premises business by the cloud


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , ,



Palo Alto Networks ; $203.76; 175 shares; 1.31%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -0.36%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe cyber security to be a secular growth trend that will continue to be a priority for cooperate investments globally in coming years. We value Palo Alto above others because, while firewall spend will continue to be a key factor supporting sales and earnings in the near- to- mid-term, we believe CEO Nikesh Arora's intense focus on cloud security will provide for longer relevance and industry dominance. Target Price: Reiterate $270; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowing global growth - particularly in the US, where PANW does the bulk of its business - leading to less than expected corporate cyber security investments, competition, cloud providers moving into the cloud security space


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (1/22/19), ,



Schlumberger ; $39.74; 1,950 shares; 2.86%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: On Thursday, analysts at Gabelli initiated shares of SLB with a Buy rating citing, in line with our own view, a "strong" competitive position, "reasonable" valuation and expectations for an international inflection. As a reminder, we believe years of underinvestment by global exploration and production companies is resulting in a deterioration of existing wells that will ultimately result in a windfall in production investments to the benefit of Schlumberger. While this has been our view for some time and we were clearly too early coming into the name, we continue to believe that it is a question of when, not if as investments will eventually be forced as wells dry up. 1-Wk. Price Change: 2.21%; Yield: 5.03%.


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe Schlumberger is the best of breed name in the oil services industry. Although the company's earnings power is dependent on the timing of the upstream investment cycle, management has a strong reputation in execution as well as a good handle in understanding the supply/demand dynamic of the industry. The company's premier technology gives it an advantage over peers and allows for market share gains. Furthermore, we value the company's international presence as it means a lessened exposure to North America, where new drilling activity remains limited. As compensation for our patience in the investment cycle's recovery, shares offer an attractive dividend that was confirmed to be backed by cash flow on the company's most recent earnings call. Target Price: Reiterate $65; Rating: Two


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, weak capital spending of upstream oil and gas operators.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (1/22/19), , , Investor Relations



Shopify ; $300.15; 75 shares; 0.83%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: We further our position in in SHOP this week. Although we continue to like the longer-term opportunities open to the company as it works to become an even more integral part of the omnichannel network for small/medium size businesses (especially following the introduction of the ), we believe the stock valuation had become full. Supportive of this view, analysts at Wedbush came out the day after our trim with a downgrade from Buy to Neutral stating, "While we continue to like Shopify's positioning, vision, and competitive moat as it builds a strong retail operating system for merchants, we downgrade to NEUTRAL, as we believe shares appropriately reflect the opportunity ahead." The analysts also noted that "most impactful announcement [from the Shopify Unite conference], Shopify Fulfillment Network (SFN) isn't expected to generate profits until 2023." 1-Wk. Price Change: -8.17%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Shopify is a leading cloud-based, multichannel commerce platform that helps businesses of all size compete on the internet. Its platform acts as a "retail operating system" for businesses and provides tools that assist in areas such digital marketing, payments and shipping. Instead of putting goods directly on an e-commerce marketplace, Shopify helps businesses build their own websites and online presence, allowing them to connect directly with their audience. Additionally, part of the Shopify value proposition relates to its benefit of scale which allows the company to negotiate online payment rates and shipping rates on their customer's behalf. Shopify also empowers small businesses and helps merchants thrive through the merchant funding and by offering cash advances. Lastly, international expansion represents a key area of opportunity for Shopify. Target Price: to $350; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowing net merchant additions, customer churn, competition, weak execution international expansion


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , ,

urn:contentItem:5WR5-2JW1-F00X-J0PP-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

While the trade war is clearly intensifying, we are viewing the market through a buyers' lens, waiting for pullbacks that improve our basis.

Markets had a volatile week as a 25-basis point rate cut by the Fed, which seemingly disappointed some in the market who were looking for a 50 bps cut, was promptly followed the next day with plans for the U.S. implementation of a 10% tariff on an additional $300 billion of Chinese goods (the last tranche). And while this next round may be taxed at a lower rate than past tranches, this time around the tax is on consumer goods and makes it so that all Chinese goods coming into the U.S. have some form of tariff levied on them.

Although the trade war is clearly intensifying and this next round, on the consumer, is the real deal, we are flush with cash and have been patient in redeploying funds raised earlier in the year in anticipation of increased trade rhetoric and political headlines. As a result we are viewing the market through a buyers' lens and will remain disciplined, waiting for pullbacks that improve our basis in order to preserve our ammo and make every buy count.

Treasuries fell below the 2.0% level this week as the Fed cut rates and President Trump threatened additional tariffs, while gold prices pushed higher into the mid-$1,400s per ounce level. The dollar index also strengthened following the rate cut, pushing to over the 98 level while WTI oil prices remains in the mid-$50s per barrel region.

We're in the heart of second-quarter earnings season. Within the portfolio, we heard from Mastercard , BP plc , Apple , Amgen , Lam Research , Twilio , DuPont and Shopify .





Mastercard reported a top and bottom-line beat with its second-quarter 2019 earnings results. Revenues accelerated to $4.1 billion (+15% year over year on a currency-neutral basis), edging estimates of $4.08 billion. Adjusted earnings per share of $1.89 (+17% YoY on a currency-neutral basis) beat estimates of $1.83. In addition to the positive headline results, operating margins of 58.3% were better than the 57.2% Street expectation.

Looking ahead, management continues to see "healthy consumer spending with some moderation versus a year ago as expected." Full-year net revenues are still expected to grow at a low-teens rate for the year.





BP plc reported better-than-expected results with its second-quarter earnings. Underlying replacement cost profit -- a non-GAAP proxy for net income defined as the replacement cost of inventories sold in the period and arrived at by excluding inventory holding gains and losses from profit or loss -- came in at $2.811 billion ("similar to a year earlier"), reflecting a good operating performance offset by lower oil prices compared with the second quarter for 2018. The result, which excludes $861 million of non-operating items, came in ahead of the $2.529 billion consensus and resulted in earnings of $0.83 per ADR.

On the release, management backed their view of organic capital expenditures in the $15 billion to $17 billion range for the year. Looking forward to the next two years, management still plans to complete more than $10 billion in divestitures through 2019/2020 as it fine tunes the portfolio. Free cash flow is expected to continue to grow as gearing moves toward the middle of management's targeted gearing range (20% to 30%) through 2020. Speaking to the company's commitment to increasing shareholder returns, on the release, management noted, "With the continuing momentum across the business, and growing free cash flow, we remain confident in our medium-term financial frame and the strength of our balance sheet. This in turn underpins our commitment to growing distributions to shareholders over the long-term."





Apple reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its fiscal year 2019 third-quarter earnings results. On the top line, revenues of $53.809 billion (+1.02% YoY) outpaced expectations of $53.316 billion. On the bottom line, earnings per share of $2.18 (-6.84% YoY) edged out the consensus of $2.09 per share.

For the upcoming quarter, management expects sales of $61 billion to $64 billion, a beat at the midpoint vs. expectations of $60.905 billion. Overall, GMs are expected to come in between 37.5% and 38.5%, slightly above implied expectations of ~37.7% at the midpoint. Additionally, management guided for operating expenses of $8.7 billion to $8.8 billion, which is in line with expectations. Lastly, management expects other income of $200 million and a 16.5% tax rate.





Amgen reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its second-quarter earnings result. Total revenues of $5.871 billion (-3% YoY) exceeded estimates of $5.686 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of $3.97 (+4% YoY) cruised past estimates of $3.59.

Taking a look at a couple key products: Worldwide Enbrel sales increased 5% year-over-year to $1.363 billion, topping consensus estimates of $1.235 billion; Neulasta sales declined globally 25% year-over-year to $824 million, falling short of the consensus of $904 million; Repatha saw worldwide sales increase 3% year-over-year to $152 million, a miss against the consensus of $160 million; and Aimovig ended the quarter with U.S. sales of $83 million, a nice beat against a $75 million expectation.

On guidance, management raised the lower end of its full year and non-GAAP EPS outlook but maintained the top ends of both. Perhaps most importantly, management provided a key update to cancer pipeline drug AMG 510 The next update is expected to come at a conference in early September.





Lam Research reported in-line-to-positive results with its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings.

On the top line, revenues of $2.361 billion (-3% YoY) were essentially in line with the $2.362 billion consensus, while non-GAAP earnings per share of $3.62 (-2% YoY) outpaced expectations of $3.42 per share. In addition to the positive headline results, gross margin as a percentage of revenue came in at 45.9% (+80 bps YoY), arriving ahead of Street estimates of 45.3%. Operating income as a percentage of revenue of 26.9% (+180 bps YoY) also outpaced the 25.9% consensus.

As for guidance, in the upcoming quarter, management expects revenue to be in the range of $2.15 billion +/- $150 million, which at the midpoint, represents a miss vs. the $2.279 billion consensus.

Working our way down, non-GAAP gross margin as a percent of revenue is expected to be 45.0% +/- 1% with non-GAAP operating income as a percentage of revenue expected to come in at 24.5% +/- 1%, both metrics coming up short vs. the 45.9% and 26.5% consensus for gross margins and operating income margins, respectively.

That brings us to earnings per share, which on a non-GAAP basis management expects to be $3.00 +/- 20 cents, also missing expectations of $3.20 per share. Additionally, it is worth noting that we can expect more buybacks in the current quarter as management's earnings per share figure is based on a diluted share count of 150 million, approximately 4.47 million less than what the company ended this quarter with.





Twilio reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its second quarter results. Total revenues of $275 million (+86% YoY and +18% sequentially for a slight acceleration) breezed past consensus expectations of $264 million, while non-GAAP earnings per share of 3 cents (compared with non-GAAP net profit of 3 cents in 2Q18) exceeded expectations by a penny.

Twilio had 161,869 Active Customer Accounts as of June 30, more than the 160,216-consensus expectation. Dollar-Based Net Expansion Rate was 140%, topping expectations of 130%. Base revenue million increased +16% sequentially and +90% YoY to $256.7 million, topping expectations of $253 million.

On full-year guidance, management raised their outlook for total revenue to the range of $1.113 billion to $1.119 billion (from $1.102 billion to $1.111 billion) and adjusted earnings per share to a range of $0.17 to $0.18 (from $0.11 to $0.13). Base revenue was kept largely unchanged, but this was due to the delayed launch of the new Verizon A2P channel.





DuPont reported mixed but solid headline numbers with its second-quarter results. Although revenue of $5.47 billion (-7% YoY) was light compared to the $5.63 billion consensus, adjusted earnings per share of $0.97 (+9% YoY) exceeded the $0.84 consensus.

Electronics and Imaging net sales were $858 million (organic -5% YoY) and fell short of the $898 million consensus. Operating EBITDA of $246 million (-15% YoY) also missed the $278 million consensus. Nutrition and Biosciences net sales were $1.558 billion (organic flat YoY) and was light against the $1.604 billion consensus. Operating EBITDA of $391 million (+2% YoY) topped expectations of $370 million consensus. Transportation and Industrial net sales were $1.269 billion (organic -7% YoY) and missed the $1.317 billion consensus. Operating EBITDA of $357 million (+2% YoY) missed expectations of $364 million consensus. Safety and Construction net sales were $1.341 billion (organic +5% YoY), missing expectations of $1.373 billion. Operating EBITDA of $382 million (+2% YoY) exceeded expectations of $328 million consensus.

For the full year, management expects organic net sales to be "slightly down" from previous guidance of up 2% to 3%. On the bottom line, management raised the lower end of its full-year adjusted earnings per share outlook to $3.75 from $3.70 and maintained the top end range of $3.85.





Shopify reported a top and bottom-line beat with its fiscal second-quarter earnings results. On the top line, revenues of $361.98 (+48% YoY) million outpaced a $350.5 million consensus. On the bottom line, adjusted earnings per share of $0.14 blew past expectations of $0.03 per share. Additionally, Gross profit of $204.8 million (49.5% YoY) outpaced estimates of $196.4 million, while adjusted operating income of $4.8 million flipped to positive from a $4.3 million loss in the year-ago period.

In addition to the robust headline results, management upped their 2019 revenue outlook to $1.51 billion to $1.53 billion (from $1.48 billion to $1.5 billion), matching consensus at the low end. Additionally, management expects 2019 adjusted operating income in the range of $20 million to $30 million, a tad short of the $29 million consensus at the midpoint. However, likely forgiven as Shopify is in super growth mode and as a result top-line results will tend to carry more weight, with investors understanding that investments must be made to keep the momentum going.

As for the upcoming quarter, management sees revenues in the range of $377 million to $382 million, well above the $374 million consensus at the midpoint. Additionally, management sees adjusted operating income (excluding stock-based compensation expenses and related payroll taxes of $47 million) coming in at $0 to $3 million, versus a $3 million consensus.



Economy

On Tuesday, the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) released personal income and spending numbers for June. Personal income rose 0.4% (or $83.6 billion), in line with expectations following a similar advance in May. Personal disposable income -- the income available for spending or saving after taxes -- also rose 0.4% (or $69.7 billion) in June, following a 0.3% increase in May. Personal consumption expenditures (PCE) -- i.e., personal spending, which accounts for over two-thirds of U.S. economic activity -- increased 0.3% (or $41.0 billion) in June, also in line with expectations following a 0.5% increase in May. When adjusted for inflation, real PCE increased 0.2% (or $21.4 billion) monthly, again in line with expectations, following a 0.3% gain in May. Notably, the PCE price index ticked up 0.1% in June, following a similar advance in May. The Core PCE price index rose 0.2% in June, also on par with June's monthly rate of advance. More importantly, on a year-over-year basis, the core index was up 1.6% in June, coming on the heels of a 1.5% annual rate of advance in May. See for our full analysis.

Also on Tuesday, the National Association of Realtors reported that its Pending Home Sales Index advanced 2.8% in June to 108.3, well ahead of expectations for a 0.5% monthly advance. Recall that pending home sales represent contracts signed for existing home sales set to close in the next one to two months. With June's reading, pending home sales are up 1.6% year over year, also outpacing expectations for a 0.7% annual increase, and putting an end to a 17-month streak of annual declines! See for our full analysis.

On Wednesday, the ADP National Employment Report was released, indicating a 156,000 private-sector seasonally adjusted payroll increase for the month of July, exceeding expectations for 150,000 added jobs. Additionally, June's reading was revised up to +112,000 (from +102,000), while May's reading was upped to +46,000 (from +41,000 previously). See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, the Institute of Supply Management (ISM) reported that the purchasing managers' index (PMI), which measures the economic environment within the manufacturing sector, fell 0.5 percentage points in July to 51.2%, missing expectations for a 52.0% reading. See for our full analysis.

Also on Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending July 27 were 215,000, an 8,000-claim increase from the previous week's revised level of 207,000 (revised up from 206,000), and 1,000 claims above expectations of 214,000 initial jobless claims. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 211,500, a decrease of 1,750 from the previous week's revised average of 213,250 (revised up from 213,000). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market -- for an incredible 230 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

On Friday, the U.S. Labor Department reported that the economy added 164,000 jobs during the month of July, a tick short of expectations for a gain of 165,000 jobs. In addition to the headline number, the unemployment rate was unchanged at 3.7% but remains at some of the lowest levels seen in decades. On a more positive note, the labor force participation rate ticked up to 63.0%, from 62.9% in June. A different, broader measure of unemployment and underemployment, known as the U-6 -- which accounts for those working part-time because they are unable to find full-time work -- ticked lower to 7.0% on a seasonally adjusted, from 7.2% in June. In July, average hourly earnings for all employees on nonfarm payrolls increased by $0.08 to $27.98, a steady rate that followed similar hourly wage gain in June. Additionally, average hourly earnings (i.e., wage inflation) have increased 3.2% from the same time last year. See for our full analysis.

Finally, also on Friday, the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured goods (durable and nondurable) in June advanced 0.6% (or $3.1 billion), to $493.8 billion, just shy expectations for a 0.7% advance following a 1.3% decline in May (revised down from -0.7% previously reported). This is a crucial reading as manufacturing is responsible for roughly 12% of the U.S. economy.

Importantly, new orders of non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft (i.e., core capital goods) increased 1.5% in June, following a 0.2% increase in May and a 1.1% decline in April. Shipments for core capital goods advanced 0.3% in May, following a 0.4% increase in both May and April. See for our full analysis.



Key Global Economic Readings

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)



Oil

On the commodity front, oil was relatively flat on the week (down ~$1/barrel) as prices advanced through the week before getting on the President Trump's announcement that he would seek to implement additional tariffs on China should progress not be made by September. While the announcement may not have been directly targeted at oil, the move lower comes as a result of the view that should additional tariffs be levied, global growth will slow further and demand for energy will decline as a result. Also impacting the move (prior to the tariff announcement) was the Fed's press conference following the FOMC meeting as Fed Chair Powell cautioned against the view that this cut was the start of a series of cuts and the dollar strengthened. Recall, a strong dollar makes the purchase of U.S. oil (WTI) more expensive for foreign buyers that must convert their domestic currency into dollars and as a result, can hamper international demand.

On the domestic front, on Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), reported that in the week ending July 26, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) fell by 8.5 million barrels to 436.5 million barrels, a bullish reading versus expectations for a 2.59 million barrel drawdown. Additionally, U.S. production jumped by 900,000 bpd to 12.2 million bpd. Lastly, net imports increased by 353,000 bpd as imports fell by 365,000 bpd, while exports fell by 718,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at roughly $7 per barrel. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive U.S.-based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.

The best-performing sectors so far have been Health Care, Materials and Real Estate, while the worst-performing have been Consumer Discretionary, Energy and Utilities.

Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.



ONES


Amazon $1,823.24; 80 shares; 5.38%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, CNBC that U.S. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper is looking into the Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure a.k.a. "JEDI" Pentagon cloud contract, which according to President Trump unfairly favored Amazon. As a reminder, the two front runners for the contract have been Amazon and Microsoft, which members know, do have the best cloud options in the world. Per the report, "the announcement [of the investigation] comes after President Trump said last month that he had from companies about the process." We will continue to monitor the situation and note that some of the prior criticism came as a result of the structure of the bidding, which was set up for a winner-take-all scenario. Per the earlier report (in the second link above), IBM told CNBC, "IBM has long raised serious concerns about the structure of the JEDI procurement. We continue to believe that the Department of Defense and our men and women in uniform would be best served by a multi-cloud strategy." As a result, given that Amazon and Microsoft do sport the two best cloud options, we believe the contract will ultimately go to one or both of these companies and again, will continue to monitor the situation and update members accordingly. 1-Wk. Price Change: -6.17%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Amazon's continued Commerce dominance, AWS' continued leadership in the public cloud space, and ongoing growth of the company's advertising revenue stream, which feeds off Amazon's eCommerce business. Additionally, we believe profitability will continue to improve as AWS and advertising account for a larger portion of total sales as both these segments sport higher margins than the eCommerce operation. And while we believe the increasing share of revenue from these higher margin businesses will be key to driving profitability longer-term, we believe margins on eCommerce stand to improve as the company's infrastructure is further built out and economies of scale further kick in. The embedded call option is that management is always looking to enter a new space and generate new revenue streams. Target Price: Reiterate $2,050; Rating: to ONE


RISKS: High valuation exposes the stock to volatile swings; eCommerce has exposure to slower consumer spending, competition. The outcome of the Pentagon's $10 billion JEDI contract is also something to watch as Amazon is largely considered to be the front runner; potential headwinds resulting from new eCommerce regulation in India; management is not scared to invest aggressively for growth, which can at times cause volatile reactions as near-term concerns arise relating to the impact on margins.

Burlington Stores Inc. ; $176.79; 400 shares; 2.61%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary


WEEKLY UPDATE: We initiated a position in Burlington this week and once additional tariffs were announced, decided to increase our position while lowering our basis as we believe Burlington to be relatively insulated from the trade war. As called out in our , on the company's first-quarter earnings call in May, CEO Thomas Kingsbury stated, "we believe over time, tariffs may cause disruption in the supply chain, which is typically a positive for off-price retailers," Kingsbury said. "In addition, if prices do go up across retail, this could possibly make value an even more important driver of consumers into the off-price channel." Plus, Kingsbury said only a small percentage of Burlington's total orders were subject to the then current tariffs. The tariffs thus far have not had a material financial impact. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.33%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Specializing as an off-price retailer, Burlington Stores sources its merchandise opportunistically, meaning that management purchases excess inventory from struggling retailers and then resells the quality merchandise at everyday low prices. The bargains Burlington's stores offer creates a "treasure hunting" experience for its shoppers, and this cannot be replicated by e-commerce. Therefore, we believe Burlington's business model keeps it immune from the pressures facing department stores, and we expect the company will continue to deliver low-single-digit same-store sales growth. Lastly, any supply chain disruptions caused by tariffs may work to Burlington's favor, as off-price's value will gain additional favor should either prices increase, or stores need to unload inventory. Target Price: Reiterate $200; Rating: One


RISKS: Consumer spending, inventory availability.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM; $112.93; 800 shares; 3.33%; Sector: Financial


WEEKLY UPDATE: Though there was no company-specific news this week, the shares came under pressure as the Fed rate cut was met with a rush into 10-year Treasury notes that saw the yield curve flatten further, a dynamic viewed negatively in relation to the financials as banks make less money when the spread narrows. Recall, generally banks will borrow (think take in consumer deposits) at the shorter-term rate and lend at the longer-term rate. When the spread between these two rates narrows, their ability to generate profit declines. Further pressuring shares was the tariff announcement from President Trump as an intensification of the trade war resulted in expectations for slower growth and therefore the view that loan growth will come under pressure, interest on loans being a key way in which banks make money. 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.83%; Yield: 2.83%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We view JPMorgan as the best-of-breed large-cap financial. The firm consistently delivers the best return on equity/tangible common equity performance in the industry, making the stock well deserving of a premium to its growing tangible book value. Not only that, but the Fortress balance sheet provides a degree of insulation to the risks associated with an economic shock. Lastly, we believe the valuation is very reasonable, especially considering the roughly 3% dividend yield and big buyback. Target Price: Reiterate $130; Rating: One


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System regulation, interest rates, credit quality.

ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , Investor Relations



Lam Research ; $204.09; 350 shares; 2.64%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . 1-Wk. Price Change: -3.16%; Yield: 2.16%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from ongoing industry dynamics that we believe will result in a coming inflection point for profitability as we enter the back half of the year. We believe that memory (DRAM & NAND) companies, which are customers of Lam Research, are currently holding back on capital expenditures in an effort to boost near-term profits and preserve cash flows, a dynamic that will ultimately result in supply growth lagging demand growth. Moreover, thanks to the digital revolution and rapidly growing internet of things space, we believe the demand for memory is becoming less cyclical in nature. As a result, we think that should our thesis prove correct and we do see a supply shortage in the back half of 2019, then memory prices should begin to rebound and lead to increased CapEx/investments in capital equipment (what Lam sells) in the future. As we noted in our initiation, the current dynamic resembles the first half of 2016, a period that immediately preceded an inflection in prices, which led to a sharp increase in Lam's earnings. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. Target Price: Reiterate $230; Rating:


RISKS: A delay in semiconductor companies increasing capital expenditures, a macroeconomic slowdown that hampers demand for memory chips.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , ,



Shopify ; $332.19; 75 shares; 0.92%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: Reported . 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.29%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Shopify is a leading cloud-based, multichannel commerce platform that helps businesses of all size compete on the internet. Its platform acts as a "retail operating system" for businesses and provides tools that assist in areas such digital marketing, payments and shipping. Instead of putting goods directly on an e-commerce marketplace, Shopify helps businesses build their own websites and online presence, allowing them to connect directly with their audience. Additionally, part of the Shopify value proposition relates to its benefit of scale, which allows the company to negotiate online payment rates and shipping rates on their customer's behalf. Shopify also empowers small businesses and helps merchants thrive through the merchant funding and by offering cash advances. Lastly, international expansion represents a key area of opportunity for Shopify. Target Price: Reiterate $350; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowing net merchant additions, customer churn, competition, weak execution international expansion.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , ,



THREES


Palo Alto Networks ; $221.56; 125 shares; 1.02%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -2.41%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe cybersecurity to be a secular growth trend that will continue to be a priority for corporate investments globally in coming years. We value Palo Alto above others because, while firewall spending will continue to be a key factor supporting sales and earnings in the near- to- mid-term, we believe CEO Nikesh Arora's intense focus on cloud security will provide for longer relevance and industry dominance. Target Price: Reiterate $270; Rating: Three


RISKS: Slowing global growth -- particularly in the U.S., where PANW does the bulk of its business -- leading to less-than-expected corporate cyber security investments, competition, cloud providers moving into the cloud security space.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , (1/22/19), ,

urn:contentItem:5VPY-98B1-F00X-J31S-00000-00Weekly Roundup2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Stocks finish week sharply lower on worries over global economic growth slowing after earlier surging on Fed's more accommodating stance.

Markets finished lower this week, selling off on Friday due to recession fears driven by weak economic reports from Germany and the flattening of the U.S. yield curve, offsetting Wednesday's FOMC meeting which indicated that we would not see a rate hike this year (versus prior expectations of potentially two hikes this year) and likely only see one in 2020. Given the material change in guidance we want to delve into what this means for the economy and why stocks reacted so favorably.

First, to understand what the guidance means for the economy, we must recall that the Fed's dual mandate is to control inflation and maximize employment. It's the inflation factor we want to focus on following the Wednesday update. The Fed uses rate adjustments to control inflation, ideally targeting a 2% annual rate; when they believe inflation to be getting too high, they raise rates, if it's getting too low, they either pause on rate hikes or potentially reduce rates to stimulate growth. So, what does the reduced guidance tell us? On one hand, it does indicate that growth is slowing, however, on the other hand, it tells us that the Fed understands this and will be more accommodative. This matters to stocks because the reduced interest rate outlook serves to make future earnings more valuable.

As we noted in our stock valuation white paper that can be found , the two main items to consider when valuing stock on a discounted cash flow basis are expected cash flows going forward (the numerator) and the required rate of return (the denominator used to discount to present value) on the security in question. If the cash flow estimates remain intact (which is indeed the case for many secular growth companies, such as those in the cloud space) and the discount rate is reduced, the present value of those future cash flows increases and as a result, the estimated intrinsic value of a stock is also increases. It is for this reason that we can get a rally such as the one seen on Thursday, despite the Fed clearly indicating an element of weakness in the U.S. economy. Additionally, we must keep in mind that a portion of the weakness can be attributed to the ongoing trade dispute with China. So, should we see a resolution on this front and global (and U.S.) growth is reinvigorated on the back of positive consumer sentiment and increased business investments, we would be faced with an environment that consists of low interest rates and rebounding growth prospects, making for a highly favorable equities environment.

Bottom line, while there are reasons to be cautious, namely global growth, there are also reasons for optimism and should we see a trade deal materialize we could certainly make our way to new highs.

Also, this week, we are proud to announce that our 2018 charitable contribution has been distributed. For the year, despite the market trading lower in 2018, we were able to donate a total of $100,838 (our capital gains plus dividends). Thank you to all our members have and continue to make the ActionAlertsPLUS club possible, we couldn't do it without you!

Treasury yields were pushed lower, to ~2.45% following the Fed's increasingly dovish guidance while as gold prices rebounded to around the $1,312 per ounce level. The dollar strengthened versus the euro while oil ended the week roughly flat in the upper-$50s, though sold off on Friday

We're in the final stretch of fourth-quarter earnings season. No portfolio companies reported.


Economy

On Tuesday, the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured goods (durable and nondurable) in January ticked up $0.3 billion, or 0.1%, to $500.5 billion, following a 0.1% increase in December. The reading missed expectations of a 0.3% monthly advance. This is a crucial reading as manufacturing is responsible for roughly 12% of the U.S. economy. Importantly, new orders of non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft (i.e., core capital goods) increased 0.8% in January, matching expectations following a 0.8% decline in December and a 1.1% decline in November. Shipments for core capital goods also increased 0.8% in January, following a 0.1% increase in December and a 0.2% decline in November. See for our full analysis.

On Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending March 16 were 221,000, a decrease of 9,000 from the previous week's revised level of 230,000 (revised up from 229,000) and 4,000 claims below expectations of 225,000. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 225,000, an increase of 1,000 from the previous week's revised average of 224,000 (revised up from 223,750). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 211 consecutive weeks, the longest streak for weekly records dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 and lasted for 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, please see .

On Friday, he National Association of Realtors (NAR) reported that existing home sales jumped 11.8% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.51 million. With February's reading, which exceeded expectations of a 3.2% advance to a 5.1 million unit adjusted sales rate, existing home sales are down 1.8% from the same time last year. The median existing home price was up 3.6% year over year to $249,500 marking the 84th consecutive month of yearly price gains. Additionally, according to Freddie Mac, regarding 30-year, conventional, fixed-rate mortgages, the average commitment rate was 4.37% in February, down from 4.46% in January and below the 4.54% average for all of 2018. See for our full analysis.

(Note: T is the most recent period, T-1 is the prior period's reading and T-2 is two periods back, the intent being to illustrate any trends)


Oil

On the commodity front, WTI continues to hover in the upper $50s as signs of an OPEC+ production cut extension continue to materialize. The news this week was that the organization canceled its April meeting, effectively ensuring no change to the ongoing production cut until at least the June meeting, where we remind members, we expect and extension to be announced should the demand/supply environment not balance out by the then. Additionally, the sanctions on Iran and Venezuela are further aiding the supply drawdown and supporting prices, despite the continued record levels of production in the US.

On the domestic front, on Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Information Agency (EIA), reported that in the week ending March 15, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) decreased by 9.6 million barrels to 439.5 million barrels, a bullish reading versus analyst expectations for 390,000 barrel increase. Additionally, U.S. production bumped back up to record levels, increasing by 100,000 bpd to 12.1 million bpd. Lastly, net imports decreased by 660,000 bpd as imports increased by 186,000 bpd, while exports increased by 846,000 bpd. See for the full report.

Lastly, we note that the spread between WTI and Brent sits at roughly $8 per barrel. Recall, this is a key metric as the wider the spread, the more attractive U.S. based crude (WTI) becomes to foreign buyers, though we note that strength in the dollar can offset this effect as foreign buyers convert their home currencies to the dollar.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we a position in Nvidia as we believe many of the headwinds that caused us to close out our original position October 2018 are either behind us or have been fully priced in.

On the other hand, we trimmed out position in Amgen ( ), Danaher ( ), Anadarko ( ), Comcast ( ) and Abbott ( ) as the market has gone on a significant run and we sought to raise cash while both booking profits near all-time highs in the case of Abbott, Comcast and Danaher, and lessen exposure to trouble positions such as Anadarko, or those with potential near-term headwinds as is the case with Amgen and the upcoming Enbrel intellectual property court ruling

Moving on to the broader market, with fourth-quarter earnings season winding down, results thus far have been relatively positive versus expectations with 67.5% of companies reporting a positive EPS surprise. For the fourth-quarter, earnings growth has increased roughly 14.7% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 14.49% increase throughout the season; of the 426 non-financials that reported, earnings growth is up 15.5%. Revenues are up 6.0% vs. expectations throughout the season for an 6.08% increase; 67.5% of companies beat EPS expectations, 23.1% missed the mark and 9.3% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 74.4% beat the prior year's EPS results, 23.94% came up short and 1.42% were virtually in line. The best performing sectors so far have been Information Tech, Industrials and Healthcare, while the worst performing have been the Real Estate, Utilities and Energy.

Next week, 11 companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. Within the portfolio we will hear from Five Below on Wednesday after the close.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: Cheetah Mobile CMCM, Winnebago WGO, Yirendai YRD, Red Hat RHT, Carnival CCL, McCormick MKC, IHS Markit INFO, Conn's CONN, FactSet FDS, Neogen NEOG, Cronos Group CRON, KB Home KBH, Ollie's Bargain Outlet OLLI, Shoe Carnival SCVL, Lennar LEN, Paychex PAYX, UniFirst UNF, Titan Machinery TITN, At Home Group HOME, Omnova Solutions OMN, SecureWorks SCWX, Synnex SNX, PVH PVH, lululemon athletica LULU, H.B. Fuller FUL, Accenture ACN, QIWI QIWI, Sportsmans Warehouse SPWH, Rubius Therapeutics RUBY, Science Applications SAIC, SMART Global SGH, Oxford Industries OXM, CarMax KMX and BlackBerry BB.

New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated over $2.46 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.


Tickers: ABT AMZN AMGN AAPL APC BP CRM CMCSA CSCO CVS DIS DHR FB FIVE GOOGL GS HD HON JPM JNJ KSS LRCX MSFT C DWDP SLB UNH PANW VIAB NVDA


ONES



Amazon


$1,764.77; 90 shares; 6.17%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: this week that Amazon is "aggressively" blocking advertisements of low margin/money-losing products from its marketplace. Through a bit contradictory to its fast-growing advertising strategy, deterring consumer purchases of these items should help the retail business improve margins. 1-Wk. Price Change: 3.06%; Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe upside will result from Amazon's continued Commerce dominance, AWS' continued leadership in the public cloud space, and ongoing growth of the company's advertising revenue stream, which feeds off Amazon's eCommerce business. Additionally, we believe profitability will continue to improve as AWS and advertising account for a larger portion of total sales as both these segments sport higher margins than the eCommerce operation. And while we believe the increasing share of revenue from these higher margin businesses will be key to driving profitability longer-term, we believe margins on ecommerce stand to improve as the company's infrastructure is further built out and economies of scale further kick in. The embedded call option is that management is always looking to enter a new space and generate new revenue streams. Target Price: Reiterate $2,050; Rating: One


RISKS: High valuation exposes the stock to volatile swings, eCommerce has exposure to slower consumer spending, competition, management is not afraid to invest heavily. The outcome of the Pentagon's $10 billion JEDI contract is also something to watch as Amazon is largely considered to be the front runner, Potential headwinds resulting from new eCommerce regulation in India, management is not scared to invest aggressively for growth, which can at times cause volatile reactions as near-term concerns arise relating to the impact on margins.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , (1/10/19), ,



BP PLC


; $43.95; 2,600 shares; 4.44%; Sector: Energy


WEEKLY UPDATE: While a reduction in Treasury yields, expectations for a weakening U.S. dollar and strength in oil are the primary factors driving shares, we also learned on Tuesday that according to a report from Bloomberg, that the "company is in talks with a solar developer it partially owns, Lightsource BP, to buy power in the U.S." Per the report "buying solar power could help BP achieve its goal of growing without increasing its carbon footprint. Earlier this year, the company agreed to better disclose how its business aligns with the Paris climate accord after coming under pressure from shareholders." We view management's focus on the future of energy as crucial to the long-term success of the company as renewable energy costs are becoming more competitive and calls for environmental reform grow louder. 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.18%; Yield: 5.60%


INVESTMENT THESIS: In addition to higher oil prices aiding the sector, we believe BP shares will see further upside thanks to management's visible trajectory toward a stated 900,000-barrel-per-day production target by 2021, a target reiterated during the companies fourth-quarter earnings conference call, and an improving cash flow profile as Macondo related payments (expected to be ~$2 billion in 2019 and ~$1 billion in 2020) wind down and the company works to reduce breakeven prices for organic free cash flow from $50 per barrel currently toward the $35 to $40 range by 2021. The cash flow dynamic also gives us increased confidence in BPs ability to maintain its dividend payout, a key factor supporting shares against any downturns in commodity prices and a crucial consideration for our income-oriented members. Target Price: Reiterate $54; Rating: One


RISKS: Commodity price pressure, Macondo liability coming in above expectations


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , (12/10/18), ,



Citigroup


; $60.98; 1,550 shares; 3.67%; Sector: Financials


WEEKLY UPDATE: There was no major company specific news and shares of the financials were impacted by dovish Fed commentary that led to a flattening of the yield curve, which in turn diminishes the ability of banks to expand net interest margins. 1-Wk. Price Change: -6.46%; Yield: 2.95%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from an expanded price-to-tangible book valuation as management executes on its turnaround initiative and believe improving return on tangible common equity performance will ultimately lead to a higher book price and multiple expansion. Furthermore, the bank's over-capitalized balance sheet provides significant room for capital return to shareholders, providing a level of support and making for an attractive risk/reward profile. Target Price: $80; Rating: One


RISKS: The economic cycle, Financial System Regulation, interest rates, emerging markets, credit quality


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: (1/14/19), ,



CVS Health


; $56.04; 2,075 shares; 4.51%; Sector: Healthcare


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, CEO to speak with Jim about changes the company hopes to make in medical care following the Aetna acquisition, working down the debt load following the deal and the company's decision to bring CBD products into stores. 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.79%; Yield: 3.57%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We see upside resulting from Aetna integration progress, which we believe will allow shares to re-rate higher as the price-to-earnings valuation closes the gap with peers, and a deleveraging of the balance sheet, which has been another concern for investors. Regarding management signaling, we also believe an inflection is coming due to the timing of management's recently announced $5 billion share repurchase program, which we view as a "call" that the industry dynamic is about to turn, and the stock has bottomed because the earnings decline is about to end. ; $155.83; 750 shares; 4.54%; Sector: Industrials


WEEKLY UPDATE: Honeywell CEO Darius Adamczyk on Wednesday about the company's exposure to the Boeing 737 Max 8 crashes. "We haven't seen any impact on our business at all yet," he said. When speaking to the broader business, Adamczyk said, "overall, the business environment we're seeing in Q1 has been relatively strong and it's been across all four of our business platforms as well as, more or less, all the geographies we participant in, which is more or less everywhere." This commentary fits the upbeat tone management provided at a recent analyst conference, which we pointed out . 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.29%; Yield: 2.11%


INVESTMENT THESIS: Following a 2018 year when the company spun off two businesses, we believe the new Honeywell is worthy of a premium to its peer group as it has become less cyclical and more focused with stronger organic sales growth trends. The two segments we remain most positive on for their long-term growth profiles are Aerospace and Safety and Productivity Solution, as both stand to benefit from strong secular trends. Additionally, we appreciate management's ability to drive operational improvements in areas such as margin and free cash flow. Lastly, the balance sheet is clean has plenty of optionality, keeping the door open for accretive M&A and/or share buybacks. Target Price: Reiterate $175; Rating: Two


RISKS: A slowdown in the aerospace market, a deterioration in commodity prices that affect businesses within PMT segment, trade war/tariffs exposure.


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , , , , , Investor Relations



Kohl's


; $67.03; 900 shares; 2.34%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary -


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: -1.40%; Yield::3.87%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We like Kohl's position in the department store industry. Its brands are tailored to middle-income buyers who shop for value, or good deals, while their store locations remain away from the mall which has been subject to decline in foot traffic. The company is run by a strategic management team who has several strong initiatives in place (standard-to-small initiatives, Amazon partnership, etc.) that drive traffic and improve inventory management. Lastly, we expect Kohl's to be a large beneficiary of peer closings (like Bon-Ton), resulting in increased market share. Target Price: Reiterate $90; Rating: Two


RISKS: A decline in consumer spending, shifts in consumer fashion preferences, margin pressure related to increased competition,


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , ,



Microsoft Corp


; $117.05; 600 shares; 2.73%; Sector: Technology


WEEKLY UPDATE: This week, management presented at the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco, providing on the company's xCloud game streaming platform. TheStreet.com's Annie Gaus was on location, providing updates and . 1-Wk. Price Change: 0.98% Yield: 1.57%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe the cloud to be a secular growth trend and that upside to shares will result from Microsoft's hybrid cloud leadership as the company grab's market in this expanding industry. While companies may look to build out multi-cloud environments, Microsoft's Azure offering will be a prime choice thanks to the company's decision to provide the same "stack" used in the public cloud, to companies for their on-premise data centers. Additionally, we would note that hybrid environments are currently the preference for most companies because it allows them to maintain critical data in house while taking advantage of the agility and scalability provided by public clouds. Outside of the cloud opportunity, we maintain a positive view on the company's growing gaming business, which we believe is becoming an increasingly prominent factor in the Microsoft growth story as gaming becomes more mainstream, management works to convert its gaming revenue from one-time license purchase to a recurring subscription model and as technologies like augmented/virtual reality evolve. Finally, as it relates to LinkedIn and other subscription-based services such as O365 and various Dynamics products, we continue to value them highly for their recurring revenue streams, which we remind members, provides for greater transparency of future earnings. Target Price: Reiterate $118; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowdown in IT spending, competition, cannibalization of on premises business by the cloud


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , ,



Palo Alto Networks


; $243.36; 275 shares; 2.59%; Sector: Info. Tech.


WEEKLY UPDATE: None 1-Wk. Price Change: 1.09% Yield: 0.00%


INVESTMENT THESIS: We believe cyber security to be a secular growth trend that will continue to be a priority for cooperate investments globally in coming years. We value Palo Alto above others because, while firewall spend will continue to be a key factor supporting sales and earnings in the near- to- mid-term, we believe CEO Nikesh Arora's intense focus on cloud security will provide for longer relevance and industry dominance. Target Price: Reiterate $285; Rating: Two


RISKS: Slowing global growth - particularly in the U.S., where PANW does the bulk of its business - leading to less than expected corporate cyber security investments, competition, cloud providers moving into the cloud security space


ACTIONS, ANALYSIS & MORE: , , , (1/22/19), ,
