urn:contentItem:5S86-P6C1-JCHV-V000-00000-00Weekly Roundup2018-05-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

A strong Friday failed to keep markets in positive territory.



Weekly Roundup

Markets retreated this week despite a strong rebound on Friday. We received several key earnings releases during the week, including Apple , which had a positive impact on investor sentiment. Additionally, we received the all-important April U.S. nonfarm payroll numbers, which came in a tad light but benefited from a strong February revision and a move lower in the unemployment rate.

Looking ahead, we continue to monitor what Jim Cramer calls the "Three Ts" -- Trump, Trade and Tariffs. These include ongoing U.S.-China trade negotiations, as well as President Donald Trump's decision (due May 12) on whether to continue abiding by the agreement designed to prohibit Iran from developing nuclear weapons.

Ten-year U.S. Treasury yields continue to bump up against the 3% mark, but have yet to hold above that psychologically important level. Gold ticked lower as the U.S. dollar strengthened relative to the euro. Lastly, oil pushed higher as it tried to take out the $70-per-barrel level.

First-quarter earnings season is also well underway, and results have so far been relatively positive vs. expectations. Within the portfolio, we heard not only from Apple, but also from Allergan , Emerson Electric , DowDuPont and Magellan Midstream .



Allergan Earnings

AGN reported a first-quarter top- and bottom-line beats on Monday. Revenues rose 2.7% year over year to $3.67 billion, topping the consensus of $3.59 billion. Adjusted earnings per share of $3.74 (up 11.6% year over year) likewise exceeded the consensus of $3.35.

Management also raised full-year 2018 non-GAAP guidance to sales of $15.15 billion to $15.35 billion, and adjusted EPS to $15.65 to $16.25. But despite Allergan's strong results and raised guidance, shares came under pressure after CEO Brent Saunders provided a more cautious tone surrounding the company's potential breakup. After Jim's interview with Saunders on CNBC's Mad Money, we hold a more constructive tone to a possible breakup. We remain patient and hopeful that a larger announcement will occur down the road.



Emerson Electric Results

EMR unveiled reported Tuesday that it beat analyst estimates on both the top and bottom lines of its 2018 fiscal-second-quarter results. Revenues of $4.25 billion (up 19% year over year) topped the consensus of $4.21 billion, and earnings per share of $0.76 (up 31% year over year) exceeded the consensus by $0.04.

In Automation Solutions, net sales of $2.77 billion beat expectations of $2.69 billion on strong demand for short-cycle repair and maintenance and a strong oil and gas market. At Commercial and Residential Solutions, sales missed vs. expectations due to softness in Climate Technologies. However, management expects demand to accelerate in 2018's second half. Lastly, management raised full-year EPS guidance to $3.10 to $3.20. The company also now expects full-year underlying sales to grow 7%, which represents the top end of previously communicated guidance.



Apple's Report

On Tuesday, Apple reported a top- and bottom-line beat with its fiscal second-quarter result. Revenues of $61.1 billion (up 15.5% year over year) topped the consensus of $60.98 billion, and earnings per share of $2.73 (up 30% year over year) exceeded consensus of $2.69.

The iPhone's unit sales of 52.2 million edged out what analysts were expecting, but total smartphone revenue of roughly $38 billion fell short of expectations. Offsetting this weakness was the company's Services segment, where revenue increased an impressive 31% year over year to $9.19 billion. In each of Apple's geographical segments, Services revenue grew a minimum of 25%. These strong results support our view that AAPL's fast-growing services business is the key to any pro-Apple thesis.

Chinese sales also increased by their largest rate in 10 quarters, which eased concerns that Apple products would be boycotted in the region. Lastly, the company announced that it would dip into its large cash pile to buy back $100 billion worth of stock.



DowDuPont's Release

DowDuPont beat analysts' top- and bottom-line estimates on first-quarter earnings Thursday. DWDP said revenues rose 5% year over year to $21.5 billion, which edged analysts' $21.42 billion consensus estimate. Adjusted earnings per share rose 7% from the same period last year to hit $1.12, beating the consensus by two cents.

In light of the noisy quarter in Agriculture, where some revenue will shift from the first to second quarter due to weather, it was a solid quarter for the company. For example, DowDuPont's Materials Science division's sales were $12.029 billion. Year over year, volumes increased 8%, local prices increased 5% and the company realized a 4% benefit from favorable currency rates.

In Specialty Products, sales were $5.597 billion. Year over year, volumes increased 3%, local price grew 2% and the division got a 4% gain from currency rates. DWDP said the division also enjoyed a 2% increase from "portfolio actions/other." Lastly, the company achieved cost synergies from the 2017 Dow Chemical and DuPont merger faster than previously anticipated, while management remains on track with its timeline to eventually split DowDuPont into three.



Magellan Midstream Results

On Thursday, Magellan Midstream Partners reported a top- and bottom-line beat on its fiscal first-quarter results. On the top line, revenue of $678.78 million exceeded consensus of $675 million. On the bottom line, EPS adjusted to exclude mark-to-market commodity-related pricing adjustments and an unfavorable one-time pension correction came in at $1.05, surpassed analyst expectations of just $1.

Within Transportation & Terminals (about 64% of total company sales), revenue of $431.9 million represented a 10% year-over-year gain, but missed analyst estimates of $441 million.

But in product sales (about 36% of total sales), revenue of $241.6 million (-1.64% YoY) easily beat out expectations of $218 million. Affiliate-management-fee revenue of $5.3 million also pushed past estimates of $4.4 million.

As for expansion projects, Magellan expects to spend roughly $950 million in 2018 and $425 million in 2019 to complete its current slate of construction. $100 million above prior guidance.



The U.S. Economy

The U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis reported Monday the month-over-month personal income rose 0.3% (or $47.8 billion) in March -- short of expectations of a 0.4% increase, but on par with February's reading. Personal disposable income also increased 0.3% in March, in line with February's rate.

Personal consumption expenditures (PCE) increased 0.4% (or $61.7 billion) month over month, also in line with expectations and an acceleration from February's flat reading. When adjusted for inflation, real PCE also increased by 0.4% monthly.

Notably, the PCE price index was flat in March, following a 0.2% increase in February. The Core PCE price index (which takes out food and energy to reduce month-to-month volatility) advanced 0.2% in March, in line with February's pace advance. More importantly, on a year-over-year basis, the core index is up 1.9%, in line with consensus following a 1.6% annual advance in February. Click for our full analysis.

On Tuesday, the Institute of Supply Management reported that the Purchasing Managers' Index decreased 2.0% in April to 57.3%, missing expectations of a pullback to 58.5%. For reference, the PMI has reached a high of 60.8% and a low of 55.5% over the 12 months ended April 30, averaging 58.4%.

The April reading follows March's 59.3% print and marks the 108 consecutive month of expansion in the overall U.S. economy and the 20th straight month of gains in U.S. manufacturing. In addition to the headline reading, the new orders index decreased 0.7% month over month to 61.2% (indicating a slower rate of growth). Production also contracted 3.8% to 57.2%, but prices for raw materials (an input for manufacturers) increased 1.2% to 79.3% (indicating growth at a faster pace). Lastly, the employment index declined 3.1% to 54.2%. Click for our full take.

On Wednesday, the ADP National Employment Report was released, indicating a 204,000 private-sector seasonally adjusted payroll increase for April, edging out expectations for 200,000 added jobs. However, offsetting the positive report, the organization downwardly revised March's reading to +228,000 from the +241,000 previously reported.

Within the goods-producing sector, the construction industry led the way, adding 27,000 jobs. This was followed by an increase of 10,000 jobs in the manufacturing industry and a gain of 7,000 jobs in natural resources/mining.

By business size, we saw gains across the board, with small businesses (one to 49 employees) adding 62,000 jobs, midsize businesses (50to 499 employees) adding 88,000 workers and large businesses (500+ employees) adding 54,000. See our full analysis .

On Thursday, the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured goods (durable and non-durable) increased in March for the seventh time in eight months, advancing 1.6% to $507.7 billion. The reading exceeded expectations of a 1.4% rise and came on the heels of a 1.6% increase in February. This is a crucial reading, as manufacturing is responsible for roughly 12% of the U.S. economy.

Shipments, which have increased in 15 of the last 16 months, gained another 0.4% to $502.8 billion in March, rising on the heels of a 0.2% February rise. Unfilled orders advanced for the sixth time in seven months, rose 0.8% to $1.1538 trillion following a 0.3% increase in February. Lastly, inventories, up in 16 of the last 17 months, added 0.3% last month to $677.3 billion after a 0.4% February increase.

Importantly, new orders of non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft (i.e., core capital goods) fell 0.4% in March. This follows a 1% increase in February, but a 0.3% pullback in January. Recall that capital goods aren't items sold to consumers, but are tangible goods used in manufacturing consumer goods. For this reason, the core-capital-goods level is a key metric that many consider a proxy for business investments. You can click for our full alert.

Also on Thursday, the Institute of Supply Management reported that the April Non-Manufacturing Index, which tracks the service sector of the economy, fell to 56.8%. That missed expectations of a pullback to only 58.1% from March's 58.8% reading.

This follows Monday's report on the manufacturing sector (see ), which also missed expectations, coming in at 57.3% vs. 58.5% expected. For perspective, over the past 12 months, the NMI has averaged 57.6%, with a high of 59.9% and a low of 54.3%. Importantly, according to Anthony Nieves, chair of the Institute for Supply Management, "the past relationship between the NMI and the overall economy indicates that the NMI for April (56.8%) corresponds to a 2.9% increase in real gross domestic product on an annualized basis." Click for our original analysis.

On Thursday, the U.S. Labor Department reported Thursday that initial jobless claims for the week ending April 28 were 211,000. That's +2,000 claims from the previous week's unrevised level of 209,000, but 14,000 below analysts' expectations of 225,000. (Claims-taking procedures in the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico have yet to return to normal.)

Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 221,500, a decrease of 7,750 from last week's unrevised level of 229,250. That's the lowest four-week moving average dating back to March 3, 1973's 221,250.

The low layoff rate reflects a strengthening labor market, as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy job market - for an incredible 165 consecutive weeks. That's the longest streak dating back to 1967. The previous longest stretch ended in April 1970 after 161 weeks. For the official weekly release, see .

Finally, on Friday, the Labor Department reported that the economy added 164,000 nonfarm jobs during April -- below expectations of 192,000 gains. Labor also downwardly revised March's reading to +324,000 from the +326,000 previously reported. However, the agency upwardly revised February's reading to +135,000 from the previous +103,000. With these revisions, job gains have now averaged 208,000 over the past three months.

Meanwhile, the U.S. unemployment rate fell to an 18-year low of 3.9% following six months at 4.1%. The latest reading is well below the Federal Reserve's 4.5% normal long-run rate. See for our full analysis.



Key Global Economic Readings



Oil

It was a relatively light news week on the commodities front, but oil prices increased as investors speculated on how a U.S. withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal could affect the global energy-supply chain.

Next week will be interesting, because as noted above, observers expect President Trump to provide his final decision on the matter on Saturday, May 12. Should Trump decide to reimpose sanctions on Iran, we could see an oil-price boost, as any reduction Iranian exports would further strain the global supply dynamic.

Compounding this are ongoing oil shortages in Venezuela and Angola. However, working against these dynamics is the strengthening dollar, which serves to make U.S. exports more expensive to foreign buyers.

On the domestic front, on Wednesday, the U.S.Energy Information Agency (EIA), reported that in the week ending April 27, U.S. stockpiles (excluding those in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) increased by 6.2 million barrels, greatly missing expectations of a 739,000-barrel increase. Additionally, U.S. production increased by 33,000 barrels per day (bpd) to yet another weekly record at 10.619 million bpd.

Net imports increased by 263,000 bpd as imports increased by 80,000 bpd and exports declined by 183,000 bpd. Lastly, we note that the spread between West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude continues to hold at roughly $5 a barrel. Recall, this is a key metric, as the wider the spread, the more attractive U.S. WTI becomes to foreign buyers -- a factor compounded by the prolonged weakness in the dollar. Click for the full report.



Portfolio Changes

In the portfolio this week, we initiated positions in Textron and WestRock . Regarding Textron, we see upside resulting from strength in the aerospace market and a recovery in the business-jet market. As for WestRock, we believe the rising adoption of e-commerce -- coupled with cost-input tailwinds -- will result in increased revenue and margin expansion.

We also added to our positions in PayPal , 3M , PepsiCo , Emerson, DowDuPont and JPMorgan , taking advantage of weakness to either lower our basis or (in the case of DowDuPont and PepsiCo) buy back shares originally sold at higher levels.

Additionally, we trimmed our stake in Nordstrom , booking profits and freeing ourselves up to buy back the stock later on any material pullback. We also trimmed shares of Eli Lilly following a nice post-earnings run for the shares.

Lastly, we took advantage of strength to close out our position in Magellan Midstream, in line with our "Three" rating on the stock. Although we believe MMP is the best among its peers, U.S. regulatory revisions to how much master limited partnerships can earn will make it much more difficult for them to maintain the distribution growth level that investors have become accustomed to. As a result, we think the market could apply a discount to the whole group.

See to review our trade alerts in more detail.



Stocks

Moving on to the broader market, first-quarter earnings are underway and have so far been positive vs. expectations, with 79.5% of companies reporting a positive EPS surprise. Thus far, first-quarter S&P 500 earnings growth has increased roughly 24.6% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 23.19% increase throughout the season.

Of the 258 non-financials that have reported so far, earnings grew 24.3% and revenues were up 8.6%. That's surpassing expectations for a 7.69% increase throughout the season.

So far, 79.5% of companies beat EPS expectations, 14.4% missed the mark and 6.2% were in line with consensus. A year ago, 89.23% beat the prior year's EPS, 10% came up short and 0.51% were virtually in line.

Information Technology, Consumer Staples and Health Care have had the strongest performance so far vs. estimates among S&P 500 sectors, while Real Estate, Utilities and Telecom have posted the worst results.

Next week, 77 S&P 500 companies will report earnings. Among names in the portfolio, we'll here from Cimarex XEC on Tuesday after the bell. We'll get earnings from portfolio holding Nvidia NVDA on Thursday after the bell as well.

Other key earnings reports for the market include Sysco , Tyson Foods , AMC , JD.com , Aramark , Dish Networks , Walt Disney Co. , Electronic Arts , Monster Beverage , Anheuser-Busch InBev , Mylan , ADT , 21st Century Fox , Sunoco , Duke Energy , News Corp. , Yelp , TiVo and Thomson Reuters .

New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated $1.8 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.



Ones


Abbott Laboratories ; $58.74; 900 shares; 2.01%; Sector: Healthcare

Shares of Abbott Laboratories moved lower this week and underperformed the broader market. There were two small, company specific announcements this week, but neither were representative of why shares fell. on Wednesday, Japan granted national reimbursement for XIENCE Sierra, and on Thursday the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the Advisor HD Grid Mapp Catheter. Our long-term thesis in Abbott relates to the robust amount of new medical devices that are new to launch and should contribute to strong organic sales growth in 2018. Included in this product list is the FreeStyle Libre, Alinity System, HeartMate 3, and the Confirm RX Insertable Cardiac Monitor. Furthermore, we expect Abbott's Established Pharmaceutical business to rebound two quarters from now that should help boost sales in the business. Lastly, the integrations of St. Jude Medical and Alere have been paying off for the company, and the company has a solid business in Nutrition. We reiterate our $65 price target.


Amazon ; $1,580.95; 100 shares; 6%; Sector: Information Technology

Shares of Amazon edged higher this week and outperformed the broader market. On Wednesday, it was reported that the company has begun offering retailers discounts on credit-card fees if they adopt the Amazon Pay service. Though this news is representative of Amazon's disruptive nature, as we wrote in our alert , we do not believe they will lure merchants away from systems like PayPal. In other news, it was reported that Amazon has plans to offer new Whole Foods perks to Amazon Prime members. Amazon's commitment to its Flywheel via Prime subscriptions is one reason why the company has been and will continue to be so successful. Also, we remind members that Prime subscriptions will carry a new price tag of $119 per year, and the additional fees should directly improve the company's bottom line. Outside of subscriptions, the big profit boosters within the company is in Amazon Web Services and its advertising business. In the most recent print, AWS accelerated for the second quarter in a row, and Amazon's "Advertising/other" segment reached a record $8 billion annual run rate last quarter. To read more about last week's earnings report, please see our alert . We reiterate our $1,850 price target.


Comcast ; $31.96; 2,400 shares; 2.91%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary

Shares edged higher this week thanks to a strong move on Friday into the weekend. We view shares as highly attractive at current levels for those that have either not initiated a position or are seeking to lower their cost basis as despite the stock weakness, company fundamentals remain solid thanks to a diverse revenue stream and sold free cash flows equal to roughly 100% of net income. Speaking to revenue diversity we cannot overstress the importance of this for a cable company in a world where "cord cutting" is on the rise; while this trend is occurring industry wide Comcast's X1 platform has proven "stickier" than others and its robust broadband offering has provided an offset for the cable weakness, a trend we believe will continue as subscribers increasingly move away from traditional Pay-TV to online streaming (and gaming) platforms that require high speed internet. Additionally, by offering several in-home services (plus Xfinity Mobile) Comcast can increase its average revenue per user by bundling its offerings. Lastly, with the weather improving we expect increased activity at the company's theme park locations. We reiterate our $45 price target.


Darden Restaurant ; $92.83; 300 shares; 1.06%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary

Despite this week's move lower, we continue to see upside resulting from increased levels disposable income (resulting from wage inflation and tax reform) and improving weather conditions, two factors that we believe will prompt more family outings rather than ordering in or cooking at home. Helping to increase our conviction, we remind members that last week, we received positive results from both Chipotle Mexican Grill and Domino's Pizza and the March retail sales number indicated an uptick in sales at food services & drinking places. We reiterate our $98 price target.


DowDuPont ; $64.47; 1,375 shares; 3.36%; Sector: Chemicals

Shares of DowDuPont edged higher this week. On Thursday the company reported a very strong quarter and provided encouraging guidance that led us to upgrade our rating to a ONE as we bought shares here ( ). Both Specialty Products and Materials Science produced strong sales and EBITDA growth, and the lagging nature of Agriculture was simply due to a season shift that will benefit the second quarter. The company also achieved faster than expected cost synergies, and we are optimistic that CEO Ed Breen will find opportunities to create additional synergies once each entity becomes more focused. To read more of our analysis from the quarter, please see our Alert here ( ). We reiterate our $85 price target.


Emerson Electric
; $68.42; 1,100 shares; 2.85%; Sector: Industrials

Shares of Emerson Electric pushed higher this week and outperformed the broader market. The company reported its fiscal second quarter earnings on Tuesday, and it beat on both the top and bottom lines and raised full year earnings guidance. Furthermore, management expects full year underlying (organic) sales growth to come in at 7%, which was the top end of its previous range. CEO David Farr also gave an excellent conference call as he reiterated his conviction that they are not at the top of a business cycle, and this increased our confidence in our position. To read our analysis of the quarter and the highlights of the conference call, pleas see our alerts . We reiterate our $80 price target.


Alphabet

; $1,051; 70 shares; 2.79%; Sector: Technology

Shares of Alphabet pushed higher this week and outperformed the broader market. On Monday, CNBC reported that the Google Cloud increased its share in the market by one percentage point to 6%. Despite the Google Cloud representing the lowest share out of the big 3 (AWS and Microsoft are the other two) we believe that there is plenty of opportunities to go around in this secular growing theme. We view Alphabet at its current levels as underappreciated because investors continue to sell the stock on fears of rising traffic acquisition costs and capital expenditures. Although these two trends have compressed margins, we believe they are for cause. Mobile advertisements are naturally associated with higher TAC, and this is just a price the company must pay because mobile ads have been a driver of Alphabet's impressive top line performance. Additionally, investors have shunned Alphabet's increased capital expenditures, and this is an opposite reaction to how other big tech companies have been viewed. We reiterate our $1300 price target.


Goldman Sachs ; $234.94; 500 shares; 4.46%; Sector: Financials

Despite the prolonged weakness in shares, we continue to view the current environment, in which volatility has returned and interest rates are on the rise as highly favorable for Goldman Sachs. Speaking to volatility, we remind members that in the bank's most recent quarterly release, FICC (fixed income, currency and commodity) and Equity revenues increased 23% year over year and 38% year over year, respectively. As for rising rates and increased Fed activity, two factors we have increased confidence in following this week's Personal Spending report, which showed an acceleration of the core PCE price index to 1.9% YoY, slightly below the Fed's 2.0% target rate, we remind members of CFO, Marty Chavez's comments from the company's 4Q17 release that "higher interest rates and more active central banks often correlate with higher client activity." We reiterate our $285 target.


Honeywell; $143.89; 850 shares; 4.64%; Sector: Industrials

Shares of Honeywell declined this week, though there was no company specific news that drove trading in either direction. One reason why we like this high-quality industrial is for its booming aerospace division that greatly exceeded expectations in the first quarter. Because organic growth was so strong (and part of this was due to a bounce back in business aviation), management increased its full year organic sales guidance well above previous indications. Also, the company's free cash flow performance is robust, and management is committed this year to using its funds on either merger and acquisition activity or a large buyback. Lastly, the company has an upcoming catalyst event through the spinoffs of its Transportation and Homes Business systems. We reiterate our $175 price target.


Illinois Tool Works ; $145.47; 475 shares; 2.62%; Sector: Industrials

Shares bounced back this week on little news, in line with our belief that the post-earnings selloff had been somewhat overblown. We continue to like ITW and believe shares have begun to put in a bottom around the $140 level. As we noted last week, we view ITW to be a case of a broken stock, not a broken company and believe the post-earnings selloff to have been overdone, providing a buying opportunity, which is why we bought back shares following last week's release and doubled down the following day. Our positive outlook is due to a strong management that has successfully implemented the 80/20 business model, in which intense focus is placed on the 20% of products/customers responsible for 80% of sales/profits, and the company's significant revenue diversity, which we believe provides resilience despite weakness in any one or two end markets. We reiterate our $175 target.


JPMorgan Chase & Co. ; $108.43; 700 shares; 2.88%; Sector: Financials

Despite weakness in the financials, we remain bullish on shares of JPM as we believe the stock to be disconnected from both company and macroeconomic fundamentals. Regarding firm fundamentals, we remind members that with its 1Q18 earnings release, the bank showed an improved efficiency ratio (operating expenses/revenue), a strong financial position with its CET1 ratio (which compares core equity capital to total risk-weighted assets) and a 4% annual increase in tangible book value compounded by a very strong 19% return on tangible common equity. As for the macroeconomic environment, we maintain that rising interest rates provide the ability to increase net interest margins (the spread between the banks cost of capital and what it charges to load out that capital) by generating higher returns on loans and the company's deposit base. Lastly, JPMorgan continues to maintain a "fortress" balance sheet that we believe deserves a premium given the increased difficulty of this year's Fed CCAR ("stress") test, something we believe may prove to be the next major catalyst allowing strong banks such as JPMorgan to shine and push higher. We reiterate our $130 target.


Kohl's ; $63.10; 1,000 shares; 2.39%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary

Shares pushed higher this week despite a slight miss on the March Personal Spending report. In addition to tax reform, investments in technology and an increase in disposable income leading higher levels of shopping activity, we have also suggested that the company's partnership with Amazon, in which select locations feature the Amazon Smart Home Experience and Amazon lockers, would result in increased foot traffic. Backing this view, analysts at Gordon Haskett noted this week that, "based on the analysis, the KSS/AMZN partnership seems to be overwhelmingly accomplishing the goal of driving incremental traffic to Kohl's stores." According to the analyst, those stores with Amazon features have drawn in more customers and led to an 8.5% outperformance over other stores as customers coming in for Amazon-related reasons are indeed staying to look around and shop. We believe the success here could lead to further expansion of the partnership and thus increased same-store-sales, a key metric when analyzing retailers. We reiterate our $74 target.


3M ; $199.36; 525 shares; 3.97%; Sector: Industrials

Following last week's selloff, shares of 3M stabilized and pushed higher. Helping shares find support was an upgrade to "Outperform" by analysts at RBC Capital. A large theme of the upgrade was based on 3M's levels representing an "attractive entry point for one of the highest-quality Multi-Industry names." In the note, the analysts wrote, "While 3M's 1Q18 operating miss and 2018 guidance cut contrasted unfavorably to the parade of beat and raises this earnings season, we heard no overly-concerning, incrementally new negatives that would justify this severe sell-off." This view echoes our analysis that we wrote in our alert , and we reiterate our $250 price target.


Nucor ; $62.94; 800 shares; 1.91%; Sector: Industrials

With shares bouncing firmly off of the $60 level, we remain bullish on shares of Nucor, believing there to be a disconnect between the company (and industry fundamentals) and the stock. Backing this view, we remind members that during the company's most recent conference call, management called for earnings to "increase significantly" in the second quarter thanks to the recently implemented steel import tariffs designed to clamp down on dumping from overseas. Lastly, we remind members that while the company beat earnings on both the top and bottom lines in first quarter release, the tariffs were not signed into law until March, i.e. the real benefits are yet to come. We reiterate our $75 price target.


PayPal ; $73.99; 1,200 shares; 3.37%; Sector: Technology

Despite this week's slight move lower thanks to news that Amazon would be looking to push deeper into the digital payments space (see ), we continue to like PayPal as it provides exposure to the red-hot eCommerce space (with core PayPal and Venmo seeing increased merchant adoption) and person-to-person payments without the need to choose a specific ecosystem (as core PayPal/Venmo is available on all major platforms, and online) or credit card provider such as Visa or Mastercard. Furthermore, with mobile payment volumes increasing 52% YoY and Venmo still in the initial stages of monetization we continue to see longer-term upside, especially as the company pushes into emerging markets where mobile adoption still has plenty of room to run and where many consumers prefer digital payment options that eliminate the need to carry cash. Lastly, there is management's push to increase services for the "underbanked," a factor that serves to increase the company's total addressable market. We look forward to learning more on Saturday during our , where we will be hosting a conversation with CEO Dan Schulman. We reiterate our $90 target.


PepsiCo ; $98.99; 650 shares; 2.44%; Sector: Consumer Staples

We view the selling in PepsiCo, which has brought the stock down to nearly a 3.8% dividend yield and only 17x earnings to be overdone, which is why we used the weakness to increase our stake , buying back shares that we originally sold much higher. Like our view on ITW and GS, we view this to be another case of a stock being disconnected from company fundamentals and attribute a good portion of the selling to the fact that the consumer packaged-goods group have recently fallen from favor. However, as we noted in our trade alert, we expect PEP to rebound as the group's pressures abate and believe the current risk/reward profile to be highly advantageous. We continue to believe that the Frito-Lay division provides for a strong offset to North American Beverage weakness and has been a key factor allowing the company to maintain its 2+% organic revenue growth profile. We reiterate our $130 price target.


Raytheon ; $202.54; 400 shares; 3.07%; Sector: Industrials

Shares remain under pressure despite relatively positive earnings last week as the defense sector has fallen out of favor, however, have found strong support at just under $200 per share. And while we are itching to add to our position, we are remaining disciplined waiting for a move below our lowest buy of roughly $196 per share. Despite the weakness, we remain bullish on shares as defense spending is on the rise both at home and abroad. Furthermore, while some of the pressure may be a result of apparent peace talks with North Korea, turmoil in the middle east remains high and could heat up even further as we approach President Trump's deadline for a decision on the Iran deal. We reiterate our $232 target.


Constellation Brands ; $221.28; 375 shares; 3.15%; Sector: Consumer Staples

Shares of Constellation Brands pulled back from recent highs and sharply declined this week. Sparking some of the selling was disappointing numbers by Molson Coors Brewing (TAP) who cited "weak US Industry conditions." Though this hurt TAP, we believe that STZ's beers sales represent a different consumer base. Whereas TAP appeals to drinkers of more value-style beer, Constellation Brands uses a premiumization strategy for its beverages, and they have been highly successful in this strategy. Furthermore, Constellation is leveraged towards Hispanic-style beers, and with a heavy advertisement campaign into this Saturday's Cinco de Mayo underway, we expect big sales numbers from the holiday. Lastly, we think that Constellation's investment in Canopy Growth Corp. represents a play on the cannabis industry, and the company plans to rollout related products if it cannabis becomes fully legalized in the US. We reiterate our $247 price target.


Textron ; $63; 600 shares; 1.43%; Sector: Industrials

Shares of Textron pushed higher this week and outperformed the broader market. With shares down roughly 5% from recent highs, we called this stock up from the bullpen on Wednesday. The key part of our thesis relates to the company's strong exposure to the aerospace market, and more specifically, the recovering business jet market. But Textron makes more than just business jets. The company has a strong helicopter business, they are the makers of specialized vehicles, and they also providing innovating solutions in defense. To read more from our initiation, please see our alert . We reiterate our $72 price target.


United Healthcare Group ; $235.90; 200 shares; 1.79%; Sector: Healthcare

Despite this week's move lower, we continue to like shares of United Healthcare for its defensive nature and lack of China exposure. While we remain optimistic on the macroeconomic environment and believe job growth is working to increase the company's customer base as new employees register for benefit plans, we also like that should conditions weaken, health benefits are one of the last things to be cut as other discretionary purchases will be eliminated first. Furthermore, we continue to believe that the company has a competitive advantage in the space due to its ownership of both UnitedHealthcare (the benefits side) and Optum (the services side) allowing for improved efficiencies and a more in-depth understanding of both customer needs and the healthcare business in general. We reiterate our $260 price target.


WestRock ; $59.41; 750 shares; 1.69%; Sector: Materials

Shares of WestRock moved lower this week and underperformed the broader market. We pounced on the recent double-digit pullback on Friday as we initiated a position for the portfolio. As we wrote in our initiation , we believe the company represents a play on e-commerce through the shipping boxes it produces. Furthermore, input costs are expected to decrease next quarter as the company is a beneficiary of lower recycling commodity prices. Lastly, the company has a visible catalyst in its upcoming acquisition of KapStone . This deal will increase the company's footprint in the US, and will be immediately accretive to earnings. We reiterate our $75 price target.


Cimarex ; $97.31; 675 shares; 2.49%; Sector: Energy

Shares of Cimarex fell this week and underperformed the broader market. Shares continue to underperform despite rising crude prices due to a production mix that has less oil that what the market prefers. However, Cimarex is expected to become more levered towards oil in the back half of the year. Furthermore, we like management's return-based approach to production as this strategy has allowed Cimarex to remain profitable during times where the industry was challenged. Lastly, we will hear from the company next Tuesday after the closing bell. Current consensus is $564 million of revenue and $1.75 earnings per share. We reiterate our $150 price target.



Twos


Apple ; $183.83; 450 shares; 3.14%; Sector: Technology

Shares of Apple greatly pushed higher this week and outperformed the broader market. On Tuesday the company reported its fiscal second quarter results, and the strong earnings washed away the analysts (us included) who feared the quarter would be weak. The concern into the print was that iPhone X sales would disappoint, however, Apple sold 52.2 million units which was better than expected. Also, the big talk of the quarter was the impressive revenue growth in Services-the key to our thesis. Apple's sales were also strong internationally, and we were greatly encouraged with China's 21% year over year revenue growth-the highest level of growth in 10 quarters from that region. The company announced a new shareholder friendly $100 billion share repurchase program. We view this massive buyback as a signal that management views the stock's recent woes as a long-term buying opportunity. Lastly, the stock got a boost on Friday when Warren Buffett said that Berkshire Hathaway , bought 75 million shares of Apple in the first quarter. To read more of our analysis for the quarter, please see our alert .


Citigroup ; $67.94; 950 shares; 2.45%; Sector: Financials

Despite this week's move lower, we continue to like Citigroup and are keeping a close eye on shares as they continue to approach the banks tangible book value. Recall, on a price-to-tangible book value basis, Citigroup is the cheapest of the big banks. In addition to valuation, we like Citigroup as management continues to progress toward its 2020 earnings per share target of $9 and has already reached its 11% return on tangible common equity target, hitting 11.4% in the most recent quarter. Furthermore, we believe shares will continue to see support from management's initiative of returning $20 billion to shareholders this year and in 2019. Lastly, we continue to value the bank for its strong financial standing as the Fed has guided for this year's CCAR test to be materially more difficult than in the past. We reiterate our $80 target.


Danaher ; $100.20; 950 shares; 3.61%; Sector: Life Sciences

Danaher stock dipped lower this week and underperformed verse the broader market. There was no news from the company this week, but on Monday, analysts from Credit Suisse released a report with takeaways from a recent visit to corporate headquarters. Overall, they remain bullish on Danaher, and they noted that M&A could occur in the near term. It was reported last week that Danaher had approached GE's Life Sciences business (something we speculated could happen could happen, and we think a deal for this strong unit at the cash strapped GE would be a win for Danaher. Outside of Life Sciences, we remain patient that DHR's Dental business will trough and stabilize, and the analysts at Credit Suisse said that management thinks pressure in distribution dynamics should abate in the second half the year. We reiterate our $114 price target.


Facebook ; $176.61; 475 shares; 3.18%; Sector: Technology

We continue to like shares of Facebook and believe management to be taking the correct steps so as to rebuild user trust, including this week's announcement at the company's F8 developers conference where CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced that the company had hired outside lawyers (that are well respected by congress) to monitor and clean up on any bias. Also, on the privacy front, management announced the "Clear History" feature, which will allow users to see information about the apps and websites they've interacted with, prevent the information from being stored with one's own account and remove identifying marks. That said, while the company will allow for the removal of identifiable data, it will still maintain and provide aggregated analytics to developers. We believe this to be a strong middle ground allowing for increased privacy while still allowing the Facebook platform to maintain online advertising dominance via targeted placements. Other announcements include the launch of FaceDate, the company's new dating platform and the launch of Oculus Go, the company's standalone virtual reality (VR) platform. Recall, in addition to improved security and increased video content, we believe the push into VR will be a strong catalyst for growth. The Oculus Go specifically stands to benefit from a relatively low entry price and the fact that it does not require any additional hardware, to factors that we believe differentiate it significantly from other VR platforms currently on the market. We reiterate our $220 price target.


Eli Lilly ; $78.40; 1,000 shares; 2.97%; Sector: Healthcare

Shares of Eli Lilly fell this week and underperformed the broader market. We got ahead of the big decline this week on Monday as we sold shares and downgraded the stock to a TWO because we felt the recent rally was due for a pullback, and we wrote about this in our alert . Despite this pressure this week, we believe that Eli Lilly's diabetes franchise is too underappreciated relative to the strength of Trulicity, which continues to gain market share. Furthermore, we like the company's optionality with its Elanco Animal Health business, and current commentary suggests that a spinoff is likely. This outcome carries more upside than what a straight asset sale has, and we reiterate our $93 price target.


Nordstrom ; $49.49; 1,800 shares; 3.38%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary

Despite our still positive outlook on shares, we decided to book profits this week as the stock had advanced over 10% in as many days and we felt we were being greedy by not trimming into such a move. Additionally, by trimming shares, we have increased our optionality moving forward and freed up space to buyback shares should they move lower on news unrelated to the company or stock. Despite the sale, we reiterate that we are longer-term bullish on shares as NYC Men's store is now open for business (with another location set to open next year) and EBIT as a percentage of sales is expected to improve thanks in part to significant technology and omnichannel investments. We reiterate our $60 target.


Microsoft Corp. ; $95.16; 1,000 shares; 3.61%; Sector: Technology

Despite trending lower this week on little news, we remain bullish on MSFT as Azure continues to grow at a strong pace and stands to continue to benefit from the company's transition to cloud services. In addition to the cloud, which benefits from a competitive edge in the hybrid cloud space and the largest global footprint of public cloud providers, we also see upside resulting from the continued growth of LinkedIn and the mainstream adoption of gaming, which will benefit the company's Game Pass initiative and thus further feed cloud growth. We reiterate our $110 target.


Nvidia ; $239.06; 150 shares; 1.36%; Sector: Technology

We remain bullish on shares of NVDA due to the company's exposure to three strong secular trends including video gaming, the cloud (data centers), and autonomous driving. Additionally, while we reiterate that it is not a reason to buy or sell the stock, Nvidia has also been benefiting from demand for cryptocurrency mining chips. Regarding video games, the largest portion of Nvidia's business, in addition to increased mainstream adoption, we see multi-year upside resulting from the rapid progress of virtual reality platforms and the coming era of augmented reality, two trends that will require intense graphic processing capabilities. We look forward to learning more next week when the company reports earnings on Thursday, after the closing bell, where we will be looking for revenue of $2.89 billion with earnings of $1.45 per share. We reiterate our $250 price target and will reassess following the release.


Schlumberger ; $68.79; 1,300 shares; 3.39%; Sector: Energy

We remain bullish on Schlumberger as management has guided for increased global E&P production related investment activity (US companies included) in the near future due to a lack of investments in prior years, a factor that is now catching up to them. Additionally, with oil prices holding in the upper 60s, with the potential to go higher should the OPEC/Russia production cut be extended, or we see any supply chain disruptions (such as the one we are seeing in Venezuela) we believe E&Ps could speedup investments so that production issues do not prevent them from taking advantage of the higher prices. On that note, we remind members that Saudi Arabia is highly motivated to see higher prices because it is both seeking to IPO its state-backed oil company, Saudi Aramco and needs to increase government revenue to support economic reform initiatives and the ongoing war in Yemen. We reiterate our $93 target.



Threes


Allergan ; $149.30; 100 shares; 0.57% Sector: Healthcare

Allergan's shares fell sharply lower this week. On Monday, the company reported its first quarter earnings result, and the story was not about how Allergan beat expectations and raised full year guidance. Instead, the focus was on commentary about the potential of a breakup as CEO Brent Saunders provided a more patient and lukewarm tone. This immediately caused widespread selling which we are protected against due to our minuscule "spec" position. But after further digesting the commentary and the quarter, we are now under the impression that Allergan needs time to clean up its balance sheet with its improving cash flows in order to seriously consider a breakup. We reiterate our $200 price target.

urn:contentItem:5RBV-5951-F00X-J1XT-00000-00Weekly Roundup2018-01-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisWeekly RoundupJim Cramer and the AAP Team

Markets roared to begin the new year.

Markets went off into "beast mode" with the "Santa Clause" rally coming in full force to kick off the new year. For those unfamiliar with the term, the "Santa Clause" rally encompasses the last week of December and first two days of the new year and gets its name due to the propensity for stocks to rally during this time as investors place their bets for the new year. As a reminder, we will be hosting our monthly members only call on Wednesday of next week at 11:30am and will begin taking questions on Monday. To see how to access the call, please read our Alert .

Treasury yields moved higher as investors moved out of bonds to kick off the new year. Gold prices also increased while the euro advance relative to the dollar. Lastly, oil trended higher as we've begun to see global supply and demand start to balance out and a geopolitical risk premium come back into play.

Third-quarter earnings are complete and were relatively positive vs. expectations. No portfolio companies reported this week.


Economy

On the economic front, markets were closed on Monday for New Year's day and there were little macroeconomic news released Tuesday, despite the markets getting off to a very strong start to start the year.

On Wednesday, the Institute of Supply Management (ISM) reported that the purchasing managers' index (PMI), which measures the economic environment within the manufacturing sector, advanced 1.5% in December to 59.7%, surpassing expectations of a flat monthly move from November's 58.2% reading. This marks the 103rd consecutive month of expansion in the overall economy and the 16th in the manufacturing sector. Furthermore, according to ISM Manufacturing Business Survey Committee Chair, Timothy R. Fiore, "The past relationship between the PMI and the overall economy indicates that the average PMI for January through December (57.6%) corresponds to a 4.5% increase in real gross domestic product (GDP) on an annualized basis. In addition, if the PMI for December (59.7%) is annualized, it corresponds to a 5.2% increase in real GDP annually." See our alert .

On Thursday, the ADP National Employment Report was released, indicating a 250,000 private-sector payroll increase for the month of December, and greatly exceeding expectations of 190,000 jobs added. This was the strongest monthly reading since March. However, it was slightly offset by a downward revision of November's reading to up 185,000 from up 190,000 previously reported. With this, 2017 private-sector payrolls as reported by ADP increased by 2.54 million, or roughly 212,000 jobs per month on average. See our alert .

Also on Thursday, the Department of Labor reported that initial jobless claims for the week ending December 30 were 250,000, an increase of 3,000 claims above the previous week's upwardly revised level of 247,000 (revised up from 245,000) and 10,000 claims above expectations of 240,000 initial claims. Claims taking procedures in the Virgin Islands continue to be disrupted while procedures in Puerto Rico have yet to return to normal. Importantly, the four-week moving average for claims (used as a gauge to offset volatility in the weekly numbers) was 241,750, an increase of 3,500 from last week's upwardly revised level of 238,250 (revised up from 237,750). The low rate of layoffs reflects a strengthening labor market as claims have remained below 300,000 -- the threshold typically used to categorize a healthy jobs market - for an incredible 148 consecutive weeks, the longest streak since 1970. For the official weekly release, please see .

On Friday, the Labor Department reported that the economy added 148,000 jobs during the month of December, below expectations of 190,000. In addition, employment figures were revised for the months of October and November. October's total nonfarm payroll employment decreased to 211,00 from 244,000, and November's number increased to 252,000 from 228,000. Between the two revisions, total jobs decreased by 9,000. Over the last three months, on average, nonfarm payrolls have increased by 203,666. Coming in at 4.1 %, unemployment was unchanged for the third straight month. This level remains the lowest the economy has seen since December 2000, and is below the Federal Reserve's normal long-run rate of 4.6%. The labor force participation rate (which accounts for the number of Americans looking for work or currently working) held constant at 62.7%, which is unchanged over the month and year. A different, broad measure of unemployment and underemployment, known as the U-6 -- which accounts for those working part-time because they are unable to fund full-time work -- was 8.1%. This represents a tick up from last month's reading of 8.0%. See our alert .

Also on Friday, the Institute of Supply Management (ISM) reported that the December non-manufacturing index (NMI), which tracks the service sector of the economy, declined more than expected, falling from November's reading of 57.4% to 55.9%, below expectations of a rise to 57.6%. This follows Wednesday's report on the manufacturing sector, which beat expectations, coming in at 59.7% vs. expectations of 58.2%. See our alert .

Lastly, he Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured goods advanced in November for the fifth time in six months, increasing 1.3% to $488.1 billion, after gaining 0.4% in October (revised up from the 0.1% decline previously reported). The reading exceeded expectations of a 1.1% monthly gain. This is a crucial reading, as manufacturing is responsible for roughly 12% of the U.S. economy.

Shipments, which have increased in 11 of the last 12 months, increased 1.2% to $491.2 billion on the heels of a 0.8% rise in October. Unfilled orders also advanced for the third consecutive month, ticking up 0.1% to $1.137 trillion after rising 0.1% in October. Lastly, inventories, up in 12 of the last 13 months, gained 0.4% last month, rising to $665.1 billion following a 0.3% increase in October.

Importantly, new orders of non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft (i.e., core capital goods) fell 0.2% in November. This follows a 0.8% increase in October. Recall that capital goods are not sold to consumers, rather they are tangible goods used in the manufacturing of consumer goods. For this reason, core capital goods is a key metric that many consider to be a proxy for business investments. See our alert .


Oil

On the commodity front, oil sustained above the $60 level this week as the Forties pipeline in the North Sea and the Libyan pipeline responsible for transporting crude to the country's Es Sider port came back online. However, working to support oil prices are the ongoing production cuts by OPEC, which were previously extended to the end of this year, and anti-government rallies in Iran, which is the 3rd largest member of OPEC based on production and proven reserves (as of 2016). That said, while Iranian supply disruption fears are certainly on the minds of industry experts, Iranian industry and shipping sources have not reported any disruptions resulting from the protests. Geopolitical unrest is also something seen in Venezuela (OPEC's 6th largest member in terms of production and the largest in terms of proven reserves) and parts of Africa (six of OPEC's 14 members are from the African continent). Looking back to comments made by Schlumberger's (SLB) CEO Paal Kibsgaard on the company's third-quarter earnings call, it appears Kibsgaard's prediction for a return of a "geopolitical risk premium," and a lessening of an "oversupply discount" are playing out as expected. This is a perfect example of why when Schlumberger's management speaks, investors listen.

Also working in favor of commodity prices is the frigid winter weather, which has increased demand for heating oil and natural gas, and an ongoing elevated level of demand internationally, namely from China. On that note, the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) reported, in the week ending Dec. 29th, that domestic crude production rose by 28,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 9.78 million bpd. However, despite the rise in production, inventories (excluding the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, an emergency reserve held underground in Louisiana and Texas by the US Dept. of Energy) declined by 7.4 million barrels as weekly crude exports, increased by 265,000 bpd to 1.475 million bpd. While international demand is certainly a key factor raising export levels, we also note that the U.S. is benefiting in particular due to the ongoing spread between WTI and Brent, which is still hovering at roughly $6/barrel.


Stocks

In the portfolio this week, we bulked up on our Honeywell position, adding 100 shares on weakness following "soft downgrade" from analysts at RBC Capital Markets based on valuation. Despite this, we are not deterred, especially given management's history of "UPOD" -- under promising and over delivering. We believe that expanding margins across all key segments and exposure to strong industrial end markets like aero and defense set the company up for success this year on earnings. See out trade alert .

Also, this week, we booked profits in Broadcom , Nucor , Apache and DXC Technology . Although we continue to believe in the Broadcom story for its iPhone chip production and its play on 5G wireless, we feel that given the strong move higher it was prudent to take profits and downgrading the shares to a Two based on current valuation. Regarding Nucor, we felt it sensible to book profits as the company's struggle to hit on earnings makes this stock always eligible for a pullback and much of the recent move is based on anticipation of the 232 investigations (clamping down on steel dumping from overseas) and President Trump's infrastructure plans. As for Apache, learning from our past missed opportunities, when Apache makes a run like it did this past week, it is important to sell a little bit into the rally as slow developments in the Alpine High have limited the stock's rise. With DXC, the stock is approaching our $100 price target and we decided to trim our stake based on valuation. However, we are leaving the lion's share of our position on the table as we believe that DXC still has upside, even above our target, should the stock hit on its upcoming catalysts.

See our AVGO trade , Nucor and Apache trades and our DXC trade .

Lastly, we exited our position in XPO Logistics with an excellent realized gain of over 28% that occurred in about a month and a half. We continue to believe that XPO Logistics remains an excellent play off the rise in e-commerce delivery. However, after shares spiked over 17% since the beginning of speculation that either Home Depot or Amazon will offer a bid, we have become more cautious in that earnings will no longer be the next catalyst for the stock. Instead, it may take a bid for shares to move another leg higher, and with ongoing silence about a potential deal from all the reported parties, we believe it was best to lock in this gain and raise some cash for the start of the year.

Moving on to the broader market, third-quarter earnings are complete and were largely in line with expectations, with 74.4% of companies reporting a positive EPS surprise. Total third-quarter earnings growth has increased roughly 7.8% year over year vs. expectations for an overall 7.73% increase throughout the season; of the 433 non-financials that reported, earnings growth is up 10.9%. Revenues are up 5.5%, in line with expectations throughout the season for a 5.5% increase; 74.4% of companies beat EPS expectations, 17.0% missed the mark and 8.6% were in line with consensus. On a year-over-year comparison basis, 73.6% beat the prior year's EPS results, 23.8% came up short and 2.2% were virtually in line. Information Tech, Financials and Consumer Staples have had the strongest performance vs. estimates, whereas Utilities and Telecom have posted the worst results in the S&P 500 for the third quarter.

Next week, 7 companies in the S&P 500 will report earnings. Within the portfolio, JPMorgan (JPM) will report earnings on Friday before the opening bell.

Other key earnings reports for the market include: Helen of Troy (HELE), A. Schulman (SHLM), Limoneira (LMNR), Acuity Brands (AYI), Schnitzer Steel (SCHN), EXFO (EXFO), Synnex (SNX), VOXX Intl (VOXX), WD-40 (WDFC), Lennar (LEN), MSC Industrial (MSM), Supervalu (SVU), KB Home (KBH), FuelCell Energy (FCEL), Shaw Comms (SJR), BlackRock (BLK), PNC (PNC) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
