Friday (1/12)


New folks, welcome aboard! You're reading the Weekly Roundup of the charitable trust that Jim talks about regularly on Mad Money and in his new bestseller, Get Rich Carefully. Jim put $3 million of his own money into this charitable trust so that you, the subscriber, can learn how he and the Action Alerts PLUS staff make decisions about a diversified portfolio and make money. You'll see every position in every stock, and we'll send you alerts BEFORE every trade. And best of all, all profits go to charity -- we've donated $1.8 million to date.


To learn more about how we construct and trade the portfolio, click on Getting Started in the dropdown menu of the Help link above.


We also want to be sure you're not confused about the terminology that Jim uses on his Mad Money television show: When you hear Jim refer to the charitable trust, he is talking about the trust that holds the Action Alerts PLUS portfolio. The gains from Action Alerts PLUS go to charity after the close of each trading year.


Here's the quick guide to the rating system, too: Ones are stocks we would buy right now, Twos are stocks that we'd buy on a pullback, Threes are stocks we would sell on strength and Fours are stocks we want to unload as soon as our trading restrictions allow.


Tickers: ABT ATVI AAPL AGN APA AVGO XEC CMCSA DHR DXC FB FDC GE GOOGL HON JPM KEY MMP MSFT NUE NVDA ARNC C DWDP PEP NXPI SLB EZU ITW LLY WM


ONES


Abbott Laboratories
; $58.99; 500 shares; 0.99%; Sector: Healthcare -- Shares got a boost this week from multiple positive reports including upgrades to Overweight from Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan and an Overweight rated initiation from analysts at Evercore ISI. Additionally, the most important news of the week came on Thursday, when Abbott announced that it had received Medicare approval for the Freestyle Libre, the company's continuous glucose monitoring system. With this, patients can be reimbursed up $250 per month for the device. While were anticipating approval at some point in the first half of 2018, the news comes earlier than expected and could ultimately result in an upside surprise to full-year sales and earnings. We reiterate our $61 price target.


Activision Blizzard
; $66.37; 1500 shares; 3.35%; Sector: Technology -- Shares started off the year on a strong note as the company closed out 2017 with the top two game franchises on consoles, with Call of Duty: WW2 (CoD) taking the top spot and Destiny 2 coming in second place. Furthermore, Destiny 2 was officially biggest PC launch in the company's history. With the release of these two top earners behind us, our focus turns to the official launch of the Overwatch League, with "Stage 1" set to begin next week, Wednesday January 10th. Recall, this has been a key factor in our investment thesis as we believe Activision will ultimately lead the way in eSports thanks largely to the league's strategic investors. Furthermore, going back to CoD and Destiny 2 for a moment, while the initial game sales are largely factored in, we continue to see upside as record buying will lead to additional sales throughout 2018 as gamers opt for downloadable content (DLC) and other add-on purchases. Longer-term, our optimism is reinforced thanks to the industry-wide shift to digital full-game downloads (not to be confused with downloadable content) as this will serve to further expand margins while decreasing the size of the secondhand market, forcing would be used game buyers to buy new. We reiterate our $68 target.


Allergan
; $172.29; 700 shares; 4.06%; Sector: Healthcare -- Shares bounced back this week following a bout of selling into the end of 2017 as investors sold stock to realize losses and offset taxable gains. Because of this dynamic, where the year's biggest losers see last minute selling into the year's end, we increased our stake last week, believing that any fundamental reason to sell the stock had already been accounted for and that shares we already view as too cheap had only gotten cheaper. In addition to our purchase, we upgraded Allergan to a One, as we believe that with 2017 now in the rearview mirro, shares will be able to gain traction as tax harvesting is no longer an issue. As we noted in our trade alert ( ), we believe little has changed in terms of company fundamentals since publishing our Sum-Of-The-Parts (SOTP) analysis ( ) and maintain that share price has simply become disconnected, at current levels, from the actual worth of the company itself. Shares caught a nice rally this week when the company announced its follow through on employee restructuring to cut down on costs. We look forward to hearing from CEO Brent Saunders when he presents at JP Morgan's annual Health Conference on Monday, Jan. 8 and are optimistic that he will be able to reasure investors that operations and outlook are strong while refocusing attention on the business itself and away from recent negative headlines and loss of Restasis exclusivity (a product we eliminated from our SOTP analysis). Lastly, we expressed our confidence in Botox during our We reiterate our $242 price target.


Apple
; $175; 700 shares; 4.13%; Sector: Technology -- Shares pushed higher this week, outperforming the overall market. We continue to see upside to shares as we believe iPhone X demand remains strong, particularly in China. Furthermore, as a result of this view, we believe Apple stands to benefit from a higher average selling price thanks both to the iPhone X's $1,000 starting price and the fact that base models for iPhone 8 are priced higher than comparable models of older iPhones. That said, while we realize that near-term the focus will be on iPhone sales, we maintain that the longer-term driver to shares is growth within the company's Services business. Recall, this segment benefits from an increased user base (regardless of which device users own) and brings with it a recurring, transparent revenue stream with higher margins that the overall business. The higher margins are key as this will aid in expanding overall company margins as it grows to become a larger portion of total revenue. We reiterate our $190 target.


Comcast
; $41.04; 2000 shares; 2.77%; Sector: Consumer Discretionary -- Shares moved higher this week but underperformed the overall market. We continue to see upside to shares as Comcast stands to be a major beneficiary of tax reform. Recall, the company has traditionally been taxed at an effective rate of approximately 35%, making the new 21% rate significantly accretive to earnings moving forward. In addition to the new tax rate, Comcast will be able to further monetize user data due to the FCC's recent repeal of net neutrality. Furthermore, we believe the company's strong free cash flow generation and business diversity will allow it to weather any headwinds resulting from a shift in customer trends, most notably the move away from cable (i.e. cord cutting) to streaming services. However, that said, we note that the company's X1 platform has proven "stickier" than other cable offerings as it effectively combines the new with the old, allowing for seamless transition between traditional pay TV and OTT streaming. Additionally, the company's strong broadband offering allows it to offset cord cutting as higher-definition streaming and gaming content ultimately means an increased demand for high speed internet. We reiterate our $45 target.


Danaher
; $94.71; 1000 shares; 3.19%; Sector: Life Sciences -- Shares pushed higher this week, however, slightly underperformed the broader market. We continue to see upside to shares as previous acquisitions begin working their way into the core portfolio. As a reminder, these past acquisitions, including Pall and Cepheid bring with them higher growth rates than the overall business, making their successful integrations accretive to the company's growth rate overall. Furthermore, we believe issues that have plagued the company's dental division, namely end-market destocking has finally bottomed and as a result, we see upside as this division recovers in the new year. Because of these dynamics (a recovery in dental and an integration of past acquisitions) we remain confident that management will be able to attain their guidance of 3.5%-4.0% organic revenue growth this year. Additionally, with past acquisitions becoming fully integrated and the company able to tidy up its balance sheet, we believe we could see a resurgence of M&A activity, something we believe will further aid shares in pushing higher this year. We reiterate our $104 price target.


DowDuPont
; $75.42; 1375 shares; 3.49%; Sector: Chemicals -- Shares of DowDuPont greatly traded higher this week and finally broke above the low $70s. As we discussed in Thursday's , the stock has been "stuck in the mud" so to speak with its break-up storyline, and we believe that this eventual catalyst needs patience. We have great faith in CEO Ed Breen, who did a terrific job creating value at Tyco, and we expect the same for DowDuPont. Since Dow Chemical and DuPont joined forces, the merged entity DowDuPont has been re-aligning in preparation for three, or potentially four, spinoffs. The current plan is to split into an Agriculture, Specialty Products, and a Materials company, and through the whole process, the company will generate billions in synergies, and the eventual spun companies are expected to trade at different, yet higher multiples compared to the company as a whole. Lastly, to pay for our patience, the stock yields a solid 2% that we believe is more than adequate. We reiterate our $85 price target.


iShares MSCI EMU Index ETF
; $45; 1000 shares; 1.52%; Sector: Europe -- With major European economic indicators firing on all cylinders this week, shares advanced, outperforming the S&P 500. This is the only ETF in the portfolio and was chosen to fulfill our desire to increase overall portfolio exposure to both the European market and the euro currency. Recall, we gain currency exposure as this is an unhedged ETF (as opposed to the HEZU, a hedged version of the EZU). We decided a passively managed ETF would be the best way to achieve these dual goals without possibly being tied to a specific company or sector that may lag the overall recovery taking place in Europe. Additionally, we selected the EZU over other European based ETFs as it has minimal exposure to the U.K., a region that we decided to avoid given uncertainty resulting from Brexit. Lastly, despite the nice gain we've had since initiating the position, we reiterate our One rating as we believe shares can continue rising on the back of upbeat growth estimates out of the European Central Bank (ECB). As a reminder, in the ECB's final policy meeting of 2017 (in the second week of December), the bank increased eurozone economic growth estimates from 1.8% (originally forecast in September) to 2.83%. Given that this is an ETF encompassing over 200 companies, we will not have a price target.


Facebook
; $186.85; 1000 shares; 6.30%; Sector: Technology -- Facebook's shares got their groove back this week, and greatly outperformed the broader markets. On Wednesday Variety reported how Facebook, and some other tech names, have been gaining market share of advertising revenue from traditional content and media companies. A sign that Facebook is increasing its share in the market is a positive signal that the company's revenue growth likely will increase, especially as the company finds ways to improve the community experience. On Thursday, CEO Mark Zuckerberg said that his challenge for 2018 is to fix Facebook's abuse issues. Last earnings call, he spoke about how important it was for Facebook to keep its members protected from abuse as he called the for the need of heavy investment. When we heard this, our memory of similar comments on investment immediately jumped in our minds, and despite the "investment year" label which is often a kiss of death, Facebook's shares increased about 53.3% for the year. We believe that investment and breakthroughs in artificial intelligence will lessen the amount of people needed for Facebook to monitor, and is why we are not too concerned about either costs or content. Looking ahead, we believe that Facebook will continue to increase its community audience, with the only thing likely to limit growth being perhaps the amount of people with internet access in the world. We expect to see content improvements this year through the company's investment in video, and even virtual reality, allowing Facebook to grow as a product. We reiterate our $195 price target.


First Data Corp
; $17.4; 3500 shares; 2.05%; Sector: Technology -- After a strong rally on Friday, shares of First Data Corp ended the week higher and outperformed the broader market. On Friday, Credit Suisse labeled FDC "the most interesting value paly in the payments space", which in our view is likely because its de-leveraging story will ultimately allow the stock to participate in multiple expansion. The bullishness in FDC's stock is also present by analysts at Barclays, who said on Wednesday that the recent acquisitions of CardConnect and BluePay will help the company position itself as "a key player in the integrated payments and eCommerce space". Barclays also sees GBS North America growth to inflect moving through 2018 (despite a challenged fourth quarter and first half), which if successful, we believe will allow FDC to move its valuation in-line with its peer's. We reiterate our $21 price target.


Alphabet
; $1110.29; 150 shares; 5.61%; Sector: Technology -- Shares of Alphabet rocked higher this week and broader outperformed the broader market. On Monday, the Wall Street Journal reported that Alibaba's (BABA) is surpassing Google Chrome as the top browser in some fast-growing markets in Asia. Although a negative, we do not believe this hurts the fundamental story of the company. Later on this week, similar to what we said with Facebook above, Variety reported that Alphabet has been increasing its market share of advertising revenue. Advertising revenue is critical to the company's search revenue stream, but we believe that through investment in Alphabet's Google Other products, and Other bets, the company is becoming much more than a company that relies of search advertising. Also, The Information reported that Google Cloud is working on "major" upgrades to voice and video. The report said that the upgraded service is to position Google Cloud to compete with Microsoft's (MSFT) Skype. Also that day, Reuters reported that Google is exploring a possible sale of its U.S. restaurant review guide Zagat, which is really just a small non-core asset. On Friday, the company announced that it had made an investment in a Chinese e-sports streaming startup. Although the investment is small, the investment boosts the company's investment in Asian startups. Finally, on Friday, the company said in a blog post that "we sold more than one Google Home device every second since Google Home Mini started shipping in October." This statement is a strong signal that the Google Other segment and its ecosystem of products is growing. As we mentioned above, while Alphabet's search revenue has been downright dominant, we believe that the company is becoming diversified beyond that. Investments in the cloud and AI has helped the company develop additional revenue streams, and we believe that the industry leading autonomous driving technology company Waymo is being heavily undervalued by the market. Lastly, we are also raising our price target to $1200 to reflect continued growth and optimism in the name.


Honeywell
; $155.58; 500 shares; 2.62%; Sector: Industrials -- Although underperforming against the broader market for the week, shares of Honeywell finished higher on Friday. On Wednesday, analysts from RBC Capital Markets gave Honeywell a "soft downgrade", citing that the stock's 2017 run has tempered expectations for 2018. Opposite of our view, the analysts believe that the breakup catalyst is priced into shares, and they said that expectations have "ratcheted" higher after management provided conservative 2018 guidance. We further discussed Honeywell in our Daily Rundown , and we took advantage of the weakness to our position that day. In addition to the company's breakup, expanding margins and organic growth in key segments increases our conviction that Honeywell will extend its all-time highs. Also, with a clean balance sheet, we think there is a good chance that the company pursues a merger and acquisition opportunity to beef up the core assets that will remain post-breakup. We reiterate our $175 price target.


Illinois Tool Works
; $166.03; 550 shares; 3.08%; Sector: Industrials -- Shares of Illinois Tool Works dipped slightly this week. With shares trading at their all-time highs, we admit that we were not completely surprised to see a firm downgrade the stock on valuation. This came on Thursday when analysts at BMO Capital said that the stock "has reached a tipping point for meaningfully better profitability." We contend that management's guidance of 8% to 10% EPS growth for the five-year period of 2018 to 2022 should support higher valuations. Additionally, management guided that free cash flow of 100+% of net income during the same period, and they expect the dividend payout ratio as a percentage of free cash flow will increase to 50% from 43% by 2020. Lastly, we are increasing our price target slightly to $178, which represents roughly 22.5x consensus 2019 earnings, and we feel is achievable based on management's guidance that did not include the benefits of tax cuts.


JP Morgan Chase
; $108.34; 200 shares; 0.73%; Sector: Financials -- Shares of JP Morgan traded higher this week, but underperformed compared to the broader market. Backed by confidence in the economy, the stock roared higher to begin the week, only to give up some gains Friday after a soft jobs report. Overall, it was a solid week for the stock that we will look to further build out when near our initial cost basis. We initiated a position in this financial last week because we believe that the rising interest rate environment and economic expansion will help the company deliver strong earnings per share growth. In fact, JP Morgan's earnings power is why we have this name rated a ONE, compared to Citigroup (C), which we feel is more value oriented. To re-read our initiation from last week, please see our Alert . Lastly, next week is a major one for the company as CEO Jamie Dimon will be speaking on Tuesday, and the company will report fourth quarter earnings on Friday. We reiterate our $120 price target.


Magellan Midstream Partners
; $72.45; 1900 shares; 4.64%; Sector: Energy -- Shares climbed higher this week, but slightly underperformed verse the broader market, as oil maintained its move above the $60 level on the back of increased geopolitical tension. With WTI reaching its highest closing price level in roughly three years and the spread between WTI and Brent sustaining at roughly $6/barrel, we continue to see several reasons MMP benefits. First, higher WTI prices encourages upstream companies in the Permian to continue producing at record levels, leading to an increased need for midstream services to transport crude products to refineries, or ports for export. Second, because of the ongoing WTI-Brent spread, foreign countries will continue to demand WTI over Brent as it is roughly 10% cheaper at current levels. As a reminder, to take advantage of both of these dynamics (elevated production levels and increased demand abroad), MMP is building out two new pipelines, a marine storage facility in Pasadena, Texas and an Aframax dock in Houston (recall, Aframax ships can carry 500,000 to 700,000 barrels of crude). Additionally, while the company's cash backed distribution may become slightly less striking in a rising interest rate environment, we would argue that when added to the company's growth potential, MMP remains an attractive name for those looking for both energy exposure as well as income. We reiterate our $89 target.


Microsoft
; $88.19; 1100 shares; 3.27%; Sector: Technology -- Shares of Microsoft pushed higher this week and outperformed the broader market. On Wednesday, it was reported that the company and Amazon (AMZN) missed a deadline to integrate Cortana and Alexa. Previously, the companies said that the two digital assists integrated functionalities would be available in 2017, and on the missed deadline, a Microsoft spokesperson told Paul Thurrott (who reported the miss) that "We'll have more to share soon." Also this week, after it was reported that Intel (INTC) chips have suffered a security flaw, Microsoft said that they expect to release a patch fixing the issue for Windows by next Tuesday. We continue to expect Microsoft shares to move higher due to growth in the cloud. With roughly $132 billion eligible for repatriation under the new tax cut rules, the company should have plenty of ammo to spend on either investment to beef up its offerings, or shareholder returns which are already compelling for a big tech company. We reiterate our $94 price target.


Schlumberger
; $73.6; 1500 shares; 3.72%; Sector: Energy -- Shares rallied this week as we've witnessed a number of CEO Paal Kibsgaard predictions (from the company's third-quarter earnings call) come to fruition. Recall when the company released earnings (see ), Kibsgaard noted that in the past, oil prices have benefited from a "geopolitical risk premium," a factor that was largely been replaced by an "oversupply discount" in 2017. However, with the supply/demand dynamic slowly coming into balance, and rising tensions in several oil-producing regions (now including Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Iran and Venezuela), Kibsgaard explained that we would likely see the risk premium return, which we clearly are given oils sustained move above the $60 level. In addition to this prediction, Kibsgaard also stated that OPEC would likely extend their production, something we also saw become a reality since the earnings release. Along with these two dynamics coming into play, we see further upside to shares due to Kibsgaard's third prediction from the call, when he noted that because of extraordinarily low investment levels into production capabilities of regions outside of North America, the Persian Gulf and Russia we would likely see a "medium-term global supply challenge, and increasing the urgency for higher investment." We believe this dynamic will play out and lead to an increased demand for Schlumberger's services. Lastly, with President Trump discussing the possibility of opening of offshore drilling in California and Florida, we believe that Schlumberger would be in the immediate running for servicing these platforms. We reiterate our $93 target and note this is exactly why when Schlumberger management speaks, we listen.


Waste Management
; $87.99; 950 shares; 2.82%; Sector: Industrials -- Shares of Waste Management increased this week, but slightly underperformed the broader markets. On Wednesday, the company received a favorable upgrade by analysts at Macquarie, raising their price target to $114 from $79 (note that price targets at other firms will often differ from our own). The analysts believe that the company will have "a structurally higher free cash profile". As members can , the company increased its baseline FCF figure which in turn, lead to the 9.4% increase to the quarterly dividend and the $1.25 billion buyback program. Macquarie views this latest step change as not only sustainable, but also with room for improvement due to the benefits of tax reform. We discussed how Waste Management benefits from tax cuts in our Daily Rundown video . One last point worth mentioning is that the additional benefits from the Hurricane Cleanup will boost Waste Management's revenues in either the fourth quarter, or the first quarter of 2018, representing a strong support for guidance. Lastly, while our current price target is $91, this value does not reflect our increased earnings expectations from tax cuts and we will likely raise estimates when management provides full year 2018 guidance.


TWOS


Arconic
; $29.61; 2000 shares; 2.00%; Sector: Industrials -- Shares of Arconic pushed higher this week and greatly outperformed the broader market. This week's rally was driven by a Wells Fargo analyst Outperform initiation on Thursday. The analyst gave the stock a $35 price target (note that price targets at other firms will often differ from our own), stating that the company's free cash flows will improve on moderated spending, and also margins in-line with peers should drive earnings growth. Higher costs hurt margins last quarter and caused a distinct pullback in the stock, and we believe that under the leadership of incoming CEO Chip Blankenship, Arconic will do a better job managing costs associated with the engine ramp. We reiterate our $31 price target.


Apache
; $46.39; 1600 shares; 2.50%; Sector: Energy -- Shares surged higher this week as oil sustained its move above the $60 level. With infrastructure continuing to be built at Alpine High and take away capacity being put in place to take crude out of the Permian for transport to refineries or for export to Mexico and abroad we believe the overarching picture of the U.S. oil industry is materially improving. Furthermore, while we have trimmed our position in recent weeks, we continue to see upside as the company has worked to reduce and all-in costs and stands to benefit from the WTI-Brent spread that has served to make WTI increasingly more attractive to foreign buyers. We reiterate our $60 target.


Broadcom
; $271.62; 200 shares; 1.83%; Sector: Electronics -- Shares pushed higher this week, outpacing the overall market. We continue to like AVGO as we believe iPhone X demand worries to be overblown (recall, Broadcom develops 8 chips in the new devices) and see multiple drivers for the name long-term. Within wireless we believe the pending upgrade of wireless networks will aid shares of AVGO as Broadcom creates radio frequency chips that will be necessary for mobile devices to connect to the new 5g networks. On the wired side, we believe an increasing demand for high speed data (largely because of increased demand for streaming services and online gaming) benefits Broadcom as the company has a number of offerings that address last-mile bottlenecks that occur when internet providers deliver service to end customers, solutions that will likely become more highly demanded as average internet speeds increase over time. Outside of these larger industry trends, we are keeping a close eye out for any updates regarding Broadcom's attempt at acquiring Qualcomm (QCOM) and will update members as we learn more, but we do note that the ongoing fight is will likely tie up shares in the interim. Long-term, however, we reiterate our $290 target.


Cimarex Energy
; $127.82; 600 shares; 2.58%; Sector: Energy -- Shares pushed higher this week, in line with the move seen in commodity prices. With oil holding above the $60 level we believe XEC can continue climbing higher from current levels as Cimarex is the best operator in the Permian with the fastest growth. Further backing this belief is management's previous efforts to reduce costs via field-wide automation and a strict policy of operating within free cash flows, ensuring that the company will be able to continue generating strong cash flows even should oil prices pullback. We would also note that there has been a notable shift in domestic investor appetites, with a heavier focus being placed on a company's ability to operate within free cash flows, making Cimarex a strong option for those looking to U.S. increase energy exposure. Lastly, with the WTI-Brent spread holding at roughly $6/barrel, Cimarex stands to benefit as WTI remains the attractive choice for foreign buyers. We reiterate our $150 target.


Citigroup
; $75.41; 1050 shares; 2.67%; Sector: Financials -- Shares pushed higher this week however, underperformed the overall market. Our outlook on Citigroup remains unchanged as the bank stands to benefit from both the unwinding of the Fed's massive balance sheet, which will aid in raising long-term interest and a strengthening domestic economy which serves to back the Fed's desire of raising interest rates multiple times this year. On that note, while expectations vary, we expect the Fed will ultimately raise rates 3-4 times in 2018, barring any surprise readings on inflation, GDP or the job market. Furthermore, thanks to the banks strong international exposure, we see upside resulting from the global economic expansion, which, depending on the country, likely has more room to run compared to the U.S. Compounding these macroeconomic tailwinds, we believe shares will rise in 2018 as management progresses on their indicatives of attaining 11% return on tangible common equity and $9 earnings per share by 2020 while returning $20 billion to investors both this year and in 2019. We reiterate our $80 target.


DXC Technology
; $100.63; 800 shares; 2.71%; Sector: Tech Services -- Shares of DXC Technology greatly moved higher this week and outperformed the broader markets. With shares creeping towards our price target, shares on Thursday. Boosting the stock this week was a favorable note from Barclays about IT Services. The firm listed "upside to synergies, appreciation around its 30% capital return, further financial engineering, and possible line of sight toward organic revenue growth from a mix-shift" as ways the stock can push higher. We believe that the upcoming spin of the US Public sector business represents a value creating opportunity, and in addition to cost synergies, growth in digital should benefit the company's overall numbers. We reiterate our $100 price target.


Eli Lilly
; $86.57; 1000 shares; 2.92%; Sector: Healthcare -- Shares of Eli Lilly traded higher this week, in-line with broader market. On Friday, the stock was upgraded by analysts at Argus. They believe that the "new product launches, expanded indications for existing drugs, and potential regulatory approvals as catalysts for growth in 2018". We also view the upcoming strategic decision on Eli Lilly's Elanco Animal Health business as a potential catalyst opportunity. Morgan Stanley discussed the value of Elanco on Friday, and we are in agreement that if the business is spun, it will trade at a discount to Zoetis (ZTS), but should still create value for shareholders. We see that decision by mid-2018, plus Eli Lilly's recently launched and pipeline growth story, as reasons to believe the stock can reach our $93 price target.


General Electric
; $18.54; 2450 shares; 1.53%; Sector: Industrials -- Shares of General Electric got off to a hot start this week, increasing about 6.25% and outperforming the broader market. While we cannot ignore how disappointing 2017 was for the company and the stock, we believe that this week's move was driven by investors flooding back into the stock in a "January" effect type move, but more importantly, higher commodity prices. As we have explained before, we believe that through structural changes like the sale of Finance and purchase of Power and Baker HughesGE (BHGE), General Electric has transformed into an energy company "in drag". With higher commodity prices, the company's cash flows should improve and find some support. Although this week's rally has been a strong sign of encouragement, we want to see more transparency of the company's cash flows, something we expect CEO John Flannery to address next earnings call. We reiterate our $21 price target.


KeyCorp
; $20.33; 2000 shares; 1.37%; Sector: Financials -- Shares trended higher this week, however, lagged the overall market as they have been met with resistance at the $21 level. Despite this, we believe shares will ultimately push higher as the macroeconomic environment continues to shift in favor of the financials. Recall longer-term rates stand to benefit from the unwinding of the Fed's balance sheet, while investors expect the Fed to raise shorter-term rates multiple times this year. From a firm-specific standpoint, we remind members that the bank expects to realize an additional $50 million in cost savings from the integration of First Niagara early this year. Furthermore, we see upside as operations become more efficient due to investments in enhanced digital offerings such as mobile banking and as the company looks to alter its revenue mix to include more stable, fee-based categories. Lastly, we believe that with the improving economy, the investment banking division will continue to strengthen and remind members that it has recently benefited from the acquisitions of Pacific Crest (technology expertise) and Cain Brothers (healthcare expertise). We reiterate our $21 target.


Nucor
; $67.86; 1100 shares; 2.51%; Sector: Industrials -- Shares pushed higher this week, outperforming the overall market. We believe the recent rally in shares is a result of both the ongoing 232 investigation, which is expected to clamp down on steel imports from overseas and in anticipation of details on President Trump's infrastructure plan. Recall the 232 investigation is key as countries such as China have dumped significant amount of cheap steel in the U.S., undercutting domestic producers and pressuring margins. As for the infrastructure plan, simply put, increased infrastructure development will lead to a higher demand for steel products. Should both of these dynamics plat out as expected, Nucor stands to benefit as it will be able to expand margins while demand increases. That said, we have trimmed our position slightly on the recent strength as we note that the company's struggle to hit on earnings makes this stock always eligible for a pullback. We reiterate our $75 target.


NVIDIA
; $215.4; 200 shares; 1.45%; Sector: Technology -- Shares surged this week as investors once again piled into this industry leadings GPU maker. While Tuesday's move can partially be attributed to a beaten down share price into the end of 2017 and a broad-based market rally on the first day of trading in 2018, Wednesday's strong move higher came on the back of a positive Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) report on Monday evening. According to the report, which members can view , worldwide semiconductor sales hit an incredible $37.7 billion in monthly sales (the highest-ever) in November, representing a 21.5% jump from the same time last year and a 1.6% increase from October sales of $37.1 billion. The report further increases our conviction that the tech revolution is in full force and we maintain that Nvidia is at the forefront as its GPUs are needed for everything from gaming to data centers and artificial intelligence to tauons vehicles. Also this week, Nintendo announced that the Switch has become the fastest selling home-video game console in the U.S. of all time. The chips that make the Switch go are made by Nvidia, and this is one of many examples which prove that this company is more tied to Gaming, as well as the data center and artificial intelligence, compared to cryptocurrency. Lastly, CEO Jensen Huang will be the keynote speaker at the CES conference on Sunday. We expect his commentary to be in its typical visionary class, and we would not be surprised to see the stock move higher off the news. We reiterate our $220 price target.


NXP Semiconductors
; $118.05; 550 shares; 2.19%; Sector: Technology --Shares remain unable to breakout meaningfully as result of Qualcomm's $110/share tender offer. We maintain that the current offer undervalues the company and reiterate that we will not tender shares at that price level. Further backing this view, analysts at RBC, referencing the Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) report (mentioned above regarding NVDA) released earlier this week, noted that semiconductors tied to the automotive industry were showing stronger than normal demand, with year over year revenue growth of 16.5%, compared with normal seasonal growth of 11.5%. This is important as one of the reasons we believe it would be more beneficial for Qualcomm to raise its offer (rather than walk away completely) is that in addition to still being able to realize synergies, the company would gain increased exposure to the auto industry, which, as indicated above, is itself going through a technological revolution. Despite our belief that shares are worth more than what QCOM has offered, we reiterate our $110 target pending any updates from either Qulacomm or NXPI.


PepsiCo
; $118.67; 500 shares; 2.00%; Sector: Consumer Staples -- Shares are once again meeting resistance at the $120 level. However, despite this, we maintain that shares will push higher in the new year as management addresses past missteps in shelf allocation and as the company once again returns 2% organic revenue growth. Additionally, we like PepsiCo over others in the beverage industry due to their meaningful investments into snacks via the Frito-Lay division as this segment has significantly aided in offsetting beverage industry pressures in the last year. Lastly, from a portfolio management perspective, we maintain that diversification is key and holding a staple such as PEP brings an added level of both diversity and stability to the overall portfolio. We reiterate our $120 target and our Two rating, which we will reevaluate once a return to 2% organic revenue growth has been confirmed by management.

urn:contentItem:5XC0-GDM1-JBKP-Y388-00000-00Weekly Roundup: Friday, October 252019-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:31ZLexisNexisNpr Politics PodcastScott DetrowDomenico MontanaroTim MakRyan LucasAsma KhalidAyesha RascoeSusan DavisKaren RiveraAlexandria Ocasio-CortezMark ZuckerbergBill ClintonKanye WestKatie HillWeekly Roundup: Friday, October 25

SCOTT DETROW: Quick note before we get started. We are doing a live taping of our show in Washington, D.C. So if you want to hear what we think about the latest political news or if you've just ever wondered what it's like to see a podcast tape live, join us at the Warner Theater on November 8. Information and tickets at nprpresents.org. Hope to see you there.

KAREN RIVERA: Hello. This is Karen Rivera (ph). And I am recording from Phnom Penh, Cambodia, where I have just set my alarm to wake up early enough to watch the Washington Nationals beat the Astros in the World Series. This podcast was recorded at...

SUSAN DAVIS: 1:04 p.m. on Friday, October 25.

KAREN RIVERA: Things may have changed when you listen to this podcast. For example, I will no longer be waiting but instead celebrating the Nationals' victory. Have a great day. Enjoy the podcast, and thank you very much.

(SOUNDBITE OF THE BIGTOP ORCHESTRA'S "TEETER BOARD: FOLIES BERGERE (MARCH AND TWO-STEP)")

DOMENICO MONTANARO: That is dedication. I didn't know the Nationals had such loyal fans.

SUSAN DAVIS: Well, she was right about the last game, so let's hope she's right about the next one.

TIM MAK: Go sports.

SUSAN DAVIS: (Laughter) Hey there. It's the NPR POLITICS PODCAST. I'm Susan Davis. I cover Congress.

TIM MAK: I'm Tim Mak. I also cover Congress.

RYAN LUCAS: I'm Ryan Lucas. I cover the Justice Department.

DOMENICO MONTANARO: And I'm Domenico Montanaro, senior political editor and correspondent.

SUSAN DAVIS: So late last night, we found out that the Justice Department's review of the origins of the Russia probe has now become a criminal investigation. Ryan, what's going on?

RYAN LUCAS: Well, that's a very good question. There are not a lot of details on this. We do not know when this change took place. We don't know what prompted it. We don't know what potential criminal wrongdoing investigators are looking into. Those are all very important questions.

But the fact that this is now a criminal investigation, what that means is that the team that is looking into the origins of the Russia investigation can impanel a grand jury. They can issue subpoenas to compel people to come in and testify and also to turn over documents. So those are important powers. And also, they could potentially bring criminal charges.

SUSAN DAVIS: So, Ryan, what were they originally looking at?

RYAN LUCAS: So they were looking at the origins of the Russian investigation and to essentially determine whether U.S. intelligence agencies, including the FBI, the CIA, did anything wrong, abused their powers in the early stages of the Russia investigation and looking at ties between the Trump campaign and Russia.

SUSAN DAVIS: So this is not the first investigation to try and examine the origins of the Russia investigation. The inspector general at the Justice Department - right? - has looked into this. The Senate Intelligence Committee has been looking into this. And there's never been - so far it sounds like - any suggestion that there was criminal behavior based on other investigations.

RYAN LUCAS: Well, we are waiting for the inspector general to issue a report. He has been looking for more than a year now into allegations of potential surveillance abuses of the Trump campaign during the election, looking into several other matters tied to the election as well. Republicans have put a lot of stock in that investigation. They are certainly waiting for that to come out.

And then you have the Senate Intelligence Committee, which has interviewed more than 200 people who were involved in drawing up the intelligence community's assessment of Russian interference in 2016. They have talked to basically everyone who is involved in doing that. And they came to the conclusion that the intelligence community's assessment was correct. They agreed with it. And importantly, they also didn't find anything that they flagged as raising concerns about how that investigation and what they were looking at was conducted.

TIM MAK: You know, the timing of this has raised a lot of eyebrows, too, right?

RYAN LUCAS: Right.

TIM MAK: We are deep into now an impeachment inquiry and very likely an impeachment process that goes from the House over to the Senate. And so it almost seems like counterprogramming to a lot of the things that'll be coming out in the coming weeks and months as Democrats try to make the case that the president has done something wrong with regards to the Ukrainian government.

SUSAN DAVIS: And this is validating for the president to now be able to say I am right to be concerned about it; there's a criminal investigation going on.

SUSAN DAVIS: And thank you for listening to the NPR POLITICS PODCAST.
